name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, today is International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Before we begin our plenary session, I would like to address the issue of violence in our society. We need to talk about it for so many reasons. We need to talk about it in order to free the voices of the victims and help them break their silence. We need to talk about it in order to raise awareness and express our commitment to non-violence and equality. Above all, we must talk about it in order to find solutions and put an end to this scourge that affects our society. This year the COVID-19 crisis has revealed and intensified this violence, especially domestic violence. This has often happened in a sneaky way, behind closed doors, with no possibility of escape, not least because in many Member States shelters and assistance lines are deficient or not sufficiently funded. This is unacceptable. The European Parliament will continue to insist that all EU Member States ratify the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and we will work, together with the other institutions, to present a directive on combating gender-based violence. As the European Parliament, we have set an example by turning one of our buildings into a temporary centre to house vulnerable women affected by COVID-19. Our public institutions have a decisive role to play and they must be close to the citizens, they must set a good example and be able to help them. That is also why we are all proud of the work that the European Parliament carried out during the negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework to guarantee an additional EUR 0.8 billion for the Rights and Values programme, which provides funding for gender equality, the fight against violence against women and girls. In addition, the Commission will develop a methodology for assessing Community funding to promote gender equality and to improve gender mainstreaming in Community programmes. We have a duty, as institutions, to talk and raise the debate on the violence that women and girls suffer and we must talk about it in the right words, but it is also necessary to strengthen ourselves collectively, adopting an integrated, global approach that focuses on socio-economic and institutional aspects, gender equality and women's rights. On the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, the European Parliament is committed to pursuing this objective, to doing so for women and girls, but also for all of us.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council meeting of 10 and 11 December 2020 (2020/2833(RSP)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  I give the floor immediately to The President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, whom I thank for being here.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, I come to Parliament today to report on our plans for the next European Council on 10 and 11 December 2020, but before I turn to that, please allow me to update you on two issues that will certainly also be topics in the European Council. It’s about Brexit and about the situation we are facing with respect to the Multiannual Financial Framework and NextGenerationEU. Honourable Members, these are decisive days for our negotiations with the United Kingdom, but frankly I cannot tell you today if in the end there will be a deal. There has been genuine progress on a number of important questions: on law enforcement and judicial cooperation; on social security coordination, and also on goods, on services and transport we now have an outline of a possible final text. In these areas there are still some important issues to agree, but they should be manageable. However, there are still three issues that can make the difference between a deal and no deal. The crucial topics for the European side are of course questions linked to the level playing field, governance and fisheries. With very little time ahead of us, we will do all in our power to reach an agreement. We are ready to be creative. But we are not ready to call into question the integrity of the Single Market – the main safeguard for European prosperity and wealth. This is why we need to establish robust mechanisms, ensuring that competition is – and remains – free and fair over time. In the discussions about state aid we have still serious issues, for instance when it comes to enforcement. Significant difficulties remain on the question how we can secure – now and over time – our common high standards on labour, on social rights, on the environment, climate change and tax transparency – you know all these standards. We want to know what remedies are available in case one side will deviate in the future. Because trust is good, but law is better. And crucial in the light of recent experience: a strong governance system is essential to ensure that what has been agreed is actually done. Concerning fisheries: no one questions the UK’s sovereignty on its own waters, but we ask for predictability and guarantees for our fishermen and fisherwomen who have been sailing in these waters for decades, if not centuries. Honourable Members, as I said, the next days are going to be decisive. The European Union is well prepared for a no-deal-scenario, but of course we prefer to have an agreement. I fully trust in the skilful steer of our Chief Negotiator Michel Barnier, but one thing is clear: whatever the outcome, there has to be – and there will be – a clear difference between being a full member of the Union and being just a valued partner. I am fully aware of the challenges the current situation is creating especially for Parliament and the ratification process, and this is why I sincerely thank you for your support and understanding. As in the past, we will walk those last miles together. Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren Abgeordnete! Zur gleichen Zeit wartet die Union auf grünes Licht für unseren nächsten mehrjährigen Finanzrahmen und NextGenerationEU. Die Kommission hat im Mai ihr Aufbauprogramm NextGenerationEU und den Mehrjahreshaushalt vorgelegt. Die Staats- und Regierungschefs der 27 EU—Mitgliedstaaten haben im Juli vier lange Tage und Nächte verhandelt und einen Kompromiss gefunden. Sie, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren Abgeordnete, haben dieses Paket weiterentwickelt. Am Ende steht jetzt ein Ergebnis, das die vielen politischen Anliegen angemessen berücksichtigt.  Jetzt haben zwei Mitgliedstaaten Zweifel angemeldet. Der beste Weg wäre, diese Zweifel auszuräumen. Im Juli haben sich alle 27 Staats- und Regierungschefs auch auf einen Konditionalitätsmechanismus verständigt. Es geht hier um Verstöße gegen das Rechtsstaatsprinzip, die das europäische Budget gefährden, und nur um diese. Das ist angemessen, das ist verhältnismäßig, und das ist auch notwendig. Es ist sehr schwer vorstellbar, dass irgendjemand in Europa irgendetwas dagegen haben könnte. Meine Damen und Herren, wer dennoch Zweifel hat, für den gibt es einen klaren Weg. Er kann vor den Europäischen Gerichtshof ziehen und die neuen Regeln auf Herz und Nieren prüfen lassen. Das ist der Ort, an dem wir üblicherweise Meinungsverschiedenheiten über Rechtstexte auslegen, und nicht zu Lasten von Millionen Europäerinnen und Europäern, die dringend auf unsere Hilfe warten. Wir sind ihnen eine rasche Antwort schuldig. Und zwar denjenigen, die ihre Restaurants und Geschäfte zu unserem Wohl vorübergehend schließen mussten, denjenigen, die in ihrer Existenz bedroht sind, den Menschen, die um ihre Jobs bangen – auch in Polen und in Ungarn. Honourable Members, this is especially the case as the pandemic situation remains serious. With nearly 3 000 deaths a day, COVID-19 was the number one cause of death in the EU last week. Hospitals remain under stress, and in some regions intensive care units are overwhelmed. I know that shop owners, bartenders and waiters in restaurants want an end to restrictions, but we must learn from the summer and not repeat the same mistakes. Relaxing restrictions too fast and too much risks there being a third wave after Christmas. Weeks ago, I said that this Christmas will be different. And yes, it will be quieter. This is also a question of solidarity between Member States.  But there is also good news. The Commission has now secured contracts on vaccines with six pharmaceutical companies. The first European citizens might already be vaccinated before the end of December. There is finally light at the end of the tunnel. And yes, as I’ve said, vaccines are important, but what counts are vaccinations. Member States must get ready now. We’re talking about millions of syringes, we’re talking about the cold chain, we’re talking about organising vaccination centres, we’re talking about trained personnel that is there – you name it, all this has to be prepared. In short, Member States have to prepare the logistics for the deployment of hundreds of millions of doses of vaccines, because this is our ticket out of the pandemic.  Honourable Members, with or without COVID, there is another crisis that rumbles on: global warming, the crisis of our planet. And, honourable Members, a growing number of countries have pledged carbon neutrality by 2050. Good news. I firmly believe we must all put a price on carbon. These words could have been mine, but they’re not. These are the remarks of António Guterres, Secretary-General of the United Nations, at the G20 summit last weekend. For the first time in four years, the G20 agreed on clear commitments for the fight against climate change, and Europe has been proudly leading the way. By now, more than half of the G20 members have committed to climate or carbon neutrality around 2050. This demonstrates that being courageous pays off, and it shows that we have chosen the right course when we decided to cut back CO2 emissions until 2030 by at least 55%. This should also encourage the Heads of State and Government to confirm this goal at the next European Council. Et avec cela, nous voulons renforcer la coopération et permettez-moi de parler à la fin de la sécurité des personnes en Europe. Je suis sûre que je parle au nom de toute l’Union quand je dis que l’Europe est solidaire des Français et des Autrichiens. L’Europe est unie face aux attaques terroristes au cœur de nos villes et l’Europe est prête à agir. Le 9 décembre, la Commission présentera un nouvel agenda européen pour la lutte contre le terrorisme, nous voulons renforcer la coopération entre les services de sécurité, nous voulons donner aux gardes-frontières la technologie moderne dont ils ont besoin, intensifier nos efforts pour éviter la radicalisation et mieux protéger les lieux publics. But there is only so much we can do when Member States do not put into practice what they agree upon. For example, the strong rules against money laundering and terrorist financing, or against the use of firearms. Implementation is key and I’m sure the European Council will be an opportunity to turn to action quickly. Honourable Members, from Brexit to the fight against the pandemic, from the budget to the fight against terrorists, it is when we manage to join forces that we Europeans can achieve the most. It is when we negotiate hard and then stick to the compromise found that we move forward best. This is how we will finally leave the corona world and continue to build our future. Lang lebe Europa! Long live Europe! Vive l’Europe! (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the Commission. If we look at the Council, we should be reminded of the situation in europe as a whole. There is a lot of fear, a lot of concern in this European Union. People are looking forward to Christmas and don't know how to celebrate Christmas. Economic forecasts have improved somewhat, but 2020 is still a historic 7% to 8% slump in our European economy. In our neighbourhood we have enormous uncertainty with Turkey, with Brexit. It is therefore not the time for party politics, nor is it the time for national selfishness, but it is the time to work together now and to give orientation to the people of this continent, to give hope, to give perspective, to show a strong Europe. The first central point is the question of Corona. I am a proud European because we have managed to find a common path in vaccination, on the vaccination strategy. I would like to warmly congratulate the Commission, including you, Madam President of the Commission, on the fact that this common approach has been practised. It was European researchers who were at the forefront of this, who have made this great progress with European research money. With the treaties that have been concluded, we will now show that there are not poor and rich Europeans, there are no large and small countries, but that all Europeans will have access to this vaccine at the same time and can be vaccinated accordingly. We should ensure that distribution begins as simultaneously as possible in all the member states of the European Union, in order to make this comprehensible.  This development of vaccines also shows us what Europeans can achieve if we invest. I am thinking, for example, of cancer, another major health issue. If we act together, we can achieve a great deal. The second, of course, is the economy: EUR 1.8 trillion, Corona and MFF are on the table together. It shows that we stand in solidarity. It would be a sign of stability if we could achieve results quickly, and that is why the veto by Poland and Hungary is simply irresponsible. We in the European Parliament have healed the mistake of the July Council. At that time, the Heads of State or Government were not in a position to take appropriate decisions on the rule of law. I would like to thank our team very much. Without the European Parliament, this mechanism would not exist, and together we have now achieved a great deal. I would still like to argue that I would like to discuss with Hungary and Poland, because, for example, the argument that Europe would dictate how to organise abortion in Poland is simply a lie. It is simply a lie! The European Union will not have a say on abortion issues, because it is national competence. Therefore: Please deal with the arguments fairly! The second is that if someone claims that this proposal is not covered by the Lisbon Treaty, as Viktor Orban does, then All I can say is that I see it differently, and please go to the ECJ and let it be clarified there. This is how the European Union works, but not with a veto. That is why we must send out a clear signal: the European Parliament will not back down a millimetre. This mechanism is right, it is necessary, it is overdue, and the sword that we then have is then in the hands of the Commission, which I want to motivate to use it, to enforce the rule of law in the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, another issue is the neighbourhood around us, which creates uncertainty. In particular, I would like to say a few words about Turkey, because that too will play a role in the European Council. The list is now very long: the breach of international law in Syria, Varosia, now the breach of UN resolutions on gas disputes. We have offered Greece to have this clarified in The Hague – that is where Erdogan refuses. And in Libya, the question is whether weapons will be supplied, whether Turkey will supply weapons there, and whether international law, UN resolutions, will also be broken there. And I have not yet talked about what is going on in Turkey with the breach of fundamental values, the independence of the judiciary and the media. Enough is enough! Cyprus and Greece must ensure that the European partners stand by their side, that we act together. And now that Turkey was discussed in the October Council, when sanctions were postponed, we must now make it clear that the words have changed enough, and that action must now follow in the term. European Council. The European Union always offers partnership with Turkey. We want cooperation, but if someone constantly rejects this partnership and constantly provokes us, then there must also be consequences. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The situation we are in is difficult, but I believe that we have a good chance with the steps that are being taken to show people in the winter of 2020 that it is better if we act together, because then we will be stronger.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I will be allowed to begin my speech today, November 25, with a memory of the victims, the women who have been murdered at the hands of their abusers. Our memory and support for their sons, their daughters, their families and the clear commitment that the institutions will not stop working until we get to end the largest scourge that this world is currently living, and that women are killed by the mere fact of being women. Ladies and gentlemen, the position of this Parliament has always been clear. Since 2018 we have been claiming the need for a legislative instrument linking the budget with the defence of the rule of law, and that is why we will not change a single comma from the agreement we have reached in the work of tripartite dialogues with the Council in this regard. This is requested by ⸻the 77% of European citizenship is in accordance with this instrument of the rule of law⸻; we are asked to do so by trade unions in Hungary and Poland; we are asked to do so by the mayors of Warsaw and Budapest; a large part of European citizenship asks us to do so. And it's not time to choose between money and the rule of law. If we want to defend the European project, we need both and we need them urgently. The European Union is not a bazaar. The European Union is a community of law. And in this sense, I also ask for courage. I ask the People's Party for courage to continue to defend the rule of law as it has so far, but understanding that it is quite contradictory when there are Members in its ranks of governing parties who are blocking this proposal. Social democracy, it's clear. We're not going to disappoint the public. Nor Hungary and Poland, which trusts the European Union. Nor will we accept solutions that harm the beneficiaries of the funds. In addition, we are in other kinds of negotiations that are also fundamental to us. Negotiations with the recovery fund continue, and let's hope they come to fruition by the end of the year. And we also expect agreement on our future relationship with the UK. We are on time, but we need to exercise our work and our responsibility as a European Parliament. We cannot give up a reliable and stable governance system, competition rules that protect our internal market and an agreement that guarantees the interests of our fisheries sector. You see, ladies and gentlemen, there are weeks left of work and we have to continue to exercise our responsibility. Months ago we saw competition between Member States in managing the COVID situation. We now see how progress is being made in this health union that our political group claimed from the outset. We have also seen what the need is like to move forward with this transparent plan for the purchase and distribution of vaccines, which is the horizon of hope we have right now. This is how Europe is built, and that is why I ask the council leaders to get to work and not waste a single minute. And I'm done. Don't waste a single minute on reforming the Pact on Migration and Asylum, either. We need a binding mechanism for the relocation of immigrants and refugees. Fundamental rights must be respected. In recent days my country is one of those most under migratory pressure in the Canary Islands, but we have been calling for a real policy of solidarity for many years now, which would have prevented the dramas of Moria, from Lampedusa. We're late, but we're still on time, because in the Mediterranean not only is the lives of human beings sinking. The dignity of the European project is also sinking if we continue with our arms crossed.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, I will start with topics that are still under discussion: the draft multi-year budget and the recovery plan, own resources, and the mechanism to protect the rule of law. Europe is being held hostage by two countries that come from a region hard-hit by the communist experience, which has spent a few decades behind the Iron Curtain and where I come from. A region where the pandemic has hit many families hard, where hospitals, entrepreneurs, researchers, farmers, communities and young people are in urgent need of European investment. A region where we still remember very well what the word oppression means, as do the words freedom and democracy. And, in the face of this history, accusing Europe of being Soviet is really ridiculous, even more so when you are behaving yourself as a despot and queuing up to get the first carton of vaccines from Putin. Yes, Europe is being held hostage, but there is no fatality or east-west divide. There are Eastern and Western, North and Southern Europeans who are determined to live in a state of law, respectful of freedom. The European budget is protected from fraud, but we must now also protect it from corruption, in a neutral and impartial manner. But the polls are clear: for European citizens, some authoritarian politicians would no longer listen to their people. They would like us to believe that the abuses come from Brussels. The problem of our Union is not authoritarianism, but the difficulty in deciding and making clear decisions. And in the face of the pandemic, we have begun to show that this is possible. Colleagues, let us also show that Brussels, as they say, knows how to take strong decisions to defend our freedom and democracy and also continue to protect our interests and values in negotiations with the United Kingdom. We must insist that the points that are essential to us are included in the agreement, but also stress the importance, for European democracy, that Parliament has sufficient time before deciding on an unprecedented partnership agreement. But let's do it too by building with our international partners. Let us use all the strength and influence of Europe, as you said, Madam President, and prepare for COP26 in Glasgow today by working with the United States to fight global climate change. Parliament and the Renew Group have already sent a strong message on these issues. We support the Green Pact for Europe and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030. The Council will also have to prove a similar determination and unity on the subject of climate change. I hope you will convey that message to him. Only by setting realistic but ambitious goals will we succeed in transforming our industries through green and digital technologies and restarting the European economy for the world of tomorrow.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in December it will be almost five months since the famous July Council, where the Heads of State or Government reached an agreement that was widely publicised by the media and the European institutions as a great success of the Community method and as a great success for the European Union. Yet, five months after that date, we are almost back to the starting point. Time has been lost, there are responsibilities and, as you know and as they teach us, time is money, time has financial value, doing things sooner is better than doing things afterwards. Today we are pointing the finger at two countries that veto, legitimately, because we cannot talk about rules that apply only on the one hand and not consider that this power of veto is a legitimate power. Therefore, those who demand respect for the rule of law because it is a fundamental point, a fundamental pillar of the Treaties, must also respect the powers and methods of exercising them, which are guaranteed to countries by the Treaties and our rules. As always, when there is a situation of conflict, the responsibilities are on two sides, they cannot be claimed only on one side. Allow me to play the pun: I am surprised at those who are surprised at this veto today. We knew, and it was clear back in July, that if we had moved forward on a mechanism known as the 'rule of law' - but anyone who has read that regulation knows and cannot but deny that this regulation is not about the rule of law - Poland and Hungary would veto it, and the majority of these institutions have decided, knowingly, to move forward and to provoke this veto. So there are clear responsibilities for delays on both sides and in this Parliament, in the majority of this Parliament which has decided to move forward on a political and punitive mechanism which, I repeat, has nothing to do with respect for the rule of law, provoking the veto of these two countries. I am also surprised by the so-called Pro-Europeans, who are today calling for an intergovernmental agreement to overcome this impasse. I am surprised because they are the ones who wanted to go ahead with the Recovery Fund, on the recovery plan, with the Community method, which has shown all its limitations today, which has shown today what Europe really is. It is not a united continent, it is a continent made up of nations which, legitimately, also have different and conflicting interests. So who's to blame? Who are the responsibility? In my opinion, the greatest responsibility today lies with those who continue to use the rules in a political way to punish those who are not aligned with a certain unique thought. We must take this into account, because the method we use does not work and we cannot expect there to be a dictatorship of the majority, as some would like. The rules are fine when we go in the desired direction, the rules must be changed if a minority goes against the will of the majority. Then we must decide what kind of democracy we want and we must finally decide to understand what the mistakes and limitations of this European Union are. The mistakes of wanting rules that should help us in times of need and when we are in need we must suspend these rules. We have suspended the fiscal rules, the Stability and Growth Pact; we have temporarily suspended the state aid rules; the ECB is forcing its mandate. So this is where we need to think, to ask ourselves whether this European Union really is, really the methods we use, compatible with what the European Union is today, namely an intergovernmental agreement between Member States, which are legitimately different. Then perhaps it is better to focus on a few things and do them well, rather than to pursue a project that is anti-historical today and that citizens and governments do not want.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, agreeing on the recovery fund was a truly big achievement of the Heads of State and Government back in July. It did need a lot of pushing from the European Parliament and not everything is ideal in that package, but this is still an unprecedented common effort to help citizens in an unprecedented crisis. It was - and is - a big step forward in European history.  But now this big success is at risk because two governments only care about their own power and about staying in power because that’s, in the end, what the veto by the Hungarian and Polish Governments is all about. Like Trump, who is killing Corona support in the US, Orbán is doing the same in Europe. Blocking the recovery fund will be felt and shouldered by Hungarian and Polish citizens just as much as by any other Europeans. What a cynical disregard of the needs of one’s own citizens. And let’s not forget that there is no binary choice to be made. The recovery fund is essential to overcome this crisis, the MFF is essential to set the EU on the path to a Green Deal transformation, and equally, the rule of law framework is essential to ensure these EU funds serve the needs and best interests of European citizens.  Dear Hungarian and Polish friends, your governments are gambling with your future. The European Union is founded on values such as human rights, democracy and the rule of law and this Parliament will never stop defending those values. For too long, many governments may not have been happy with straying away from democracy in some Member States, but they have never truly spoken out. That time is over. At this summit, it is time for everyone to take a stance. Decisions are also needed at this summit to ensure that the EU takes serious climate action. At the last summit, any decision on the 2030 climate targets was postponed. Now governments must act. The European Parliament has delivered an ambitious target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60% by the year 2030, and the governments must now follow suit to allow for swift and decisive climate action. I also want to stress that we need to have an honest emission reduction target, not one with creative calculations and loopholes that might create pretty numbers on paper, but would fail in real life. The task is to preserve a liveable planet in all of its biodiversity and the measures must live up to this target. With an extraordinary year coming to an end, we’re also running out of time to find any agreement with the UK. While we’re immensely sad that the UK will be leaving us, it is also clear that we cannot just simply agree to anything that comes up at the last minute. This Parliament needs time for scrutiny and for debating any possible agreement. As the Verts/ALE Group, we will not just sign off any deal. We will look very closely at whether this is an agreement that is of mutual benefit, that safeguards social and environmental standards and that does not endanger peace in Northern Ireland. We will not hesitate to defend those rights and standards for the benefit of European citizens, but also, we believe, for the benefit of British citizens, now and in the future if the UK decides to rejoin.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Many of you have talked about solidarity, you have talked about the rule of law, you have referred to the principles that should be applied in the European Union, because they have underpin the creation of our community. But it is the European Parliament, you are proposing to break these rules. There is no link between European funds or the European budget in the Treaties, the disbursement of these funds to the rule of law. This is an attempt by the majority in this Parliament at the moment to impose rules that are not enshrined in the Treaties, which are not in force, which the European Union has never discussed and adopted, so if you are talking about the rule of law, you have to answer yourself the question whether you are breaking this rule of law at the moment. Poland, my country, has often been cited here, and I must tell you that the rule of law is excellent in Poland. In democratic elections, Poles decided to choose a party, my party, Law and Justice, which has formed a government and has consistently implemented the programme to which the Polish people have committed us. Polish, the government cares about the Polish and cares about the interests of Poles, because that is its role and has been obliged to do so in democratic elections. And here we are trying at the moment, here in this House, to convince everyone that the July agreement was about something different than what was actually agreed, because the rule of law, or this discussion that was going on at the time, was going in a completely different direction, and you know that very well.  The will of the majority of minorities cannot be arbitrarily imposed simply because you represent the majority of the European Parliament here believe that what is good for you is good for the European Union - it is not.  The European Union is twenty-seven countries, it is twenty-seven sensibilities, it is twenty-seven nations, it is twenty-seven economies, and it is our duty, because the Treaties oblige us to do so, and what the idea on which the European Union was built obliges us to do so is to solidarity, to take into account the interests of all Member States and all Europeans and to protect the interests of all the people of the European Union and to take care of their interests.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU budget does not meet the expectations of Europeans or what is needed in the face of the Corona crisis. The Member States have agreed on an historic low in contributions and are reaching deep into the discount box. The roadmap for own resources is so vague that it is doubtful whether there will ever be a comprehensive financial transaction tax or a strong digital tax. And the Rule of Law Mechanism, the rule of law mechanism, has also been weakened and falls far short of what Parliament originally called for. But the fact that it is precisely because of this weak rule of law mechanism that the autocrats in the EU are now taking the Community hostage and vetoing the Corona Reconstruction is completely unacceptable politically. The Orbans and Kaczysskis can only do this because their activities have been watched in silence in recent years and they have been protected from all of them by the conservatives, including in this House, out of power-tactical calculation. The PPE-DE is still refusing – and I am now citing a somewhat more far-sighted conservative – to exclude 'the little dictator Orban'. To demand the rule of law on the one hand and, at the same time, to peddle their enemies is not only implausible, dear conservative colleagues, it is seriously damaging to democracy. On Brexit, it remains a question of whether the left can agree to a deal. We need a robust level playing field to prevent ruinous dumping competition in the social, environmental and consumer protection standards. Boris Johnson must finally show a willingness to compromise, or there is no deal. The peace process in Northern Ireland must not be jeopardised, and that is why the UK Single Market Act, which is in breach of the Withdrawal Agreement and the Good Friday Agreement, must be withdrawn. My group is prepared to allow a special session of Parliament to avoid a hard economic Brexit at the end of the year. However, Mrs von der Leyen, we are firmly opposed to the provisional entry into force of a possible agreement without any prior thorough democratic scrutiny by Parliament.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Mr President, the enforcement of our common values and norms is not up for debate. Therefore, we must equip the European Union with the means to constantly make its members respect these values and comply with these norms, otherwise Europe will never be strong. This is a quote from the EP manifesto of Fidesz from the year 2009 and I agree with every word of it. However, since it entered government in 2010, Orbán has created division in Hungary and, as a Trojan horse, is dividing Europe from within, destroying its values. Only unity can defeat division. I personally have come a long way to understand the importance of working in unity. This is why, as a conservative, I work together with social democrats and liberals of my country to bring change to Hungary. I am not asking fellow MEPs from across the continent to do our job in Hungary. We will take care of that. But what I do ask you is to be consistent in following your core values to deal with this plague. We can cure it together.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The situation in Europe in February/March, when the first wave of the Corona pandemic came, was appalling. We have seen that borders have been closed, we have seen that the Member States have taken national solo actions forward, and many people in Europe have had the impression that the partners in the other European Member States are letting them down. But you, Madam President of the Commission, we in Parliament and also the Member States have taken advantage of the summer. We have managed to reopen the borders and to keep them open in the second wave. We have negotiated a sustainable budget for the next seven years and put together a multibillion-dollar rescue package. If the Member States now really use this money for research, for investment in the future and for new jobs, then Europe, and especially the people who live here, has a very good future, and I would like the Member States to really do their homework now when it is using funds. We have seen that European researchers with European money are also at the forefront when it comes to vaccines and modern technologies. The Commission, under your leadership, Mrs von der Leyen, has managed to ensure that we conclude contracts for all Europeans together with the vaccine manufacturers. The manufacturers did not even come up with the idea and were not even tempted to pit the people of the Member States against each other, but you and your Commission negotiated, bought and concluded together for all of them. This Europe, we want, is what you stand for, and for that we would like to express our sincere thanks. As a second issue, I would like us in the Council to be truly ambitious in proposing a new package for new transatlantic cooperation to the United States. We must seize the opportunity that we are now getting. After the low point of the transatlantic relationship over the last four years, I really hope that all the people of Europe have understood that we need to reposition ourselves together with the United States in order to better meet the new global political challenges.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the most dramatic historic moment for our generation. A health emergency that has shocked our lives and taken away our loved ones, that is bringing to its knees the foundations of our economy and of which we still do not see the end. Faced with all this, Europe responded with the anticipation of an investment plan unimaginable until recently, thanks to the work of the European Parliament and the Commission, but also thanks to the fundamental agreement of that European Council last July, to which we all, all, looked as a turning point. The citizens of Europe have once again recovered to trust us, after years in which Europe was perceived as far removed from their needs. The Council, right now, at the peak of the second wave, cannot go and tell those who have come back to look at us with hope that perhaps we have joked, that we will not reach out to those who have lost their jobs, to the companies that are closing their doors, because there is a rule that two Heads of Government do not like. This rule simply says that Europe is not an ATM but a community of destiny, that we in Europe are sharing the same values and, above all, that the public authorities must act within the limits set by law, in accordance with democratic principles and fundamental rights. The next Council on 10 December has a fundamental task: faced with the veto on the European budget, the result of important negotiating work, which blocks the ratification process of the national parliaments on the historic increase in the European Union's ceilings and own resources, and therefore the departure of the entire Next Generation EU plan, we must take a step forward. Parliament has done its part and does not accept backs down. We therefore ask the Council not to disperse the wealth of credibility that the institutions have regained. They must not be held responsible for failure. What is at stake is the fate of Europe and the citizens of Europe, including those of Hungarians and Poles.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Mr President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last May, the newspaper Libération was already headlined: Europe at its bottom with its 750 billion euros displayed in large numbers. And you are, Madam President, on this front page that has gone around France, I can guarantee you that. Last July, this stimulus package with the multi-year budget was implemented between the heads of state, not without difficulty. And finally, two weeks ago, the final agreement with MEPs fell. Not without difficulty, again, but we did. And now, despite all the goodwill of the world deployed by all of us here, it is blocking. It is blocking because one state in particular has decided to take the hope of 450 million Europeans hostage. And what do the states do? Last week: European summit. We talked about it for 17 minutes. We are told that we will have a clarification, perhaps at the summit on December 10. But finally, it's not believable! Europe cannot continue to be governed intermittently by crossing its fingers that a great leader finally decides to give up his veto! Our Europe, ladies and gentlemen, and the Europeans deserve better. They deserve the agreement that has been negotiated with more resources for its missions, with their own resources and of course with preserved values. Madam President, Parliament will not back down. No, not this time, and I regret that there is no minister in this Chamber today who can hear it. This revival must allow our continent to recover, it must allow Europeans to stand. So, no, blackmail is not acceptable in our democracies. No, unanimity is no longer bearable in Europe, do not displease you, Mr Zanni. In the States, I say, there is an emergency. Find a solution that respects our agreement. As long as it is Europe and the Europeans who come out of it from the top, we will support you.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Mr President, the dogmatism of a majority in the European Parliament has paid off: the European budget and the recovery plan are blocked. You wanted to condition them to respect the so-called rule of law? Well, you have the result. Too happy to have an opportunity to extend its prerogatives, the Commission has taken over this idea in order to be able to punish recalcitrant nations. Definitely, it has become a real obsession. Brussels bears full responsibility for this political crisis, but would obviously like to blame Warsaw and Budapest. Well, I would like to commend the constancy and courage of Poland and Hungary, which reject this scandalous clause which is well known to give rise to permanent blackmail and that it is obviously not a new general rule, but a deliberate and targeted persecution against two Member States. Let me be clear: conditioning access to the funds, to which these countries are entitled, to the dictates and the whims of Brussels, is simply unacceptable. Yes, the peoples of Europe have the right to refuse the migration submersion which aims, I quote, to replace the ageing populations, as Commissioner Johansson again wished last week. Yes, the peoples of Europe have the right to reject the communitarian demands and progressivism that deconstructs everything or the deleterious influence of globalist liberals, who see only financial interests against the real economy. Yes, the peoples of Europe have the right to refuse foreign interference, that of political Islam or the networks of George Soros. Yes, the peoples of Europe, through their elected and often re-elected governments, have the right to acquire the political and judicial institutions that they believe are best at safeguarding their interests. That is what I call the rule of law. Hungary and Poland are right to defend their sovereignty, to uphold the right of peoples not only to decide for themselves, but also to remain themselves. Instead of being the mere hierarchy of legal norms, the rule of law is in your mouth an increasingly broad and vague concept, extending to areas where states are yet sovereign, such as justice, health, education or the family. This rule of law is yours who flouts it. You have no legitimacy to dictate to nations and peoples how they should live. The demands of the European institutions violate the very spirit of the European treaties, you have gone from the motto 'united in diversity' to 'centralised in uniformity'. The issue is nothing less than the establishment of a government of judges against the will of the people. Poland and Hungary must stand firm.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, in the coming days the European Council has a golden opportunity to show that it is working for the European interest and with a vision for the future. They can show it in at least two ways. First, resist a reverse Polish and Hungarian governments’ blackmailing with the budget. By blocking the biggest mobilisation of EU funds ever, these two governments are preventing funds and investments from reaching citizens and economists in urgent need of support. Warsaw and Budapest want full access to EU funding while avoiding any scrutiny on the way they deal with the rule of law. This veto is unacceptable and irresponsible. So it is for the Council to find a way out of this situation without giving up oversight of our fundamental values. And second, approve a more ambitious emissions reduction target for 2030. Raising the carbon emissions cut to 60%, or even better to 65%, will show to the EU citizens and the rest of the world that we are living up to our commitments on climate neutrality, and it’s time to fill the climate law with concrete and more ambitious plans - no public money for fossil fuels by 2025, an ambitious budget to fight climate change, an independent scientific climate council to guide decisions on the latest science. The parliament has made its choices, now it’s time for the EU leaders to be up to the challenges and to really show the lead in overcoming the climate crisis.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Violence is spreading in society. I see it not least in my own country, Sweden. Robbery, ill-treatment, even people subjected to pure torture. We in Sweden have a Socialist-led government that has lost its grip on the increasingly escalating violence. We have a Prime Minister who repeatedly says that the situation is unacceptable. He has now reiterated this throughout his time as Prime Minister without succeeding in getting strong measures in place. We even have, lo and behold, a newly built police station outside Stockholm, where the police officers who have been stationed there must have a police escort on their way to or from their work. The situation is horribel to say the least. We have a Minister of Justice who wants newly trained police officers, which in itself is positive. But according to a survey by the Police Federation, 42 percent of current police officers are looking for new jobs because of their vulnerable situation. That's 4 out of 5 cops. Why, then, do we have this situation? Of course, one problem is the governments we have in our own country, both current and past, which have failed completely in their tasks. But the EU also has its role in it, with its completely unsuccessful and irresponsible migration policy, which has led to far too much immigration, not least in Sweden, Germany and a number of countries beyond that. As a result, it has resulted in a direct exclusion of people who no longer enter society. The EU and national governments, I mean, have a social contract with their clients, and that is the taxpayer. It is to deliver a safe, secure society to live in, and there we have failed from politics. Violence must be repelled by all means. We must do our part from the European Union and governments must do their part. It is time to move from words to action and to repel violence with all the force at our disposal.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, Mrs Merkel, Mrs Michel, Mrs von der Leyen, stop stroking Erdoğan. Stop closing your eyes to the growing challenges in the Aegean, Varosia, Cyprus, the Eastern Mediterranean, Libya. It is finally time for the words of solidarity in Greece and Cyprus to become a reality. We've had enough of words. The summit on 10 December must finally take decisions, adopt a package of sanctions against the Erdoğan regime. For months, Mr Erdoğan has been denying the opportunities you have given him, pretending and provoking. A few days before each summit appears as a lamb and after the summit behaves like a wolf. So prove that the European Union is not naïve. Only if Erdoğan is substantially pressed will he respect international law and sit at the dialogue table.  One more thing: to implement without any delay the agreement on the Recovery Fund, the budget and the rule of law. The European Parliament will not back down from the agreement it has signed. Honor your signature, too. Every day of delay caused by Mr Orbán and Mr Kaczyński means greater recession, greater unemployment, greater insecurity for all European peoples, and Hungary and Poland included.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, seventy years ago, the European Union also thought about the risk of moments like this and the help that all countries could give each other in the event of a serious social, economic and health crisis. That is why I find it absurd and unacceptable that the Polish and Hungarian Governments should be able to keep the whole of Europe in check when we see such a tragedy, with EUR 1 750 billion to be released. I find it shameful that the right of veto is being used instrumentally to harm the whole of Europe, to the 440 million citizens who are waiting for the Recovery Fund in order to continue to live, to work, to dream, to be part of a community that must now show all its strength. As an Italian, I would like to ask Giorgia Meloni, President of the ECR, and all my fellow Members of the ECR: how do you fraternise with those who are blocking money for Italians and for all Europeans today? Now distance yourself from those who are playing on our children's skin for mere squalid political interests. Our citizens are entitled to that money! Take responsibility!

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, this European Council will mark the transition from the pandemic to the post-pandemic European Union. The pandemic is not yet over, but this European Council and the decisions that we will make together in the upcoming weeks will determine what the European Union will look like and how the European Union will act in the years to come. I want a European Union in which we are together, united in solidarity and based on our values. These are the principles which I want for the relation with one of our closest neighbours, the United Kingdom. These are the principles which I want when we spend money. We are now about to spend more money than the European Union has ever spent in its history, EUR 1.8 trillion, and the more we spend, the more we need to make sure that money reaches the people in need. The EU budget is money from the people for the people and we, and all of those who manage EU money, have a special responsibility to make sure that EU values are respected. Spending money in the interest of the people means spending it well, but it also means to decide fast. Parliament and Council have made several agreements and in a democracy, once something is agreed you have to adopt, vote and then implement it.  This is why I call upon the European Council and upon the Council of Ministers, to vote and adopt what we have agreed – budget, own resources, recovery package and the rule of law. It’s in the interest of all of us, given that the Union is based on the freedom of people to move, the freedom of companies to move, that the rule of law is respected in every single corner of the European Union. As soon as the budget will be sent to us for a vote, we will vote on it. We expect the Council to do the same.  In conclusion, a word about one of the countries in our immediate neighbourhood. Madam President, dear colleagues, in the Republic of Moldova, a country that we have a direct border with, a pro-European, pro-reform candidate attached to European values and to the rule of law, has won an election against the incumbent, pro-Russian, pro-Kremlin president. This is good news for us, for Europe. This is why I call upon us to work closely with this immediate neighbouring country of the European Union. It’s in their interests, but it’s also in the fundamental interest of us.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, the December European Council has a long to-do list before the end of the year and carry-overs are not an option. 2021 will be the year in which we can finally return to normality, but only vaccines will not be enough for the EU to regain what we lost, and while our thoughts go to the victims, their families and the efforts of our health care workers, we need the Recovery Fund, and an EU budget well in in place fast. The Council must address firmly the irresponsible actions of Prime Minister Orbán and his friends from Slovenia and Poland without any concessions or delay. We also expect the Council to conduct a thorough review of EU-Turkey relations and identify concrete responses, and also authoritarianism at home and ever-increasing aggression in our immediate neighbourhood cannot go unchecked. It is also time for Bulgaria’s EPP leadership, which claims to be one of the greatest advocates of enlargement, to return to its senses and give North Macedonia its well deserved green light for negotiations. And finally Brexit. It is clear that we urgently need white smoke, but let me reiterate once again that the Parliament will not move its red lines to ratify just any last-minute deal. Whether we find an agreement is now up to UK Prime Minister Johnson, and as Parliament, we will continue to stand ready and constructive, but we will not be shy on our democratic role and prerogatives.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, our Union is not a union of merchants. Our Union is based on fundamental values that we share. Mr Bay, Mrs Szydoo, our colleagues in the far right of this House tell us that they are not in the treaties. I read Article 2, which reads: 'The Union is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights'. These are our values, and these are the values we are fighting for. Mr Kaczyski and Mr Orbán have decided that this value thing does not go with them. They have been lashing out at freedom of the press and the independence of justice for years and attacking the rights of minorities. I would tell our colleagues that they say this is an invasion of their freedoms which, when they attack judicial independence, when they use majorities to wipe out minorities by appointing judges, are violating The Treaties of the European Union. They're making fun of us. They think we're merchants and we'll never stop their feet. They think Europe is an ATM that's there to give them money without conditions. Well, this is over. That's how far we've come. This Parliament has been trying for years to put in place a rule of law mechanism. We have finally reached agreement with the governments to put this mechanism in place to prevent European money from being used to build authoritarian and corrupt regimes. Hungary and Poland's response is to block a recovery fund that is essential for our citizens to succeed behind this terrible pandemic. I will tell you clearly: European money will not be used to finance corruption, attacks on press freedom or attacks on judicial independence. If the recovery mechanism is essential and the Hungarian and Polish veto is unacceptable, what do we have left? I believe that the solution has been put on the table by my colleague Guy Verhofstadt, and I invite the Council ⸻by the way, now sadly absent⸻ to consider it. The other twenty-five countries must start the dialogue as soon as possible to launch a strengthened cooperation mechanism that will end blackmail and enable the recovery of this pandemic to begin. We can't be late anymore.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The EU is obviously in heavy seas. We have an unresolved Brexit - that can still go pretty wrong. We then have a bloated budget: the budget has suddenly become more than 70% more than before – that cannot be done well. We have adopted an own resources regulation which may not bring some money into the coffers until next year, but which is otherwise very vague and very vague, and we still have Turkey at the borders, with which we cannot get along. But what do we do? We make rules and now try to pack everything we can sort out in a big package in a big wash-up. I told you that this must go wrong and it has gone wrong. We cannot relink the rule of law mechanism with financial mechanisms. You are well aware that we have unanimity here in the Treaties. Of course, Hungary can, of course, Poland can veto it, because with this rule they have entered the EU. If we simply change these rules along the way, that is legitimate if Poland and Hungary then oppose it. What should we do? I think we should be aware that we cannot process this package together as a whole. We need to put it back on the line - only then will you get an MFF, because if you don't make it by the end of December, then the rules of the 2020 budget will apply. You know that, Article 312(4). I would therefore like to remind you once again: please be content with the sparrow in your hand and do not let the pigeon fly away on the roof!

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The EU is not a self-service shop. Democracy, the rule of law, common values and objectives are the basis for European cooperation and for our budgetary policy. Mr Orban, Mr Morawiecki, what are you afraid of? Stop blackmailing the European Union! It won't work. A majority in the European Parliament and the Council will adopt an effective rule of law mechanism. They will not prevent it. The only thing you achieve is that together we are slipping deeper and deeper into the crisis. Your businesses are also going bust, more people are becoming unemployed, and the health situation in your countries is also dramatic. It is your choice whether you want to be part of the solution or whether we have to find solutions without you. Mr Michel, Chancellor Merkel, we MEPs have done our job, now it is your turn. Make it clear that our European democracy is non-negotiable! Find a solution, but do not sacrifice the rule of law mechanism! Anyone who now buckles in front of Orban will weaken the EU for decades to come. Prefer the Council summit! If a solution is not found until 11 December, there will be no time to get the budget off on time. As a budgetary politician, I would also like to make it quite clear that an emergency budget, with only agricultural subsidies and administrative expenditure, must not be an option. That would weaken us all. We wish you every success for the European project and for the EU budget to be able to get off to a good start on time.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, Poland and Hungary are blocking the so-called recovery fund. That's what I understand. The EU uses rule of law as a weapon against both countries as a kind of blackmail. They only get money if they comply with what the EU requires them to do.  There is something wrong in every country, ladies and gentlemen, including in Poland and Hungary. But in almost all Member States and also the EU itself, judges are appointed politically. France saw violence against the yellow hesjes. Never heard anything about the rule of law here. There wasn't even a debate. In the Netherlands there is a surcharge affair. Many civilians were persecuted disenfranchisingly. Speaking of rule of law ... But do take Hungary and Poland! These countries, meanwhile, see rule of law as a kind of Brezhnev doctrine of the European Union, as a crowbar for regime change, because that is the real agenda. The incumbent Conservative governments must go. But that is the decision for voters, not the EU.  The EU is becoming a debt union with the Debt Generation EU. The Dutch youth will be grateful to Poland and Hungary if they prevent this.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in an unprecedented crisis, we need an unprecedented response and we are faced with a deadlock that does nothing to help the European project or those suffering from the crisis. We are at a stalemate which is the result of a successive lack of courage for a solidarity response in the European Union.  At the moment, we are witnessing a European Union, a European project wedged between the blackmail of so-called 'frugais' and the blackmail of the aggressors of the rule of law and democracy.  Next-in-house has put us here and my question is: how long? Until when? What will be left of the European project? If we do not have a firm response of solidarity, if we continue to accept the blackmail of those who do not want the European solidarity project, if we accept the blackmail of those who want the rule of law to be just a flower on the lad, what will remain of the European project? We need to respond to this crisis and we need that response to be in line with what are the concrete needs of the people who are suffering. We started this project and the President of the Commission presented this proposal as conditionally free. We have reached the end of this project with full conditionality, without even the environmental goals to be met and, on top of that, with this shameful blackmail. We need resources, we need to end blackmail, because we need to continue to make the European project survive.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the deadlines given by the European Union for Turkey to supposedly change its stance are part of methodical moves within the framework of the strong strategic relations between the two sides, which are not cancelled by the sanctions debate. This situation strengthens Turkish claims to the detriment of the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus by raising the table of co-exploitation promoted by the United States, NATO and the European Union in the region. Thus, from the challenges of Oruç Reis, we have reached the unacceptable opening of Famagusta.  No confidence in the European Union and its haggling with its strategic partner, Turkey, whose aggression is also legitimised by the State Department in a report. Forces that have launched wars against peoples in Syria, Libya, Iraq cannot be transformed into defenders of the peace and security of the peoples. The involvement of the Greek government in such projects only poses risks. The way out lies in relations of mutual benefit, the exploitation of natural resources on the basis of popular needs, the release of Greece from imperialist alliances.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, intensive negotiations between the United Kingdom and the European Union have been taking place during the last weeks. We have heard this morning that both teams are working tirelessly, day and night, as well as over the weekends, to finally reach an agreement.  In many fields indeed, texts have now been finalised. However, as the Commission President pointed out, the three major stumbling blocks related to the level playing field, to governance and fisheries remain, due to the British position. There are only 36 days left until the United Kingdom will have left the customs union and the single market, yet there is still no agreement and there’s still no text available.  I want to point out that we cannot simply wait until the very last minute to agree on a text, since we as a Parliament have to scrutinise the final text, in the same way as we have been scrutinising the entire negotiation process.  The United Kingdom will remain a close partner and ally of the European Union. For this reason we should use all our efforts to set the ground for fruitful cooperation beyond the end of the transition period. This will, colleagues, indeed require a certain degree of flexibility, creativity and pragmatism concerning our parliamentary procedures.  But to be very clear, we as the European Parliament will have the last word. To give our consent we need to receive the text as soon as possible. Nobody should underestimate the risks that a late submission entails for the orderly start of our new EU—UK relations. Michel Barnier and his team are making the most of every opportunity to reach a deal in the interests of the European Union. On behalf of us all in the European Parliament, let me wish Michel Barnier good luck for the coming days, which certainly will be decisive. (Applause)

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The current pandemic continues to be a huge challenge and it represents great sacrifices for all of us. That is why it is important that we, in the Member States, continue to act together, and the European Union is an important part of limiting the spread of infection. We have to do two things at once. We must strengthen health preparedness in the crisis. But we must also begin work to build a new future, a new sustainable economy for the future. We're not going to build the old economy. We're going to build the new green economy. The Green Deal and the Paris Agreement will be our road map for building europe's economy sustainable and for us to be able to give hope for the future. In the run-up to the summit, I would therefore like to call on the Eu ropean Heads of State or Government to now make a serious contribution to this important work so that the budget, the Recovery Fund, is agreed, and tackles the Rule of Law for real. It is the far-right forces that are blocking this. I want europe to become the world's first climate-neutral continent, and that work must go hand in hand with social rights and gender equality.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Madam President, first of all, I don’t want to intervene on Brexit. I think that we are in injury time, like we say in football, in these negotiations, but I’m still optimistic, Mr McAllister, because I do not think that this is like football. Footballers are tired in injury time, but politicians are not. I think that politicians are at their best in injury time. I am still optimistic, because it’s in the interests of both to have this agreement.  On the rule of law, I want to simply echo what Luis Garicano and my colleague, Valerie Hayer, have said here in the debate. Ms Szydło, and Mr Zanni – sorry they are no longer here – can read the Treaty. The rule of law is not a question of subsidiarity, because that’s what they in fact are saying, that it’s a question of sovereignty. Freedom of expression, freedom of gathering, democracy, that is not a question of subsidiarity. Respect for the LGBT community in your country, that’s not a question of subsidiarity. That’s a value of the European Union, and that’s the reason we have to stick to the compromise we have found, even when I personally don’t think – and I’m grateful for the tenacity of Ms Merkel in still trying to find an agreement with Poland and Hungary – that there is a lot of room for compromise, because already in the text today you need to prove a link between the breach of the rule of law and the accounts of the European Union before the European Commission can act. So, if there is room for making it better, it’s to strengthen the system, not to weaken the system. If it is not possible – I repeat – there is only one way forward, which is enhanced cooperation inside the Treaty, based on Article 226 of the Treaty, like we did with the euro, like we did with Schengen and like we did with the European Patent. That is far better than to cave in to the blackmail of Orbán and Kaczyński.  (Applause)

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If we are having a debate today in preparation for the European Council – 10 and 11 December – then allow me to single out two things that are of particular importance to me. The first point is the relationship between the European Union and Turkey. As you know, accession negotiations have been under way here since 2005. And instead of being able to make progress here at least by a metre, Turkey is moving in a completely wrong direction. You are all aware of the debate on the human rights situation, the lack of the rule of law, the lack of democracy. You are all familiar with the debate on the treatment of minorities, namely Kurds. You are all familiar with the discussion on Turkey's foreign policy activities, keywords conflict Nagorno-Karabakh, eastern Mediterranean, Iraq, Syria. Everywhere you have behaviour that is diametrically designed to form a kind of consensus of European interests. Moreover, do not forget that If Turkey were a Member State of the European Union, it would be an Islamic country, and so that the European Union would also sail under the Islamic flag, with a country that has the most inhabitants – a fundamentally wrong development. My approach would therefore be to speak clearly and finally to put an end to this accession process, instead of continuing these negotiations and giving hundreds of millions in euros and preparatory aid. A second point, which is also very important to me and which will perhaps bring about a debate at the Council meeting, is terrorism. In Austria, we had an ugly attack by an Islamist assassin at the beginning of November, resulting in four deaths and more than 20 serious injuries. If this European Union does not see itself as a western-style set of values and discourages this Islamism from being the whole thing, then the EU will also fail.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Madam President, the Council will meet after ten months of an unprecedented health crisis. The risk is twofold: social dislocation and the oblivion of the ecological crisis. Yet the crisis we are going through is systemic, it is ecological. Destroying nature makes us vulnerable. Everything has to change: how to distribute wealth, to produce, to consume. By bringing the climate back into the background, we are feeding the very evils that are leading us today to the decline of civil liberties and social justice. Mrs. von der Leyen, hold on, we don't negotiate with the climate. Five years after the Paris agreement, the French Council of State has just reminded, after the Dutch Supreme Court, that climate action is an obligation. In view of our historical responsibility, the current procrastination on the target of at least 55%, or even 60% as we ask, for the climate by 2030 is miserable. Stop waiting, let us finally adopt the political objectives that will allow us to keep our planet alive, to preserve the rights of all and our democracies.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are approaching a decisive Council swamped by too much, too much hypocrisy. The words of the left and the fratricidal ones from the PPE benches, those of so many governments and the mainstream media, all to tell us a pre-packaged and self-desoling truth, in which Europe's supposed enemies blackmail everyone else from Warsaw and Budapest. Unfortunately, the opposite is true: those who slow down the funds for recovery are the left of this Parliament, blinded by ideological hatred, and it is the governments of the frugal countries that, it must be admitted with some consistency, the Recovery Fund never wanted it, and they do so by introducing conditionality on the rule of law that is outside the treaties, to blackmail Orbán and Morawiecki today and tomorrow Iohannis and any other government that does not accept their diktats. Now all that is needed is hypocrisy, respect the Treaties, go back to the July rule of law agreement and release the funds for recovery, or millions of Europeans who are suffering will present the bill to you.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – (start of speech without microphone) ... divided, democracy, minority rights, women's rights are under threat. Enemy images of minorities are built, on the basis and on the basis of which their rights are then cured. That is why much is at stake at the next Council meeting. Are we a Union that invests, through a long financial framework, in climate action, research, innovation, green transition and the future? Are we a Union that is not flexible about fundamental values that defend the legality of our society, the rule of law and democracy?  I welcome the tripartite compromise on the rule of law mechanism. It contains a preventive element of recipients of last-place subsidies, their status is protected, and a functioning decision-making process. This is in line with Parliament's demands and position, but there can be no compromise on this. Democracy is non-negotiable because the opposite of the rule of law is authoritarian arbitrary power. A functioning rule of law and free courts guarantee the fundamental rights of citizens and the freedom of people and societies.  Although a number of countries are emerging in this debate, I would like to remind you that this mechanism has not been built against any single Member State, but that these demands to uphold the rule of law and free societies apply to every single Member State.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Madam President, Mr Orbán happens to be an important leader of the EPP. His abuses have long been tolerated and he knows that the Council and the Commission will eventually find some, perhaps messy, way out. As long as Member States can exercise with power, grand statements from this Parliament about the rule of law are mostly hypocritical. Speaking is easy. This Parliament really needs to support the rule of law in a concrete and credible way. To start with, this Parliament should not tolerate the fact that concern for human rights is applied selectively, turning the internal affairs attention switch on and off depending on what Member State we are looking at. For Catalans, the European institutions keep attention turned off. Our human rights are not their concern. So, for example, the Commission can report on the rule of law in Spain and have the nerve to ignore Amnesty International and the United Nations group on the tensions. Please stop hypocrisy in this Parliament.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, we are thirty-six days from Brexit and with the recovery fund blocked, and the European Council is allowed not to be present in this debate. It seems to me to be a clear expression of what is happening to us in the European Union.  I demand that the Presidency not hold a debate like this again, feeling the Council's contempt for Parliament.  Since the wars we have not had as much need as we are now to be united and to work together, but neither have we made as much of an effort as we are now making to provide ourselves with funds, to provide us with European money that saves Europeans.  That is why I want us to think about the United Kingdom, because being outside the European Union is going to be left out of the recovery fund. Next year, for the first time, we Europeans are going to give us money that is not going to come from any state, but from our pooled debt; but not the UK, because the UK next year is going to be out. The family is there for when you need it and so does the European Union, and now they're going to see how bad it is when you're alone. With no recovery fund, no single market if we don't reach an agreement and without Donald Trump, the UK can become a real economic island. That's why we have to make an effort, not only because we feel linked to them, but because they're our neighbors, to try to help them make next year not the blackest of their entire history. And that is why it is not understood that, from within the European Union, some countries are trying to block the recovery fund.  We can argue about euros, we can argue about money, but we cannot discuss principles and we cannot act against our own interest.  Nearly three hundred thousand Europeans and Europeans have died since the pandemic began and millions are losing their jobs and losing their relationship with the world. These victims do not deserve us to dedicate ourselves here to iliberal political games.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: – Madam President, I too would like to begin with a memory of women victims of gender-based violence, because it is the worst face of the inequality, discrimination and machismo that women in the world suffer. And, against these violations of rights and against many others, we have been fighting in this Parliament for years. And we're not going to take a step back. That is why I want to send three messages for the next European Council.  Firstly, that the agreements on the financial framework and the rule of law, negotiated by this Parliament with the German Presidency, are balanced, sensible and supported agreements by a very large majority of this House. And I want to be very clear: the negotiations are closed and the agreements with this Parliament are not modifiable.  Second message: I think we all agree that a solution to twenty-seven is the best of solutions. If there is one thing that characterizes the European Union, it is negotiation and agreement. I believe that we are in time to close this chapter with absolute success and for this purpose the German Presidency has our full support. My third message must also be very clear: the ultimate objective must be to implement the conditionality mechanism, long-term budgets and recovery plan, and to be able to issue debt to finance it. And we're not going to let anything put it into question. If we can't do it by a usual procedure, we'll do it with alternatives. And, in case it's not clear, no matter what happens and what happens as it happens, citizens are going to have a rule of law mechanism, budgets and recovery plan.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Madam President, how many hours and days have we worked on this recovery plan in this Chamber, when our governments have already presented their own recovery plans, when we are in the second wave of the pandemic, when some Member States are already thinking about a second recovery plan? In any case, we have some difficulties in explaining to our fellow citizens that there is still no signature of the Council and Parliament on this agreement negotiated between us at the bottom of the page. I would just like to point out a few things to our colleagues who have criticised the method and the way, but also the institutional framework in which this agreement was made. In April, in the same Chamber, we reached an agreement between our political groups. In July, the Heads of State and Government, after a unanimous Council, reached an agreement. And then, on the basis of this agreement, our colleagues worked for hours, days, nights, to find an institutional agreement.
