And for the last two weeks we have had an agreement: this is European democracy. And I hear the criticisms about democracy and the process, but it is European democracy. And we must recall it here and hammer it: we cannot be caught by the extreme right of this Chamber. This process is, from a democratic point of view, absolutely indisputable. Today we are worried because I can see the attempt to ridicule seven months of work between us, between political groups, between representatives of the European people. I will just end by saying, Madam President, that I, like my colleague Gonzalez Pons, would have liked to see the representative of the Council here. I understand that the German permanent representative has a lot of negotiations, but at least one representative. What values are given to Parliament today? And in this configuration, we will have to advance surely to 25, maybe to 26, I hope, but in any case, we know very well that unanimity is not the only way. It is the work of all these months that is being discussed, European democracy has done its work and therefore I would like to say today also to the Council that it will have to take its responsibilities in the coming days.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam President! The President of the European Council has proposed on Twitter that the EU should set up imam schools, and he will address that at the December Council. I have almost no words for how foolish and naïve I think the President-in-Office's imam's proposal is. Mass immigration from Islamic countries is challenging our values these years. Do you really expect that the terror of Islamism can be curbed by putting imams in school and giving them Quran lessons? I am still shocked at how naïve the EU system is when it comes to Islam, terror and mass immigration. The EU system has not yet realised that Europe is in a struggle for survival that cannot be reversed with dialogue coffee, Euro-Islam or imam training. The battle for Europe is won by closed borders, control of immigration and repatriation of Islamists and troublemakers. That is why dear EU leaders, the only thing you have to train the Islamists in is to find the nearest airport and go back to their own countries, because they have nothing and do in Europe.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, the first thing is to pay tribute today, 25 November, to the victims of sexist violence and their families and to promise them that we will continue to fight to get ahead, so that ratification of the Istanbul Convention will be completed. With regard to the blockade of Hungary and Poland at hand today, some would prefer this Parliament to take the option that, as the recovery fund is so essential, we should set aside the mechanism for defending the rule of law. That's not going to happen. This Parliament is not going to reopen any of the agreements that are already closed. And that has to be clear to everyone. Further, Mr Zanni tells us that we may have to abandon the Community method to unlock it. We don't have to abandon the Community method. We have perfectly mechanisms, as has been said here, to move the recovery fund forward without abandoning the Community method. I would like to pay tribute to the mayors of Budapest and Warsaw, who have raised their pro-European voice from Hungary and Poland. And I would also like to tell friends of the People's Party that Orbán acts as an act because he has been protected for too long. It is time to take decisions, because other hand, Parliament's credibility in defending the rule of law is diminished as long as Orbán remains in the ranks of the European People's Party.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, in recent years we have seen international trade rules being called into question. It is a warning sign that the interest in setting standards of international trade is being expressed by Communist China, which is currently formalising a trade agreement between fifteen countries.  I therefore hope that trade relations between the EU and the UK will be managed by common agreement in December. I would like the Council not to waste time and, with the advent of the new US administration, to resume trade negotiations between the EU and the US. A comprehensive agreement across the Atlantic will create the world's strongest trading bloc, bringing much-needed growth and jobs to the European Union as well.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I will use what you are here for, so I will ask you why there is no effective system of verification of European funds in Croatia? Why is there no effective system in Bulgaria to verify European funds? If various schemes, such as the Universal Basic Income Scheme, were to be funded, it must be made impossible for money to leak all over the place. Why is it allowed across Europe for money to go into the pockets of thieves with close ties to the authorities in their countries instead of the citizens who paid the money? In Croatia, the body that is supposed to control it is called AFCOS - it just claims that it does not have the authority to do control. And now, why does this mess exist? Why does it suit someone for that disorder and that crime? Is it because there's no competition from these countries, is it because you don't care? And for Croatia, is it because the Croatian Prime Minister is your friend?

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, I will speak about Brexit. In this process, there has always been a time deficit and since day one we have worked against the clock. This continues. Today we are all with Michel Barnier and his team, hoping that by the end of the weekend there will be a ratifiable agreement.  Will it give us sufficient time to see the future partnership agreement entering into force on 1 January? I dare say, we don’t know. Contingency planning should continue. A lot has been done, but of course a no-deal scenario has never been our option. So we can only hope that compromises will be reached, review clauses established, brackets gone in time for us to go into proper democratic scrutiny.  The question is how far our House can go with pragmatists. We have to be clear on one issue where there is no space for pragmatists: the Council decision of 25 February this year authorising the opening of these negotiations made it very explicit. It says that the negotiations of the envisaged partnership should be premised on the effective implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement and its three protocols. Full and timely implementation of this agreement is fundamental for us here. We hope to hear again soon from Vice-President Maroš Šefčovič on this. And we cannot forget either the famous clauses in the Internal Market Bill and their effective disappearance.  We know that in the Union, political will makes miracles. But there are limits. Many options can be discussed and likely will be discussed, including provisional implementation with a delayed ratification. We do not know yet either whether this will be a new exclusive competence agreement, but I sincerely hope we will not be pressed by such challenges. It is clear that the list of risks and uncertainty stays long. What must be respected, however, is this House’s right of proper democratic scrutiny. (Applause)

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, at this European Council it is too late to adopt the Multiannual Financial Framework. We have reached a political agreement with the Council. We are waiting for the Council to honor its commitment. We need a Multiannual Financial Framework on 1 January 2021. We all know what it means to enter a twelfth-tenths mechanism. We don't want that.  The situation in January 2021 is not the same as we had in January 2020. The crisis changed everything. The MFF and the Recovery Fund are the answer. The European Union cannot frustrate citizens, but that is what the Council is doing.  We can't give in to blackmail. It is assumed that all Member States respect the principles with which they have committed themselves. The rule of law is one of them and the mechanism that we have now agreed politically with the Council concerns 27 and not two or three. It merely ensures, in a transparent and democratic manner, the proper use of European money. That is why we do not understand that countries can reject this mechanism.  Minister, you are not, but I have to mention it, Commissioner, yes, we need to find a way out of this crisis. This exit cannot be made at the expense of the Values of the Union and, above all, it must be within the Community framework. The European Parliament does not dispense with its capacity as budgetary authority, but also does not dispense with what we have jointly built in the process of negotiating this MFF.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which While a survey in all Member States shows that in Hungary, the most citizens feel the financial impact of the Corona crisis, Viktor Orban is engaged in a public debate with George Clooney. I think that is the wrong way of prioritising, including for its citizens. And it goes further, this wrong setting of priorities. It blocks the entire budget there, which would also help the citizens the most, the Corona aid, which would actually help him the most and, incidentally, Poland the most. There is now much talk here of these two governments, including here today in plenary. At the summit in the summer, there would have been no agreement on the rule of law. But the rule of law conditionality was part of it, and the two agreed. The rule of law is a vague concept and that is not in the Treaties at all. But that's what it does! And then there is the greatest thing: the rule of law is actually just a matter of punishing Member States that want a different migration policy. That is simply a bare lie! When I hear all this, I wonder: have you read the regulation at all? I think no. And I can only recommend it to everyone. I would like to ask the whole right here in the European Parliament the question, because otherwise you want to pay so much attention to every euro that flows into Europe and best of all want to have as little of it as possible. How do you actually explain to your citizens, your taxpayers, that you are continuing to defend here that Viktor Orban is distributing EU money to his corrupt friends? I really wonder. That is what you are doing here in the European Parliament. A warning to the European Presidency, even if it is not here today: we are now hearing that we might be able to offer Hungary and Poland that they are not using the mechanism at all, or that the Article 7 procedure or similar things are being stopped. These are all the wrong compromises. I warn the Chancellor, who said here at the beginning of the Presidency of the Council in Parliament: the rule of law is what matters. This word she has given us here will be shown by the extent to which she is now actually committed to it.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wonder in this House how many people have read Franz Kafka's 'The Trial'. I wonder because I have the impression that I am witnessing a surreal debate, the sentence of which has already been delivered. It is political blackmail, a story that has already been written, since it was clear to everyone that, by adopting a controversial regulation by qualified majority, the consequences would be a veto on the budget, which would lengthen the already lackluster timing of the Recovery Plan. As far as external relations are concerned, I read that you will be dealing with Turkey, a country where human rights are trampled underfoot and freedom of the press does not exist. But this Parliament, instead of making amends for the billions of euros, since we have talked about it before, given to Erdoğan, finds time to debate Poland and Hungary. Well, perhaps take advantage of this to have a nice debate on the rule of law, but in Ankara. Finally, with regard to security, let us not forget what happened only a few weeks ago in Vienna and Nice. In one of the two cases, the killer had landed on the Italian coast illegally. Let us not forget either that here, last year, someone thought of applying Article 7 to Italy, whose Minister of the Interior Matteo Salvini had considered putting a stop to the business of illegal immigration. Good work, gentlemen, despite the fact that there are no representatives of the Council today. We need a change of pace because, if we discuss it in Brussels, we die in the rest of Europe.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which How can it be that Viktor Orban is leading the whole of Europe by the nose? The Commission, the vast majority here in Parliament, almost all the Member States wanted a conditionality on the rule of law with an upside-down qualified majority. Orban has prevailed, and we here in Parliament have swallowed this very painful compromise, because in this most serious crisis we want to leave the millions of Europeans who do not want to leave many thousands of companies in the rain. Nevertheless, we now have this veto. It is the next stage in a ten-year process, and I believe it is time for us to finally admit that this appeasement policy does not work with Viktor Orban. We see it in the constitutional amendments. Now he writes that the looting of EU funds can continue if he loses an election at some point. He writes it into the constitution, and he also changes it so that he does not lose the election and makes it even more difficult for the opposition. Unfortunately, in this situation, the German Presidency is not in favour of the debate here in Parliament for the second time. I think that you should finally get through the ratification of conditionality. That is the right signal that we need now.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to remind my colleagues that this Union is, or at least should be, a Union of free and equal nations built on treaties in a spirit of compromise, not dictatorship. The Treaties talk about how we set the multiannual financial framework. There is no word on the conditionality of funds on an arbitrarily defined risk to the rule of law. You would like to get around these treaties. Speaking of the rule of law, you want to violation the EU rule of law. Poland and Hungary have exercised their right. This parliament also blocked the agreement for months, exercising its right. This is not a discussion of European values. This is not a question of European values, because we respect them. This is a discussion about who has the right to interpret them. You have the right to interpret them. We do not, for example, believe that human dignity lies in free abortion and free euthanasia. We do not think that democracy is about the decision in Brussels on who is to govern in Warsaw and Budapest, and not in this House.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: – We MEPs from Fidesz and the KDNP agree with the position of the leading politicians of the European People's Party, which clearly and emphatically rejects the political blackmail tool of so-called rule of law conditionality. In fact, EPP President Donald Tusk said, and I quote, "making EU budgetary resources dependent on the rule of law is a risky step and points in the wrong direction. It would not be good for Europe to confuse these two regulations. Resources allocated to different tasks in the budget should not be subject to purely political criteria." We agree with Tusk. Jean Claude Juncker of the People's Party, as President of the European Commission, said of the proposal, and I quote, "I believe that we should not do this. Threats are not appropriate to comply with the rule of law. I do not think that it would be useful to share the European Union. That would be toxic for the continent." Juncker is right. And Manfred Weber explained in an article less than a year ago on the conditioning of the rule of law that common values are not specific categories, but abstract categories. The protection of the legal community must not be subject to daily political beliefs and there is a risk that the rule of law procedure will be involved in political battles and therefore no new political acionism is necessary. We support Manfred Weber's position.  German Chancellor Angela Merkel said of the situation in the absence of agreement between Hungary and Poland, and I quote, "if the European Parliament establishes a majority, but there is no unanimity in the European Council between the heads of state and government, then this is not possible." On the one side is the unanimity of the Member States. Angela Merkel is right. We therefore remain in favour of the people's party's position rejecting the political blackmail tool.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: – Madam President, it’s really time to close up the agreement on the budget, the Recovery Fund and own resources. It is not acceptable that countries like Hungary and Poland, which have democracy disregard, which have minorities in disregard, which have women and independent media in disregard, keep on blocking everything.  We as MPs have to relaunch the conference on the future of Europe and to revise the unanimity rule and real paralysis in decision—making. We can’t be hostages of veto points and national selfishness. We can’t be hostages of despotic leaders and we can’t rely every time on rescue at the last by Angela Merkel, like kids with their mummy. Chers amis, des millions de citoyens sont en train d’attendre des réponses solides, concrètes et visionnaires. Il ne s’agit pas de nos petites carrières, il s’agit de donner des certitudes et il s’agit de l’avenir de nos jeunes, de la lutte pour la démocratie, le climat et les droits.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, we have said it so many times in this Chamber and I will say it again: we have a chance for a historic budget, a budget that demonstrates vision, courage and solidarity, that reforms our own resources after five decades, and that is ready to take on the climate crisis. It is also a budget which has a rule of law conditionality mechanism. After so many years, the EU is finally demonstrating that it is ready to take action against democratic backsliding and stop behaving like an ATM for corrupt autocrats. Frankly, it’s a disgrace that it has waited so long.  Let me remind you that the rule of a mechanism does not require unanimity and the Parliament has no intention of taking even one step back. Every intention that works in the opposite direction is a historic mistake and is a sign of political weakness. We will not succumb to this. The fact that Prime Ministers Orbán and Morawiecki got so hysterical about this probably demonstrates that we are on the right track because, if the rule of law is as much in order in these countries as they claim, then why do they hate their citizens so much to deprive them of the recovery money in times of crisis, alongside so many other millions of Europeans?  Let’s make something clear: this is not an east-west divide, it is not about a bizarre global conspiracy theory, it’s not an anti-Hungarian coup and it’s not an anti-Polish machination,  because what can be more pro—Hungarian or pro—Polish than standing up for the money that belongs to the citizens to get where it really has to be - to the small businesses, to the local communities - and not into the pockets of autocrats or members of Viktor Orbán’s family? It is not about Christianity either. Last time I checked, stealing is against the Bible too, so let’s keep that in mind.  One last thing, let me say to those on the right in this House and to the Conservatives in the Council: please stop appeasing European autocrats. It’s not working and you are making a huge mistake here. Please stand on the side of the people and on the side of European values. After so long, you have a historic chance to do that.  (Applause)

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, beyond the health crisis on the agenda of the next European Council, the news reminds us every day that Europe is going through another crisis, which you sometimes seem to forget about, I want to talk about the security crisis. In recent weeks, Islamist terrorism has hit Europe hard again. He knocked in Paris, he struck in Nice, he struck in Vienna and the terrorists did not come from here. They entered the continent without difficulty, then crossed unhindered the borders that separate the European countries, which were supposed to be strengthened in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. In its 25 years of existence, the Schengen area has shown its indigence in the face of each of the crises we have gone through. Europe has been unable to stem the migrant crisis of 2016: the Schengen system placing the full weight of controlling migration flows on countries of entry into the EU, already hard hit by an economic crisis. The Schengen system has not protected us from the terrorism crisis. Nor has it protected us from the health crisis, while elsewhere in the world, from Asia to New Zealand, it is the countries that have closed their borders very early on that have withstood the epidemic best. Today, Europe continues to flee forward. The European Commission is proposing a pact on migration that will jeopardise the continent's demographic stability and MEPs are calling for an immediate return to the open borders of Schengen in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. Faced with this ideological stubbornness, European heads of state must now decide on the suspension of the Schengen agreements. The crises we have been through in recent weeks remind us of a thousand-year-old lesson: borders are the best tools people have to protect themselves, so let us protect them.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Madam President, the next Council meeting is decisive for the future of the rule of law in the EU. Mr Orbán and Mr Morawiecki threaten to block EUR 1 800 billion meant for our citizens, for our climate and for our economies, to protect their own corrupt and autocratic agendas. We hear rumours that the German Presidency is seriously considering finding a compromise with those two Member States, but that would be a historical mistake. Giving in now would send a message that the EU gives in to blackmail and that it’s possible to violate the essential values and rules of the European treaties and enjoy impunity.  Now is not the time to focus on Poland or Hungary. We know the game that they’ve been playing for so long. It is instead time for the Council to admit that it has inflicted this crisis upon itself. Member States neglected the rule of law crisis for years and continuously prioritised other interests over the protection of our fundamental values. If the Council seriously wants to end the rule of law crisis in the EU, it must have the courage now to keep its legs stiff. Enough is enough. Council Presidency Member States, European citizens are counting on you. (Applause)

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Respect, solidarity, pragmatism are three conditions for discussing money for citizens seriously, to get out of the crisis and to be able to talk seriously about climate law, not blackmail, not emotion, not political muddle and ideological hysteria, because today that is what you are presenting in the European Parliament. We need to talk about climate law with respect, with responsibility for citizens. Because the European Parliament has not listened to what the Council has talked about. He broke all established rules, such as the new 2030 target. The council says 55%, the Environment Agency says that 40% is impossible to implement, Parliament says 60%. Similarly, when we talk about solidarity, we will come together to zero emissivity. Parliament says no, I repeat once again: solidarity, responsibility, pragmatism, respect for one another.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Today, International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, tell you: You are not alone.  Madam President, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to hit us all, highlighting that we are vulnerable and teaching us that, by acting together, we are stronger and more effective. That is why we support the Union's leadership in researching and buying vaccines, which is a breath of hope and for the future for all. We have a responsibility to save lives, to protect everyone's health, to boost the growth of our economy and to guarantee the jobs of millions of Europeans. That is why we must urgently boost European funds and make ambitious and necessary national reforms.  There are no populist policies here that are just looking to satisfy partisan desires. The Council should prevent the aid from s stoping. We can't wait any longer, we're suffering the biggest crisis of the last seventy years. Action must be taken and must be done by guaranteeing the rule of law and without allowing any attack on fundamental rights.  The rule of law and the recovery of the economy are paths that must go together, in the Union and in the 27 Member States, and, with this same intensity, we must face other challenges that we face today in Europe. We have once again suffered the ruthless violence of terrorism. Therefore, we need to continue to collaborate together, from the firmness and strength of the rule of law, to win this battle. We're playing our values.  The uncertainty caused by the prospect of an unencordance Brexit requires greater unity between Member States.  The images we are seeing in the Canary Islands are inadmissible. We must give a response from across the European Union, with a real common migration policy, to the ongoing drama of immigration. What happens in Spain happens in Europe.  We hope that, after the Council meeting, the news will be one: that Europe is more united than ever and that it gives a coordinated response to all the challenges ahead. European citizens need us and we cannot fail them.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by saying, as others have already done here, that the absence of the Council in this debate, in which the agenda of the Council meeting is a unacceptable insult to this Parliament and to European democracy, but I understand the Council's embarrassment, because the Council, with the veto of Hungary and Poland, is , it is not being able to make the financial crisis response package possible consistently with the agreement it has already negotiated with this Parliament on the rule of law. But this is a problem that the Council itself has to solve and it is important that it does so, honouring its word, because the intergovernmental solutions that some are talking about run the risk of not solving any problems and creating new problems, including the removal of this Parliament.  In our countries, it is often said that we should not leave for tomorrow what we can do today. The European version of this saying is: we must not leave to the Portuguese Presidency what we can resolve in the German Presidency. European citizens in the Union would not understand further postponements.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Madam President, at the next European Council, the fight against terrorism will be on the agenda. The day before, the Commission will have presented a new European agenda against terrorism. To you the Commission, to the members of the Council, but also to all of us MePs, I would like to say here that we must collectively do more and do better. Ursula von der Leyen, I ask you to stop hesitating to name the perpetrators of the barbaric terrorist acts that strike us with tragic regularity. It is Islamist jihadists who are attacking us, not for what we do, but for who we are: an area of freedom, tolerance, respect for everyone, a Europe of Enlightenment that will always put knowledge over beliefs, reason over obscurantism. To the members of the Council, whose absence I regret today in this Chamber, I ask to get out of the narrow nationalist reflexes which are the absolute opposite of what cooperation needs in the fight against terrorism. We need to give Europol a stronger mandate and more resources. We need a European anti-terrorism prosecutor. The European databases we have or put in place need to be better informed and communicated with each other. There is an urgent need to better secure our external borders, freedom of movement in Europe does not apply to terrorists, radicalised Islamists or arms traffickers. To all of us, the Commission, the Council, Parliament, I ask us to take our responsibilities to ensure that the regulation on the removal of terrorist content online is adopted quickly and that we commit ourselves without weakness to combating hateful content on the internet. Social networks had the ambition of being a formidable space of freedom, they sometimes became a formidable reservoir of hatred and incitement to violence. Acting responsibly against terrorism is what we owe to the victims of terrorism, their loved ones and all Europeans.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, this is going to be a quite crucial summit for the German Presidency. This is going to be their last, and basically whether we can judge whether the Presidency is going to be a success is going to depend on this last Council. There are a lot of issues at the table. We have been back-loading a lot on this last Council and I think everyone said it already very clear, it’s the European values that are at stake and the European Parliament will not accept any watering down of the deal that has been made before and we will remain on that line.  But also on vaccines, if we look at the distribution, now we have to make sure that it will be distributed to all our citizens in a fair and accessible way – very crucial. On Brexit, the deal must be fair and not undermining social and environmental standards, also that is at stake during this Council. And last but not least, the climate crisis. The world is changing. We have a new president in the United States and next year should be a year of global action. So this year, this December, Europe needs to get its own house in order and except the 2030 higher, ambitious climate targets.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab When we fight together against a pandemic, with terrorism, when we are fighting for a better climate, for the economy, for good trade, then we win in the European Union. It is bad when we forget about the Treaties, and one of the provisions of Article 4 of the Treaty says simply that any competence not to be ensigned of the European Union belongs to the Member States. Remember that. The July European Council remembered this and was therefore successful, but the European Parliament, through its resolution, destroyed this very good July agreement through various speeches. These false resolutions, false information, for example about Poland, have destroyed European solidarity. And that's how you want to keep doing. We will not allow it. We are not afraid.  Fake left-wing liberal prophets want to use fake weapons – the rule of law mechanism, or simply a mechanism of rage against Christian right-wing governments. You can see how this fake weapon is already delaying investment in the European Union. We stand still, we discuss. Europe is waiting for the truth and great values on which it began its activity with such important figures as Adenauer, Gasperi and Schuman.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Addressed to the Council: we cannot solve any problem with absence. We have to ask ourselves the question: is we still to be helped? In the US, Joe Biden and Kamala Harris are winning the effort to overcome divisions in the US and the world. And in the European Union, the mini-Trumps are blocking the biggest investment programme against Corona and into our common future for a more independent, greener, more digital, more democratic, more credible, stronger European Union. Is we still to help? Liberal parliamentary democracy, the legal and values community, the rule of law mechanism are non-negotiable. We will not be blackmailed! Neither from the inside nor from the outside. Hungary, or rather, the behaviour of the Heads of Government of Hungary and Poland, is un-European, it is undemocratic, it is unacceptable, it is directed against the future of Europe and, above all, against its own people. I ask the Council: do you finally realise that unanimity only helps nationalists, populists and blackmailers and harms Europe? Give up this instrument, regroup the decision-making process, create a directly elected Senate, get out of hostage securitisation and ensure a summit that decides what we have negotiated, that decides what we have decided – not only on the rule of law mechanism, not only in terms of investment in the future, but also in meeting our climate targets through the 60% climate target. , at least 55% by 2030. Do what you have to do!

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Madam President, the European Council meeting will be a decisive day where Europe will set the bar in its climate efforts, and we expect nothing less than that it contains a clear and progressive commitment on a revised EU climate target for 2030. It is high time that the Member States unite on a progressive target so that the European Parliament and the Council, as Union legislators, can have proper negotiations on the necessary updates in the Union climate effort accordingly. The European Parliament has already decided on revised EU 2030 target at 60% emission reduction compared to 1990. As the rapporteur from the European Parliament on climate law, I urge the Member States to do the same, to be constructive, listen to the citizens, listen to the science and be responsible, ensure that the European Council will agree on a sufficiently progressive Union climate target.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, President von der Leyen when you were referencing the EU-UK negotiations on Brexit you said and I quote, ‘we will do all in our power to reach an agreement, we are ready to be creative, but we are not ready to put into question the integrity of the single market, the main safeguard of European prosperity and wealth’. Equally, President von der Leyen, I say to everybody, we must not put into question the integrity of the Good Friday Agreement which is the main safeguard of Ireland’s prosperity and peace. This is a Rubicon which nobody can cross and we have to insist, regardless of what are the outcomes in terms of the Brexit negotiations, we simply must have a border on the island of Ireland that is open and unguarded, and this is a message I bring very strongly to everybody that’s involved in the final throes of these negotiations - those in the European Union negotiating on our behalf here in Ireland and those in the UK who are negotiating for the United Kingdom. Bearing in mind this Good Friday agreement is sacrosanct and is integral to peace on the island of Ireland. With regard to the COVID-19 vaccine, we need to show solidarity and I want to thank the European Commission for securing all these vaccine doses. But it must be dispersed in a fair manner - no rich countries versus poor countries, rich people versus poor people. It must be distributed based on medical advice and vulnerability of the peoples of Europe.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her excellent work. Two months ago, we in the European Parliament adopted the most ambitious climate law to date. We made three points clear. Firstly, we hear the call of young people. Secondly, we take the climate crisis seriously. Thirdly, we want to negotiate at last.  But we cannot negotiate, because the Heads of State or Government are blocking a decision. Now it is even clear that they will not adopt a climate target at their meeting in December. Don't do that! We cannot wait any longer. The dying, dehydrating forests, they can't wait any longer. And even the people who elected us for climate protection do not want to wait any longer. We have only a few years left to meet the 1.5° target. That is, every year, every month counts. Clear the way for the European Climate Protection Act! Anything else would be a disaster for the German Presidency and a bitter disappointment to the hopes of millions of young people across Europe.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Mrs von der Leyen recalled the famous compromise of 21 July this year just before leaving this Chamber. Indeed, at that time, the prime ministers of the 27 Member States agreed to a multiannual budget, a reconstruction fund with all its instrumentation. They also agreed to the rule of law mechanism, but understood as protecting the European Union's financial interests. Unfortunately, the parliamentary majority and the German Presidency broke this agreement brutally on 5 November. Now you call the countries that point out that this agreement has been broken, blackmailers. After all, this is bizarre. Two EU institutions point out that what you have prepared is in breaking the Treaties. The European Court of Auditors wrote that clear and detailed criteria for this mechanism were needed. For two years, the Commission has not prepared these criteria. Finally, the Council's legal services write that circumvention of Article 7 is a violation of the Treaties. You are on the agenda. How can eu treaties be violated and a mechanism for guarding the rule of law in the Member States can be created? After all, this is bizarre.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, the Council has put the fight against terrorism and violent extremism on its agenda for the next session. But, Madam President of the Commission, we will never have the courage to fight the enemy that is attacking us, if we do not even have the courage to appoint him. Professor Samuel Paty, the faithful of Notre-Dame de Nice, the recent victims of the Vienna attack were not victims of a vague anonymous extremism, but of a clear ideology: Islamism. And naming things is not superfluous, it is the condition to be able to finally act effectively because, in order to put an end to terrorism, we will obviously have to improve our cooperation in security and justice, but we must finally agree to fight an ideological battle. Islamism attacks what Europe has too often given up defending: our civilization, our principles, a certain way of living, deliberating and transmitting. In short, all the police in Europe, despite their dedication, will not prevent violence from striking if we have done nothing upstream to combat the grip of this ideology, especially among the youngest. The Commission really wants to be reduced to sending its condolences, attack after attack? So there is no point in indignanting in the vacuum against violent extremism, we must start by no longer being complicit in this ideology, by stopping funding associations inspired by the Muslim Brotherhood that spread, with European funds, the hatred that will make other innocent victims tomorrow, by stopping subsidizing Islamist leaders, like Erdogan, when he is still attacking by stopping turning a blind eye - and I turn to you, ladies and gentlemen, in this Parliament which says it is so attached to the rule of law - that in many parts of our countries, the leaden cloak of a fundamentalist Islam has replaced the authority of our democracies. We must put an end to our denial of migration, so many attacks would have been avoided if no one had been able to enter Europe if it had not been legally allowed. On this point, and only on this account, we can succeed in the challenge of rebuilding the unity of our societies around common principles and then we will have really worked against violence by fighting against the Islamism that feeds it today.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, it is gradually clear to everyone, I hope, that there is a very strong link between the European Green Deal and European trade policy. The objectives, the ambitious targets, which we set for our internal policy, must be translated into trade policy. What we preach with us, we must also preach in the rest of the world. And in that context, I really need something from the heart.  We have worked very hard today on vaccines and tests – with great success – and I think it has been Von der Leyen, our President of the Commission, who has said that Europe will only be safe if the whole world is safe and therefore has access to a vaccine. So I would like to have an explanation from the Commission and the Council as to why we are opposing the World Trade Organisation, where there is an initiative by a number of countries to impose a derogation – temporarily, during the pandemic – to ensure that duty-free production can be made – for example, a vaccine, because that is going to be a very big problem. I would like to know why we are opposed to this. What are the reasons? And why don't we negotiate? Because Europe will not be safe until the whole world is safe.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is characteristic that the German Commissioner is first pushing for a rule of law regulation in 2018, and now the German Presidency is pushing to end this. The main charge against Polish "politicized choice of judges." Meanwhile, Germany has the most politicised way of selecting judges across Europe. There, politicians often choose politicians as judges. And in Poland? Next, the judges have a decisive influence. And you have the audacity to tell Poles that they are in power? I will remind you that to this day you have not even paid one euro for your previous lessons in the rule of law in Poland. How many more examples of your arrogance that has broken European solidarity are needed for you to understand that every country has the right to decide what is enshrined in the Treaties? Do you want to talk about the rule of law? Here you go. Is it law-abiding to get along with Putin over the heads of Europeans on the gas issue? Is this the solidarity and rule of law that Germany wants to teach the whole of Europe?

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, the Council we are going to have on 10 and 11 December is decisive in that the most important, most fundamental of our European Union is at stake. These are the values of the rule of law, the values of the rule of law, and it is essential that the Council is able to signal to all European citizens that the values of the rule of law are ahead of any other interest, whether national, regional, partisan or social.  This is the fundamental point and it is very important that the Portuguese Presidency too is clearly linked to these values and that it does not return to its July position, in which before the July European Council, Prime Minister Portuguese said that the rule of law should not be linked to the Recovery Fund. It is important that you have changed your position and it is important that you remain true to that position. On the other hand, there is a fundamental point for the European Union which is precisely the agreement with the United Kingdom, which is precisely the regulation of Brexit. Let us hope that the Uk will show positive signs and, if it gives these positive signs, that we will be able to prepare a future relationship that is fruitful.  If this cannot be done, then it is crucial, it is indeed essential, that the European Union, in one of the most difficult moments of its life with the crisis, is also able to prepare effective contingency plans for a deregulated Brexit.  These are the two main concerns in the midst of the one that is the greatest, which afflicts our citizens today, which is precisely the pandemic and the vaccination phase.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that we were making good developments in the negotiation of the financial framework, the Decision on own resources, the Rule of Law Regulation, and also a reasonable development in the regulation which is pending us on recovery, when we were aware of the threat of the Polish, Hungarian and Slovenian Governments. I want to say that this threat is not a fundamental threat to the European Union, but is, in essence, a threat to its own citizens. Citizens who are suffering the authoritarian and liberal path of their governments and who may run out of access to the recovery fund, but also without access to new instruments of the Multiannual Financial Framework, such as the Fair Transition Fund. So, I think that's an unbelievable threat. A threat which must have a strong response on the part of the Council, a Council response supported by this Parliament, which also needs parliamentary groups of families whose national leaders are behind this threat to move tabs.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, it’s a pleasure to be with you this morning from Dublin. The EU leaders’ summit is an agenda that is a shopping list of pivotal topics for our Union.  Brexit is not on the agenda, which is very much on our minds. Thanks again to Michel Barnier, Ursula von der Leyen, Angela Merkel and the German Presidency for trying to get a deal done. If the United Kingdom meets us halfway, I think that it can be done. We can get the deal done. Brexit is, of course, not the only issue. The pandemic is the big challenge as of now. But the news of several successful vaccines is a great ray of hope. It’s a triumph for research, cooperation and indeed EU funding, which isn’t mentioned often enough. It will lead to the biggest rollout of a vaccine ever seen. This must be done carefully, prioritising the most vulnerable.  The vaccine will help in the health recovery, but we also need an economic recovery. The EU recovery fund is a great initiative, but we also need a trade and investment policy that is fit to meet the challenges as well. We need to diversify our supply chains, we need more effective risk management tools and we need stockpiling of key products, such as medical equipment. On the climate side, the Green Deal is our major initiative. We have targets and we have ambition, but targets and ambition are no good unless they are met. So, this time next year, rather than talking about what we should be doing in 2030, 2040 or 2050, I would like to hear what each Member State has actually achieved in 2021. The same for the next four years so that, when we finish this term, we can say we have achieved so much and gone so far in reaching our ambition and our targets.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, 2020 is a year we will remember for a long time for the health and economic crisis. Nevertheless, in recent days we have received encouraging news about finding a vaccine. I welcome efforts to make the vaccine available to citizens and particularly at-risk groups as soon as possible.  The European Union must also help make the vaccine available to countries involved in the pre-stage process, as the fight against the virus does not end at our borders. As for the neighbourhood, I expect the leaders of the European Union to adopt a clear common position on Turkey at the Council. It is inadmissible for us to witness almost daily aggressive provocations that defy international law and call into question the territorial integrity of our members.  We want a more ambitious Council approach to climate. I ask all members to include binding climate neutrality measures in their legislation by 2050. I certainly expect the summit to confirm the agreement on a multiannual budget. European citizens' money must not be used for the political agendas of autocratic governments that are vetoed not only by shared values but also by the economic recovery of the entire Union.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we face multiple security challenges and Turkey has a key role to play. Some of this is the result of our indecision in the past, such as our inability to deal with the threat of terrorism and our heterogeneous relations with states such as Turkey. Unfortunately, our procrastination as the European Parliament in both these areas now threatens to explode in front of us, creating a significant impact on the security of the citizens of the European Union. Our tolerance of the Erdoğan government's proven links to ISIS enclaves for oil smuggling in the past has remained unanswered. Cooperation with Turkey's extreme jihadists in Syria, their training and their transfer as mercenaries to Libya and Nagorno Karabakh also went unanswered. Erdoğan's tooling of the refugee issue, primarily to collect funding and to put pressure on Europe to serve its own interests, not only met with weak reactions, but was also accepted to some extent. But now we are faced with the consequences of our indecision, as ISIS fighters were arrested by the Greek authorities after they passed through Turkey. We are experiencing the challenge of religious tensions in the Muslim communities of France at the instigation of Erdoğan. Ladies and gentlemen, all the European Union's actions so far have, unfortunately, been evidenced by Turkey's extremely provocative attitude, but without addressing the problem at its root. Turkey and Erdoğan threaten Member States of our Union and the security of our citizens and the European Council must assume its historic responsibility with groundbreaking decisions and the activation of sanctions. This change in attitude and position should only take place if Turkey really proves by actions that it is changing its mindset. Europe cannot remain an observer. Europe is the crown of stability and law, and it must state this explicitly everywhere.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, the Council's agenda of 10 December speaks of solidarity in the face of the pandemic, but not a word of solidarity in the face of the migratory event; there is only one mention of migration, when talking about Turkey and the eastern Mediterranean. But does the Council ignore that at the moment the most pressing and deadly route is migration to the Canary Islands and that the drama we are living in the cayucos crisis between 2004 and 2006 worsens? Because then there was no European Asylum Support Office, no Frontex operation, no Asylum and Migration Fund, no area of freedom, justice and security governed by the mandate of shared responsibility and binding solidarity, nor re-assurance programmes, which must be reactivated as soon as possible. But in the meantime, of course, the insolidarios cannot get away with it, nor in their refusal to take down the rule of law with all its consequences or in its refusal to solidarity with the States that maintain external borders of the European Union. Commission, Council: The Canary Islands is not a wall, it is Spain, it is the European Union. And people rescued at sea who arrive at the ports of the Canary Islands are already in the European Union and are our common responsibility.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Madam President, in these uncertain times for millions of Europeans finding concrete solidarity in health and economic crisis should certainly be on the top of the leaders’ agenda in December. There is another topic however that deserves our utmost attention and that is the fight against violent extremism. The recent Islamist terrorist attacks in Vienna and across France have once again shocked Europe but also shown that the need for a stronger European fight against terrorism and radicalisation is really necessary. This is not only a French or Austrian tragedy, but this is also an attack on Europe. Only last year there were more than 100 prevented, failed or completed terrorist attacks across the EU, and more than 1 000 individuals were arrested on suspicion of terrorism-related offenses. This shows that fights on multiple fronts, including on online platforms, coordination and appropriate funding can prevent such attacks. Freedom requires security and protection of citizens – from the pandemic from the economic crisis – but also from brutal terrorism.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, Poland and Hungary want to receive subsidies from the European Union, but refuse to live up to European values, which we find unacceptable. The European Parliament wants to put an end to this and has therefore fortunately succeeded in concluding a historic agreement. It hit Orbán and consorts where it hurts the most: in the wallet. Now that the Heads of Government of Poland, Hungary and Slovenia have vetoed the European Recovery Fund and the multiannual budget, they are jeopardising much-needed measures to tackle the corona crisis. It is now up to European leaders to put pressure on their colleagues. This recovery fund must be put in. We don't give in to blackmail. Every citizen in Europe must be able to ensure that his or her rights are guaranteed.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Vice-President Šefčovič, ladies and gentlemen, at the leaders' summit on 10 December, the European Union is facing an existential dilemma. Will it proceed with sanctions against Turkey as it has warned for months now, or will it continue its policy of tolerance and appeasement towards Erdoğan? Turkey did not take advantage of the window of opportunity given to it by the European Union to sit at the table for dialogue with Greece, instead continuing its aggressive behaviour in the Aegean. Erdoğan himself has ostentatiously violated United Nations resolutions with his visit to Varoshi. Turkey is serially violating the rules of the rule of law. Turkey is insulting our values by turning Hagia Sophia, the World Heritage Site, into a mosque. Turkey is violating the peace operation to monitor the embargo on Libya. Turkey is violating and demonstrating its strength in Nagorno Karabakh, violating international legitimacy and ultimately believes that the European Union will not deliver on its warnings. Will the European Union stay in the words? Will he succumb to the attack of friendship of the last twenty-four hours, when there are already scenarios that bring Erdoğan ready to annex occupied Cyprus?  Will the European Union give such a window of opportunity to Erdoğan who appears as an official trespasser of international legitimacy, not only in the Eastern Mediterranean, but also in the Caucasus? It is very important to understand this: by postponing decisions on sanctions on Turkey, the European Union is not only undermining the course of Greece and Cyprus. The European Union is undermining its international path as an international player. She shoots her legs, and I think that's the biggest disaster she can do to herself.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has When the Heads of State or Government meet at their summit in December, blockades must be resolved, without any false compromises. But a conclusion will also be drawn, a preliminary conclusion of the German Presidency. Let me say that this conclusion will be: Europe has become different, this Germany has become different from what it was ten years ago – a Europe that is helping itself. A Europe that supports itself. The reconstruction programme will once go down in the history books as a reversal of the trend towards more solidarity, fiscal responsibility and a common will to build a more sustainable Europe. We need this debate internationally, Mr. Efsovic. I miss our discussion about europe's strategic role in the world. Because only if we work together, with Latin America, with Africa, and with Asia – and Joe Biden will be a partner – can we turn that into the future and build a just, sustainable world. I would ask you to put this directly on the agenda: in the Commission, in this House, we will ensure that this is the case, and also in the Council.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in preparation for the European Council meeting, I believe that the European Union must strengthen its control over sensitive technologies. A recent report by the Tactics Institute for Security and Counter Terrorism, the UK-based research organisation, publicly presents worrying facts: technological transactions of know-how between the West and third countries, which use them against their opponents to subvert democracy. Examples include the UAE's infrastructure and internal surveillance program, DREAD, which has been used to monitor Saudi women's rights activists, UN diplomats, FIFA staff and political and human rights activists. Other examples are project Travel and project Karma. The first helped the United Arab Emirates identify political opposition to the monarchy; the second developed iPhone violation features. Activists, diplomats and rival foreign leaders from the Middle East have been targeted with malware spread via mobile phones, or by email or remotely. We must recognise that many totalitarian regimes use these weapons. Some prefer to be part of the Western Internet ecosystem, engaging directly or by proxy to undermine transparency and privacy, to outline their digital sovereignty while maintaining the economic benefits of connectivity. Authoritarian regimes can become so efficient and sophisticated in suppressing opposition with information technology that they do not have to resort to brutal coercion. They may even appear benign in the eyes of world public opinion. The European Union should then concern itself with the export of knowledge and technology, with strict restrictions, as well as the export of conventional weapons. The European Union could set a benchmark and regulatory parameters that can be imposed on others. This can be done through strategic planning and within a framework of cooperation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the December European Council must be decisive in closing the agreement on the multiannual budget and the Recovery Plan. The European Parliament has played its part, European governments must now do theirs. There can be no risk of further delays because of the whims of the sovereignists. The Hungarian and Polish Governments, with their vetoes in response to the rule of law rules, are also doing harm to their citizens, who are beginning to realise this and therefore, we are sure, will have to go back in their footsteps. The European Union is not an ATM and respect for the fundamental values of the Union cannot remain an optional option, as has sometimes been the case in recent years. We need to conclude, because we need to start the recovery plan as soon as possible, after important actions in recent weeks too, I am thinking, for example, of the many billions from the SURE fund to support workers in difficulty, which my country, Italy, has also obtained. In such a difficult context as the one in which we live today, we need a stronger and more united Europe, without uncertainty.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, congratulations on your premiere in the presidency of this House. As always, the Council shines through its absence. Citizens, as well as businesses, need European aid to arrive as soon as possible so that they can move forward with their vital projects. Other than that, the political, economic but above all social consequences could be disastrous even for the stability of our democracies. In the face of the pandemic, the European Union has responded and reacted quickly and effectively, but the final stretch remains. The Commission and Parliament have done our job and now it is up to the Council to unlock the final pulse between the governments that want to move forward and the governments which want to block the agreement so as not to be forced to respect the rule of law. I tell the latter they've got the wrong club. The European Union has in its DNA respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law, and this Parliament will not take a step back. This crisis has also once again demonstrated the institutional difficulties that the Union has in responding to the great challenges. There can be no veto right on such an important issue. The time has come to launch the Conference on the Future of Europe and to change the rules of the game.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The idea of creating a reconstruction fund based on own resources and loans taken out jointly and severally by all Member States is an important step towards deepening European integration. It is a fact without precedent, but according to the principle that an emergency situation requires extraordinary action, it is fully understood. A compromise draft regulation linking EU funds to the rule of law means strengthening the values on which our Union is built. The mechanism of budgetary conditionality is not an attack on the sovereignty of any state. The membership of my country, Polish, in the Union is a guarantee of sovereignty, not a threat of loss of sovereignty. The conditionality mechanism is not aimed at the interests of the Member States, but at the policies of governments that act against the interests of their own citizens. I hope that in the further work all governments will retain responsibility, prove to be adults, and understand the compromise arrangements. This also applies to the Polish Government.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, the European Council is called upon to decide on two issues relating to the existence of the European Union itself. Firstly, in the budget and the Recovery Fund we do not accept, as the European Parliament that we represent with European citizens, a reduction in the rule of law, which is an integral part of our European principles and values. However, we will not accept a discount even to those Member States that want to link the state's public finances with the use of funding to deal with the effects of the pandemic.  On the problem of Turkey, as long as the European Council remains committed to the policy of appeasement, the human costs we will pay to get rid of the neo-Ottoman policies of the neo-Sultan in Ankara are piling up. We have also heard about terrorism, about the chief terrorist in Ankara, but we offer a positive agenda. It is a one-way street for the European Council: imposing economic sanctions and arms embargoes on Turkey now.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: – Madam President, denying reality today is something that even some European governments allow themselves to do. This reality today is climate change, and this reality is a scientifically proven threat to the whole world, but the most vulnerable are small and weak countries that alone cannot cope with the upheavals and consequences of global warming.  In Bulgaria we breathe the dirtiest air in Europe and together with Poland we are record-breakers in early mortality from respiratory diseases due to dirty air. The European Council must agree on the targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in December, despite attempts by some European governments to deny reality. And these self-forgotten autocrats can continue to do so, but they cannot take hostage the health, future of our children and the livelihoods of millions of European citizens. In this unprecedented crisis, it is the duty of every democratic institution, government and community to thwart and stop them.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, very few times in the long history of the European partnership has the European Council been so decisive. This is the last formal Council of the German Presidency on the bridge with the launch of the Portuguese Presidency and in it the future of the European Union is at stake and does not allow hesitation.  Can we hesitate to implement solidarity recovery funding? Can we hesitate in the democratic matrix of our partnership? Can we hesitate to preserve a constructive relationship with the United Kingdom? Can we hesitate on the priority of a multilateral and equal partnership with Africa? Can we hesitate to reinforce the Atlantic Axis, which has to be the aircraft carrier of our global positioning? Can we hesitate on the social agenda, on the digital climate agenda that reconnects citizens with the European project?  No, we can't.  The next European Council will not just be another European Council, it will be a Council that will be in history for success, half-inks or failure.  The world needs it to be a success.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report We face major challenges: climate change, the social divide in our society, fighting the COVID virus, reorganising economic and social development after the COVID crisis – and to do so we must act coherently and quickly. But two or two governments in our Member States are once again shearing out and threatening to veto it. Our answer to this must be very clear: Europe remains tough on the rule of law. Europe is not an ATM where the money for the destruction of the rule of law can simply be withdrawn. The European Union must not bow to blackmail from Warsaw and Budapest.  Who benefits most from the EU budget and the multiannual financial framework? It is Hungary, and it is Poland! The truth, however, is that Morawiecki and Orban are acting against the people of their countries. They are harming the Poles and poles, they are harming the Hungarians and Hungarians.  We remain firm and clear on the Rule of Law Mechanism, and we remain firm and clear on the medium-term financial framework and the Reconstruction Fund.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear colleagues! The December meeting of our leaders could be groundbreaking. In light of the epidemic and the weakness of the health systems of many countries, I expect them to focus largely on the project of building a health union. This would greatly facilitate the participation of members, increase the efficiency of care and, above all, ensure equal opportunities for citizens in tackling diseases. The treatment of Hungary and Poland with a blockade of the necessary, necessary money is irresponsible, is completely incomprehensible. At the moment, the Union does not need solo outbursts, and neither does some false saviors such as the Slovenian Prime Minister Janša. What we need is a clear signal to people that the Union is capable of recovering, starting the economy and returning society to a state of prosperite. Leaders who have interests beyond respect for accepted standards, values and the rule of law should leave their places to the better.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I should like first and foremost to thank Ms Metsola very much. I would also like to sincerely congratulate you on your the election as First Vice-President of the European Parliament. I would also like to thank all the honourable Members of the European Parliament for what was indeed a very rich debate. For the Commission it was very important to hear your positions on the key political priorities, on these key issues we have to resolve before the end of the year, and I have to say that your message was loud and clear. If you allow me I will start with your comments on Brexit, made by all leaders of the political groups and also by Mr McAllister, who plays such an important role in our discussions.  I think that, as the President said, we are clearly in the endgame. I would like to assure you that the Commission, Michel Barnier and myself, very much appreciate your support and also the clarity of your message and we are ready to be creative, but under no circumstances would we put into question the integrity of the European single market. And the same goes for the respect of the withdrawal agreement, which must be implemented as agreed and on time, and here I would say, Deal or No Deal. Peace and prosperity on the island of Ireland is of paramount importance and the respect for the Good Friday Agreement is absolute, and I really would like to assure of that Mr Kelleher who made this point very clearly. To respond to Ms Hübner in greater detail, I would like to tell her that if it comes to the withdrawal agreement we are also working around the clock on proper and timely implementation of this agreement. I’m glad that I can pass the good message to the 4.5 million citizens of the European Union in the United Kingdom concerning their residence rights, because here we are working very hard and I believe that for sure we will solve this issue. I am in frequent contact with Mr Gove. I would not hide that the negotiations are difficult, but I appreciate the constructive atmosphere and I hope that it will help us to adopt all the necessary decisions of the Joint Committee which are due before the end of the year.  Here again, we are also in the endgame and I’m looking for having the Joint Committee meeting in the next days and I really would like to use it as a decisive one to find a solution on all outstanding issues, especially on the proper implementation of the protocol on Ireland and Northern Ireland, and we are fully aware of the scrutiny requirements by this House, and by the Council. The Commission President told you this morning that we don’t know if we reach a deal with the United Kingdom or not, but I can assure you that we will do our maximum, our utmost, but we will not accept a deal at any price. The next days will be absolutely decisive and therefore I would like to underscore how much we appreciate the European Parliament’s readiness to hold an extraordinary session for proper assessment of the eventual deal. We will continue the close cooperation with you and with this House on this issue and we will respect to the fullest the transparency which was established in this process because we know that this is how we can earn your trust which is so important for all of us.  Many of you address the issue of multiannual financial perspective and the NextGenerationEU instrument, and I would say that an overwhelming majority of honourable Members, most of the leaders of the political groups, have been a very clear. In this unprecedented crisis we need the firepower, the novelty of this new financial structure to tackle the crisis, to restart the economy, to save lives and jobs, and to modernise our economies. I can assure you that for the European Commission, the rule of law is part of the deal and the European values are not negotiable. And I would like to assure you that the Commission will be working relentlessly with you, with the Council, with the German Presidency, to resolve the situation which is becoming very grave and to make sure that the European Union and our citizens will have the necessary financial means to perform our duties as of the beginning of the next year. Ms García Pérez, Mr Eickhout, Ms Van Brempt and Mr Picula referred to the importance of vaccination. I have to say that thanks to the advanced negotiations and prepayment to the pharmaceutical companies it’s very important to say that we will have enough doses of vaccines for all of the European Union citizens, and we are not thinking about them only because we make sure that we want to develop the mechanisms how the citizens of the world can benefit from this very important vaccine because only in that way would we be able to tackle finally the COVID-19 pandemic. If it comes to the vaccination we already asked the Member States to develop their vaccination strategies and we also issued a recommendation how we believe they should be developed for the orderly and fair process of the vaccination of our citizens. The next financial perspective and NextGenerationEU will have to focus on achieving our very ambitious Green Deal on our ambitious goals in the area of the digital agenda. Ms Keller, Ms Bonafè and Ms Cseh were actually highlighting the importance of the climate discussion and climate targets which have to be assessed and we believe positively decided upon by the leaders in the next European Council. Your calls for clarity is the same what we hear from investors, from business leaders, from our citizens, that we need the clear deal coming from the European Council meeting on climate goals to put into the higher gear our efforts to reach the ‘fit for 55’ agenda. The good news is that very soon we will have a strong ally in the United States in fighting climate change. The initial contacts of President-elect Biden with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, but also with other European leaders, and the track record of Mr Blinken, Mr Kerry, whom I know personally, is an absolute guarantee that the United States and the European Union will work hand-in-hand if it comes to the importance of tackling climate change. And to conclude, a quick response to Ms Loiseau and Mr Bellamy who raised the issue of counter-terrorism. On 9 December the Commission will present an EU agenda on counter-terrorism. It will set out the EU counter-terrorism strategy for the next four years, setting out new measures to better anticipate, prevent, protect and respond to the terrorist threat. It will include a strategic approach to respond more effectively and with innovative approaches to radicalisation. But we should also not forget that Member States need to implement the current framework and that it is high time to agree and adopt the proposal on terrorist content online.  In addition to that, in December, the Commission plans to adopt a revised mandate for Europol, as well as proposals on critical infrastructure and network information security. The Commission also included in the next year’s work programme a new agenda on counter-terrorism that will set out the new measures to counter radicalisation and terrorism.  Madam President, I really would like to thank all the honourable Members for a really very rich debate covering all the important topics which are on the European agenda. I very much appreciate the support, the clarity of the message and I really thank you for the floor.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The most relevant discussions were the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, climate change, counter-terrorism and violent extremism, situation in the Eastern Mediterranean and relations with Turkey, EU relations with Southern Neighbourhood countries, EU trade policy. Key themes for the Socialists are Brexit, negotiation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027 and own resources. In this regard, the Spanish delegation supports Parliament's position on the need for a legislative instrument linking the budget with the defence of the rule of law, and therefore requests that the Council confirm, without changing it, the agreement reached. The recovery fund negotiations are essential for us and we expect agreement as soon as possible. We also expect agreement on our future relationship with the UK, and we cannot give up a reliable and stable governance system, competition rules that protect our internal market and an agreement that guarantees the interests of our fisheries sector. And to manage the COVID situation we need to make progress in creating a health union and ensure a transparent plan for the purchase and distribution of vaccines.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: par écrit. – Dear Commissioner, Dear Minister, in April, Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen solemnly promised that a vaccine against Covid-19 would be universally good for us. That was important, because everyone, all over the world, deserves protection. So if there is an effective and safe vaccine, we're going to need huge amounts of it. This means that we cannot accept that one company should be given a monopoly right to do so. Because no company will be able to produce enough for everyone. Since then, however, you have been backing down. In June, you forgot to mention the promise in your Vaccine Strategy. You then limited your commitment to international initiatives that wanted to share health technologies worldwide. Then you replied to me that your April promise actually had no legal value and quickly bought up just about all the vaccine doses. Solidarity promises were just a laugh, in other words. Today you go one step further. Now that 100 countries, including India and South Africa, want to suspend patents and make the vaccine widely accessible, including in poorer countries, you are actively opposed to it. How dare you? This is about people's lives. Support that initiative from India and South Africa. Make the vaccine a global audience.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – During this debate, the European Parliament discusses the preparations for the European Council of 10-11 December 2020. There are many sublime words, references to lofty ideals, appeals for observance of the law. At the same time, contrary to the laws and treaties of the European Union, one is blackmailed and attempts to forcely impose one's own beliefs, its own systems of values, on other countries, especially Poland and Hungary. There are many wrong accusations against my country in this institution. Poland has been regularly attacked, most recently for lacking free access to abortion, which is known as a clear violation of the rule of law. At the same time, The Commissioner for Equality herself, Helena Dali, states during the DEBATE in the EP that: "The EU has no competence with regard to the right to abortion in a Member State. The legal provisions in this area are the responsibility of the Member State concerned." Nevertheless, it calls in this House for the budget to be linked to the alleged violation of the rule of law, without any legal basis. Thousands of people around the world are fighting for their health and lives, others are fighting to survive against the economic effects of the COVID-19 virus. We should focus on this real threat. Health, restoring economic stability, building security mechanisms - these are the challenges that we should focus on both now and at the next European Council.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – Next month's European Council will discuss important issues for the EU, such as the COVID-19 pandemic and the fight against climate change. It is essential that this Council be assertive in its decisions and in its responses to citizens.  As regards COVID-19, it is essential that there is a robust response by strengthening pandemic coordination, but above all a decision on economic responses and financial mechanisms for European citizens, both by the Multiannual Financial Framework 21-27 and by the Recovery Plan - Next Generation EU.  There is an urgent need for a compromise between the European Council and European citizens. In this sense, the interests of the parties, in particular, the most vulnerable regions, such as the Outermost Regions, which, more than ever, need a recovery of their economy, safeguarding jobs and supporting key and strategic sectors that have been severely affected by the pandemic should be safeguarded.  Decisive action on climate change must be a reality and the focus on the ecological transition that should not leave anyone behind.
