Special attention is needed to the populations in the transition process and, in particular, I warn of the vulnerability of the ORs.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – On 26 November 2020, for the first time, the European Parliament, with the universal support of the college, demanded that strict sanctions be taken against Turkey for its delinquent behaviour. At the same time, the resolution strengthens the laws of Cyprus and Greece in the face of Turkey's aggressive behaviour. We call on the European Council to take action and impose severe sanctions against Turkey for its illegal actions in Famagusta and for its general, provocative aggression. It is time for the EU to prove that it does not tolerate Turkey's criminal actions against Cyprus, Greece and Armenia. How many other crimes will the European Union tolerate to finally impose sanctions on Turkey?

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: Writing. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. The fight against COVID-19, climate change and security will be the main topics of the meeting of EU leaders, which will take place on 10 and 11 December. It is clear that the fight against the Corona pandemic is still a top priority. Several Covid-19 vaccine trials are currently in their advanced stages, so it is time to discuss their production and distribution. It is also very important that future vaccinations are accepted by the population, that people are convinced of their effectiveness. There is currently no lack of disinformation regarding the coronavirus. There are a lot of people who spread scientifically unproven anti-vaccination rumors. Such claims fuel fears and harm public health. That is why it is very important that all misinformation and conspiracy theories are effectively combated. We need to convince EU citizens that they only get information from reliable sources and up-to-date.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: in writing. – The European Council on 10 and 11 December will be key to defining the political, economic and strategic horizon of the European Union. At the moment we are confronted not only with a pandemic, with human, social and economic costs that we do not yet know in full, but also by an institutional blockade that prevents us from acting in a timely and appropriate action. The recovery package, which includes key resources for our recovery and to trigger an inclusive ecological and digital transition, continues to face the resistance of two governments, Hungary and Poland. It is regrettable to note that its undemocratic approach remains, just as they are willing to protect it at any cost: in this case, with damage to all European citizens, including their own countries. I support the determination of policymakers who are working to honour the agreement reached in July and to ensure that this process is completed by the end of 2020.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – Dear colleagues, I underline the urgency to find a general agreement in the Council regarding the adoption of the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 and Next Generation EU in order to enable Member States to access EU’s historic budget of €1.8 trillion from 1 January 2021. European taxpayers, our citizens, already expressed their firm support to link EU funds to respect for rule-of-law and it is extremely difficult to understand how anyone can oppose that. Rule of law is one of the fundamental values upon which the EU is based on. It guarantees fundamental rights and values, allows the application of EU law, and supports an investment-friendly business environment and predictability. Under the rule of law, all public authorities act within the constraints set out by law, in accordance with the values of democracy and fundamental rights, and under the control of independent and impartial courts. Accordingly, I urge governments currently opposing the link of EU funds to rule-of-law to listen to the people, enhance public trust, and allow the finalization and adoption of EU budget, crucial to overcome current socio-economic crisis and provide rapid solutions to millions of Europeans counting on our help.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The European Council has a duty to provide a quick solution for the implementation of the future budget and the European economic recovery plan. We can't afford to miss this moment. The European economy and society cannot be held in place by the inability of national political leaders to meet their commitments to citizens and the European Parliament. The European right today is blocking Europe. The European right must explain to us why they are holding us all hostage to an anti-European policy. The explanations given by right-wing political leaders cannot justify the position taken. The European left has initiated the idea of the European economic recovery plan, and we are also the ones today who support an ambitious European budget for Europe. Romania will benefit from the nearly EUR 80 billion provided for in the European budgetary structure thanks to our efforts. Solidarity is needed at European level to emerge from this crisis, but we all need to go in the same direction, for sustainable and modern development. What will happen at the future European Council depends on how Europe looks in the future and how it will emerge from this crisis.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – The most relevant discussions were the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, climate change, counter-terrorism and violent extremism, situation in the Eastern Mediterranean and relations with Turkey, EU relations with Southern Neighbourhood countries, EU trade policy. Key themes for the Socialists are Brexit, negotiation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027 and own resources. In this regard, the Spanish delegation supports Parliament's position on the need for a legislative instrument linking the budget with the defence of the rule of law, and therefore requests that the Council confirm, without changing it, the agreement reached. The recovery fund negotiations are essential for us and we expect agreement as soon as possible. We also expect agreement on our future relationship with the UK, and we cannot give up a reliable and stable governance system, competition rules that protect our internal market and an agreement that guarantees the interests of our fisheries sector. And to manage the COVID situation we need to make progress in creating a health union and ensure a transparent plan for the purchase and distribution of vaccines.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialist Delegation supported Parliament's position on the need for a legislative instrument linking access to European funds with the defence of the rule of law, and therefore requested that the Council confirm, without modification, the agreement reached on 10 November 2020. It should be noted that, if Hungary and Poland's veto persisted, it would be possible to approve the Qualified Majority Recovery Plan on the basis of Article 122 TFEU and with the support of additional national guarantees. On the other hand, the recovery and resilience instrument and the 2021 budget could also be adopted by a qualified majority in accordance with Article 310.4 TFEU. With regard to Brexit, we expect an agreement in which we cannot renounce a reliable and stable governance system, competition rules that protect our internal market between the two sides and an agreement that guarantees the interests of our fisheries sector. With regard to the Covid-19 pandemic, we need to make progress in creating a European Health Union and ensure a transparent plan for the purchase and distribution of vaccines.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: in writing. – The most relevant discussions were the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, climate change, counter-terrorism and violent extremism, situation in the Eastern Mediterranean and relations with Turkey, EU relations with Southern Neighbourhood countries, EU trade policy. Key themes for the Socialists are Brexit, negotiation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027 and own resources. In this regard, the Spanish delegation supports Parliament's position on the need for a legislative instrument linking the budget with the defence of the rule of law, and therefore requests that the Council confirm, without changing it, the agreement reached. The recovery fund negotiations are essential for us and we expect agreement as soon as possible. We also expect agreement on our future relationship with the UK, and we cannot give up a reliable and stable governance system, competition rules that protect our internal market and an agreement that guarantees the interests of our fisheries sector. And to manage the COVID situation we need to make progress in creating a health union and ensure a transparent plan for the purchase and distribution of vaccines.

name: Christine SCHNEIDER
text: Writing. – Hungary and Poland's veto of the EU budget package is irresponsible towards the southern states, which desperately need the money to alleviate the Corona crisis. I believe that the rule of law mechanism is the right instrument to protect the European budget from abuse, fraud and corruption. I hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council soon and that we will be able to release the necessary funds to combat the crisis as soon as possible.

name: Mihai TUDOSE
text: in writing. – It is inadmissible to blackmail Hungary and Poland, which veto the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Plan to relaunch the EU economy, opposing the conditionality of European funds on respect for the rule of law. EU citizens are being steps on by urgent support in the face of the pandemic crisis, because of these governments with dangerous anti-European orientation. It has come to the situation where the mayors of Budapest and Warsaw are demanding direct access by municipalities to European funding in order to avoid harmful isolation. The European Parliament has categorically stated its decision not to give in to this blackmail. We will not accept any compromise that would jeopardise the European budget by possible violations of the rule of law. I therefore call on the Council to find ways at the 'Last Chance' Summit on 10-11 December, without concessions at a fundamental point for European unity based on the rule of law and democratic norms. Ultimately, there is the option of adopting the recovery package through enhanced cooperation between the other 25 Member States. It would, however, mean that Hungarians and Poles would suffer because of the obtuseness of their own governance. There is also the option of saving the Relaunch Plan, as exceptional financial assistance, under Articles 122 and 310 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – How much is the rule of law worth to you or to your country's honourable Fellow Members of the European Parliament? As a Hungarian patriot and a social democrat, I believe that neither the country nor the rule of law is for sale! I hope you feel the same way. We are now at a historic crossroads: whether we will give in to political mobsters blackmailing the Union with an affordable deal or not get into this dirty fight. It is a shame that today's Hungary, the illiberal mafia state of Orban, would no longer be included in this European club. It is a shame that the people's party community of the founding fathers is still cowardly assisting in the illiberal rampage and it will be a historic crime if the Heads of State or Government stab the European Parliament, which is representing the will of nearly 450 million European citizens, and finally make a deal with the mobsters. It's a visceral law not to negotiate with political hostage takers.  I wonder how much Angela Merkel's support for Orban in the German car industry is worth, or whether it is another chunky and unnecessary Hungarian military order. It is worth it for the independence of the Hungarian judiciary to be eroded; that the public media can demonstrably lie to political control and gradually abolish the rule of law? According to Fidesz, the issue of the current veto is the struggle between Central and Eastern Europe and the West. I think it's a battle of common sense, European decency and petty mafia bosses. Decide which side you are on and, accordingly, look for a way out of the veto crisis.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Il-punt li jmiss fuq l-ażenda huwa d-dibattitu dwar id-dikjarazzjoni tal-Kummissjoni dwar il-Konvenzjoni ta' Istanbul u l-vjolenza kontra n-nisa (2020/2875(RSP)). Nixtieq ninforma lill-Members li dan id-debates huwa expected b'dawra waťda ta' kelliema tal-gruppi politièi, u li gťad-dibattiti kollha ta' din is-sessjoni parzjali mhux ser ikun hemm pro-"catch-the-eye" u mhux ser ikunu aèettati l-karti blu. Barra minn hekk ukoll, hemm planned remote interventions mill-Uffièji ta' Kollegament tal-Parlament fl-Istati Members.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Membru tal-Kummissjoni. – Nibda biex nawguralek xogħol tajjeb għal din il-kariga l-ġdida. Many things have happened since I last addressed this House on the Istanbul Convention and violence against women. Since March, the world has changed. The number of cases of gender-based violence, violence against women and, in particular, domestic violence, has been on the rise. This is what we know because, as we know, this is one of the most under-reported crimes.  The strict confinement that many of us have been experiencing led to heightened exposure of women and children to domestic violence and abuse.  Home is not a safe space for everyone, especially not during lockdown. Anyone can experience domestic and intimate partner violence, but the majority of victims are women, and children, by witnessing violence, are being targeted directly.  This trend is extremely worrying, in particular as a second wave of confinement rules has been introduced in many countries. We must do all that we can to prevent domestic violence, protect its victims and punish offenders. We have taken a commitment in the EU Gender Equality Strategy, concluding that the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention is a key priority for the Commission since the Convention is the benchmark for international legislation on tackling gender-based violence.  As requested by the Parliament, the European Court of Justice is currently assessing the compatibility with the EU treaties of the Council signing decision and adoption procedure. The Court’s Opinion will be delivered in the second quarter of 2021. Should the EU’s accession subsequently remain blocked, the Commission will propose, in 2021, a legal initiative to prevent and combat violence against women in order to reach the same objectives as the Istanbul Convention. But we also need to act quickly to ensure a high level of protection and adequate specialised support services across Europe. Women should not be afraid to report cases of violence, nor should there be a fear of revictimisation. We must also counter the rising trend and prevent violence from happening. Last week, on the initiative of the German Presidency, the 27 EU Ministers for Gender Equality reiterated their strong commitment and support in strengthening and improving actions on combating gender-based violence and violence against women.  I am encouraged by these developments as the Commission shares the Ministers’ determination to prevent and combat gender-based violence. We will also need your strong support for our legal proposal on violence against women. As co-legislator, you will have a key role in making this happen. Additionally, as announced in our different equality strategies, we will present an initiative to extend the list of Euro crimes to hate speech and hate crime.  I am also here to call for your support to defend our common values. Gender equality is a core value of the European Union and a principle we will keep fighting for. I will continue to stress that the Istanbul Convention is the gold standard in terms of policy in this area and I will continue to facilitate a better understanding of its aim and provisions. The European Parliament has consistently taken a strong stance on the issue of violence against women, and has repeatedly called for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention and for its ratification by individual Member States. I count on your continuous support for the work ahead of us.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, every third woman or girl in the EU has experienced physical or sexual violence in her life. Every day, women in Europe are murdered because of the violence they suffer from their partner. COVID—19 has put many people in a very difficult situation. It has also become a dangerous outcome for those women who are being trapped in their violent relationships during lockdown. Across Europe, violence in close relationships has increased dramatically during this crisis, and we must increase our forces to put an end to this now. The Istanbul Convention is the first binding international instrument on preventing and combating violence against women. It’s a strong and necessary tool for protecting women from all types of violence, but unfortunately the Convention and the fight against violence against women is under attack by a great deal of unfair disinformation. Some say, ‘Oh, the Convention supports destructive gender ideology’; others say, ‘Oh, the Convention will introduce a third sex’; some more say, ‘Oh, but we don’t need this Convention, we already have legislation’. But this is untrue, this is false, and these are myths, because even in my own country, Sweden – which is considered to be at the forefront when it comes to gender equality – violence against women is a serious problem and the Istanbul Convention is a very important tool for national and local legislation and the judiciary. So it has a big impact in combating these kinds of crimes. The Istanbul Convention is about guaranteeing fundamental human rights also for women, and the perpetrators that are beating, abusing or killing their partners must be put behind bars. How can one even be against that? I don’t understand. This is why ratifying this Convention is so important. The victims of violence have no time for more excuses. As legislators we must do all we can to protect victims and to end the increasing violence now. We have the responsibility to fight for women’s rights, for their freedom, for their safety, the basic right not to be beaten, not to be raped, not to be murdered. An important step towards this is that every EU Member State and the EU itself should ratify the Istanbul Convention and that violence against women should be an EU crime. As rapporteur, I will not stop until this fight is achieved, and we must do more than we have done up to now.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Commissioner, someone in this House or outside may be led to believe that this day, this debate, is only about women, but that is not the case. Because this day, the celebration of the fight against this immense crime against humanity, concerns all of us, concerns all of you, it concerns above all men. Because it is men who carry out the violence, it is the men who have often been complicit in the name of an alleged, prevalent sexist culture, but it is only with them that we can work to ensure that it never happens again. So each of us, as we know, Commissioner, either directly or indirectly knows or has suffered violence. If you think about it, that is the thing that unites us the most: we do not share our rights, because huge differences remain and persist between the various women between country and country and between women and men; we do not have freedoms in common, because there are unbridgeable differences between women from different countries. Instead, we have the condition of being victims of violence and then being, later, criminalized or judged for this, to the cry of "I have sought it", as is always the case. So I want to address myself, Commissioner, especially to those who are the actual or potential perpetrators of this tragedy, which has spanned the whole history of humanity, which has crossed all cultures and latitudes, and I want to say to people: 'Enough!' I want to say enough to them, let us take together that step that separates barbarism from civilisation. Finally, Commissioner, I would like to say: let us hire ourselves in this House, let us make every death, every bruise, every tear pay, every violence inflicted on women as if it were, yes, a common debt collected by all humanity.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, indeed, violence against women is one of the most serious violations of women's human rights, freedom and dignity; crosses borders, crosses continents, also crosses economic and social levels.  Silence has been over the centuries the greatest accomplice of violence against women and girls. That is why silence and isolation from confinement have caused violence against women to have increased. Some data tell us that complaints have declined, that court proceedings and protective orders have declined, but violence has increased, because phone calls to victims' special phones have increased. The women and girls in their homes, together with their aggressor, have called and whispered to us to help them. That is why today, this 25 November, I think it is important that the victims get a very clear message: the European Parliament, the European Union is with them, they are not alone. And, as we are with them, from this Parliament we demand, once again, the Member States which have not ratified the Istanbul Convention, to do so: Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic and Hungary, ratify already!. And, to Poland, we say that it cannot withdraw from the one Convention, the only international legal instrument we have to combat gender-based violence, because it is the heart of the rule of law, which is precisely where the fundamental rights of victims are located. That is why, Commissioner, I have every support to move forward, so that we can effectively fully protect victims with a directive on gender-based violence and including violence in European crimes set out in the Treaties. Finally, I want the victims who are listening to us to know that this European Parliament is always with them, alongside the victims and in front of the aggressors, and also in front of those who protect them and justify, to this day, this horrendous crime.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today is World Day against Violence against Women and I want to be clear: for a certain political part, the protection of women begins and ends with gender language and pink quotas – we are not pandas to be protected – without taking any account of merit and commitment. This is not the way to combat violence and abuse. Words are no longer enough to counter the subjugation of women, the one that takes place with infibulation and with the obligatory Islamic veil, all things for which, all too often, that same political party is silent. Words are no longer enough to denounce ridiculous punishments for rape in too many countries. We need more tools to report, we need more certainty than punishment. In short, in a nutshell, I would say, less pro-80s feminist propaganda and more facts.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, today, on behalf of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to express solidarity with women experiencing violence. Our duty is to stand up for women.  Violence against women is a violation of fundamental human rights. It is the most drastic form of gender-based discrimination. Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. We create smart cities, produce autonomous cars, we fly into space, but at the same time there are women in Europe who cannot feel safe in their own homes. They live in fear, they fear for their health and life. Many women do not report violence to the police. They are ashamed. They do not trust the state. They hear that these are family matters. The time of COVID-19 is special. The scale of domestic violence has increased. There are still countries in the European Union that call the fight for women’s rights an ideology. They use tradition, religion and protection of family as an excuse. There are countries in the European Union that have still not ratified the Convention. We have countries that want to denounce the Convention.  A year ago, we gave the Commission a clear signal. We called on the Commission to include violence against women in the catalogue of EU-recognised crimes. A year ago, we called for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention but 12 months have passed and nothing has happened. We jointly criticised governments that ignore the European Parliament’s resolutions, but sometimes the Commission does the same thing: it ignores European Parliament resolutions. Dear colleagues, let me remind you that the President-elect of the European Commission promised us all of this over a year ago in Strasbourg. While it turned up with nice words, how long will women in the European Union wait for equality, safety and the right to dignity? We want just one thing from Madam President Ursula von der Leyen: please keep your promises. It’s about fundamental rights. It’s about the health and life of millions of women.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, instead of the Istanbul Convention it should be called the Trojan Convention, because it is like the attractive Trojan horse, but it comes to invade our judicial systems. Following the very important intention of protecting victims of domestic violence, it introduces the concept of the gender perspective. It literally says that "the structural nature of violence against women is gender-based." I mean, the woman's a victim because she's a woman. And, therefore, that man for being a man is a mistreater. This conditions permanent suspicion against man. But the man does not rape, he does it a rapist; man does not kill, kills a murderer; man does not mistreat, he does it a mistreater; man does not humiliate, humiliates a coward. This only confronts men and women and also destroys the fundamental right of equality and non-discrimination. Attacking this foundation ends our judicial systems, as has happened in Spain, where an unfair law of gender-based violence has stripped the male of another fundamental right such as the presumption of innocence, determining in advance his guilt. It has also given women a supremacy that has rarefied relationships in our environment, blurring what is criminal and what is not. For example, today it is a crime to say a compliment. As you can see, it's a poisoned gift that doesn't help victims of violence and does break our society. Don't be fooled. Ask yourself, ladies and gentlemen, whether this instrument has solved violence against women. No, right? Because it is not a question of ratifying covenants but of strengthening the values that were the foundation of this house.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, look away from insistent glances, pretend to ignore a 'you're good, you know', be followed, hasten the pace, pretend to call, change sidewalks. We have all learned to grow with his reflexes of self-defense, the only answers that our patriarchal society has given us. But do you really know how we feel? Today, I want to tell you our rage, that of women who can no longer suffer violence from the streets to our homes, in public space or intimacy, including here in the European Parliament. Suffer macho remarks, walking hands and be silent for fear of losing his job. Feeling a body you do not want, being considered a vulgar object, being forced, raped, sometimes by a stranger, but much more often by a spouse, father or friend. And to suffer in his flesh the violence of a sex that one does not want. Feeling dirty, humiliated and still being silent for fear of not being believed, ashamed, feeling guilty: double punishment. And like so many women, hear from the one who was chosen first criticisms, then insults, ever more frequent, and then the first slaps, isolation, stigmas on the body, suffocated, paralyzed with fear, pain, not being able to flee, see death approach, the beatings more and more violent to those who kill. These femicides, all too often described by the media as a crime of passion. Life torn away for the mere fact of being a woman. Since January, 86 of them in France have been killed at the hands of their spouses or ex-spouses, and even more in the whole of the European Union. They're our mothers, our sisters, our friends. I would like their name to resonate loudly in this Chamber, even if, for that, Madam President, I must exceed my speaking time and be interrupted. If neither our testimonies nor our rage inspire you to act, then I hope that this morbid count of those lives that we should have saved will compel you to do so. Raymonde, 84; Anne-Sophie, 48; Laetitia, 31 years old; Valerie, 48, Jeanine, 89; Valerie; Dina; Pascaline, 60; Melanie, 35; Jacqueline, 23; Georgette, 88; Brigitte, 67; Therese, 80; Veronique, 50; Aïssatou; Gwenaelle, 34; Marie-Amélie, 53; Andrée, 81; Claudette; Virginia, 41; Sylvie, 50; Magdalena, 33; Florence, 50; Jennifer, 35; Sylvie, 45; Marguerite, 90; Salma, 21; Grace, 21 years old; Séverine, 31; Lisiane; Olivia; Sabrina, 21; Anne, 83; Sélène, 55; Marcelle, 84; Brigitte, 68; Fatiha, 52; Karina; Dialine; Bettina, 53; Barbara, 47; Myriam, 37; Emmanuelle, 41; Madalina, 40; Linda, 37; Tiffany, 23; Monica, 51; Genevieve, 42; Joelle, 50; Simone, 76; Deborah; Virginia, 45; Celine, 38; Laure, 52; Hanane, 37; Manon, 19; Lola, 29; Korotoume, 30; Natacha, 43; Sylvina, 51; Brigitte, 59; Aurora, 49; Khaddija, 48; Alexandra, 30; Stephanie, 43; Aurélie, 43; Franciele, 29; Christine, 58; Karine, 51; Anonymous; Nirojini; Anonymous; Anonymous; Valerie; Melissa; Anonymous; Maelys; Anonymous; Sonia, 47; Camille; Anonymous; Anonymous; Sandy, 33; France, 56; Lucette, 78.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Minkejja li mort lil hinn mill-ħin, jiena xtaqt li nagħtik dan il-ħin għaliex nifhem il-gravità tas-sitwazzjoni u l-konverżazzjoni li aħna qed ikollna. Ngħaddi issa l-kelma biex tagħlaq din id-discusjoni l-Gumssarju Helena Dalli.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Manon Aubry for this. Certainly even one death is one death too many. This goes to show how much more we still have to do in order to eradicate this scourge from all our societies. No society is free from the scourge of violence against women. Again, I reiterate my thanks for your support for everything we are attempting to do to combat this reality. As Pina Picierno rightly pointed out, this is barbarism versus civilisation. She put it exactly as it is because what you have demonstrated, Manon, is barbarism. It’s not civilisation. As Pina also pointed out, this is about men. When we speak among ourselves here, among women, we are speaking to the converted. We all know what the problem is. Some of us are victims. So it would have been good had we had some male speakers during this session, but I am sure that they are listening and I am sure that there are many men – I know many men – who want to fight this. But, as I said, it would have been good had they been vocal about it in this particular session. And, yes, as María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos put it, silence is complicity. So at no point must we stop working on this reality. Sylwia Spurek, I said that we are working on the ratification and simultaneously we are working on legislation. As you know, we are committed to this and this is in our Gender Equality Strategy, which we presented last March. So of course we are committed to this and we shall keep our promise, but obviously we also need your support.  Again, as Manon Aubry said, gender-based violence is not only about being physically beaten by your partner. There are many other forms of violence which some women don’t even realise, like the examples you mentioned –this is violence against you. There could be psychological violence, there could be financial violence and there could be other things, which the Me Too movement has highlighted and worked upon. The world started to realise then that many things happen in life to women and that women don’t speak up. Until they did speak up, which is a good thing, but of course there’s so much that we have to do in this area of policy.  We are committed. We will keep our promise. We have been saying how this year has been a challenging year, especially for women facing violence. I therefore count on this Parliament’s support to put in place an instrument that helps prevent violence against women and domestic violence, protects victims and prosecutes perpetrators. There is no time, nor any excuse, to roll back on gender equality and on women’s rights.  I thank you again for your participation in this debate today and I thank you heartily for your support. I know that you are with us on this and we shall continue fighting until we don’t come here to this Parliament with lists of women who have been killed in these situations.  (Applause)

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: in writing. – On the 25th of November 2020, the European Parliament honoured the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Violence can never be tolerated in a society based on Judeo-Christian principles. As of today, the most spoken of instrument adopted by the Council of Europe to eradicate this phenomenon, on behalf of Nations, is the Istanbul Convention. Interestingly, and apart from the little pinches of “gender” ideology proposed by article 3/b of the Convention, studies are showing that it falls short of attaining its goals. For instance: Just in Sweden, the National Council on Crime Prevention reported that the number of people killed in domestic violence doubled between 2017 and 2018. Belgian Interior Minister Pieter De Crem also denounced an increase in domestic violence during the same period, in other words before victims were locked in with their abusive partners because of confinement measures. Sweden and Belgium have ratified the Istanbul Convention, as well as Turkey, the country where it was adopted and where the rate of femicide is skyrocketting! This makes me want to ask you the following question: is there really an added value to this instrument?

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Dear President, Commissioner, colleagues, the Is istanbul Convention is so far the only real instrument that, once properly implemented, would make significant progress in protecting women and girls from violence. The problem of violence against women has always been particularly acute, but it has become even more relevant during the pandemic. We are constantly hearing about cases of violence against women who have been forced to live with perpetrators during this long quarantine period. Not all Member States have been able to ensure that women who are subject to violence have access to safe havens and residences where they are safe. This concerns not only women, but also children who are subjected to physical or psychological violence, causing enormous and often irreversible harm . We are very pleased with the EP's initiative to provide its own premises for women who are victims of violence. In this way, we have sent a clear message that protecting women from violence is a European priority. To date, it is difficult to comprehend that some Member States have not ratified the Is istanbul Convention . We very much expect decisive action from the Commission to persuade the Member States to ratify this Convention as soon as possible, so that we can effectively protect women, girls and children from violence and ensure their safety.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. The pandemic has exacerbated pre-existing inequalities, including gender inequality, with women most at risk of suffering the serious economic and social effects of the crisis. Furthermore, domestic and gender-based crimes have grown dramatically: the United Nations has called this increase a real shadow pandemic, to which Europe is far from immune. The International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women therefore takes on further significance this year, making legislative, social and cultural actions and instruments even more urgent, truly capable of putting an end to such a serious violation of fundamental human rights. We must therefore strongly reiterate our call for the EU to conclude the accession procedure to the Istanbul Convention and for the Member States, which have not yet done so, to ratify it. The Convention is, in fact, the first instrument, at European level, to introduce binding measures specifically dedicated to the prevention of gender-based and domestic violence, the protection of victims, and the punishability of the perpetrators of these crimes. Full EU accession to the Convention would ensure a more coherent regulatory framework, strengthen support and assistance to victims, and improve data collection, which is an essential prerequisite in the fight against a phenomenon that is still too underestimated.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the Istanbul Convention does not protect women from domestic violence, it is a platform for imposing the new ideology according to which gender is not a biological characteristic, but a social one. For me, there are only two sexes - male and female. In no way can I agree that there is a third, fifth or tenth sex and that these are social constructs. Our children need to know what is normal and what the real roles of a man and a woman are, that the family is from a man and a woman. The Istanbul Convention is a Trojan Horse that, under the mask of the fight against violence against women, pushes dangerous feminist ideas. The Convention does not help victims of violence, but attacks our traditions, values and beliefs about family and the relationship between a man and a woman. Countries that do not want to ratify it should not be condemned or pressured to accept it. There is a decision of the Constitutional Court in Bulgaria declaring that the Convention is contrary to our Constitution and I believe that Europe must respect this decision.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – Despite the progress made in recent decades, gender-based violence remains one of the most notable human rights violations in the European Union. According to the latest studies, one in three women in the European Union has been the victim of this type of violence. The existence of this phenomenon, which has gender inequality at its core, is inadmissible in today's society. That is why the European Union marks this challenge as a priority, establishing that it will do everything possible to combat this phenomenon and to protect its victims. The Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Fight against Violence against Women ('the Istanbul Convention') is the first legally binding international instrument on the prevention and fight against violence against women and girls at the international level. This Convention will finally enable an integrated European framework, ensuring a common and coordinated approach in this area. Gender-based violence is a phenomenon with which zero tolerance must be taken. We must support any initiative that promotes its eradication, such as the Istanbul Convention.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialist Delegation in the European Parliament considered that it was a necessity for ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the six countries that had not yet done so (Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and Slovakia), as well as its effective implementation by all EU Member States. The Delegation supported the Commission's unremanidated statement, coinciding with the International Day for the Elimination of Gender Violence, since the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Fight against Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, the Istanbul Convention, was the international reference. According to the Fundamental Rights Agency survey (2014), 1 in 3 EU women have experienced physical and/or sexual violence since the age of 15. 55% of women have faced one or more forms of sexual harassment and 1 in 20 have been raped. Confinements have resulted in an increase in cases of gender-based violence.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialist Delegation in the European Parliament considered that it was a necessity for ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the six countries that had not yet done so (Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and Slovakia), as well as its effective implementation by all EU Member States. The Delegation supported the Commission's unremanidated statement, coinciding with the International Day for the Elimination of Gender Violence, since the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Fight against Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, the Istanbul Convention, was the international reference. According to the Fundamental Rights Agency survey (2014), 1 in 3 EU women have experienced physical and/or sexual violence since the age of 15. 55% of women have faced one or more forms of sexual harassment and 1 in 20 have been raped. Confinements have resulted in an increase in cases of gender-based violence.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: in writing. – Ending violence against women means that we fight with all possible instruments and strong legislation for the right of every woman and girl to live a life free of violence. When I say we, I mean we all, together, at all levels, in all spheres of society, together. Every single EU Member State must make sure that laws are implemented to insure the protection and assistance victims require. The Istanbul Convention is one instrument among others. It is politically driven with the introduction of the gender ideology and in many cases sets lesser standards than the legal instruments already existing. Furthermore, the Istanbul Convention does not guarantee the end of violence against women. It is decisive governmental action that makes the difference and that is the case in Hungary. Numbers speak for themselves and each day we see the situation improve without ratifying the convention. Equality is an essential principle enshrined in our European values and we all must ensure this becomes a reality for all our citizens, men and women, boys and girls. We need targeted actions that address the roots problems and adapt to the reality in Member States, and address the associated problems such as poverty and exclusion.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – The Istanbul Convention constitutes an essential legal basis for the protection of women against violence and questioning this major treaty, or slowing down its ratification, is a worrying alert and a serious setback for women's rights. We have constantly called on the national, local and regional authorities to set up awareness-raising, prevention and protection mechanisms to put an end to violence against women. We must remain at the forefront of the fight against domestic violence. It concerns all of us. It is not a private matter, but a public matter. That is why we call on the Member States to do their utmost to guarantee women's rights within the framework of the Istanbul Convention. Many Governments are concentrating on health measures aimed at combating the COVID pandemic while ignoring the safety of women. The quarantine has isolated victims from their support networks, making it difficult for victims to get immediate help / justice or escape from the abusive situation. The Member States must ensure that women have a right to live a life free from violence, including at home, and action must be taken to ensure that essential services are in place, and able to function, even in times of crisis.

name: Guido REIL
text: Writing. – On the issue of increasing violence against women, certain taboos are to be broken. The increase in violence against women in Europe is mainly linked to immigration from certain countries of origin and regions. For example, a study by the Federal Criminal Police Office in November 2019 on partnership violence pointed out that in the categories of murder, manslaughter, sexual assault, rape, pimping and forced prostitution, the proportion of non-German perpetrators is significantly higher than the proportion of foreigners in the total population of Germany. Immigration is confronting us with an image of women that has nothing to do with equal treatment and non-violent relationships. Researchers in Beirut pointed to the link between violence against women and societal factors such as the lack of political and economic participation of women, discriminatory legal systems and impunity for violence against women and girls. In some Middle Eastern countries, 70 percent of women are victims of sexual violence. In this way, social progress becomes impossible. A 2019 survey conducted by the Ministry of Social Affairs in Morocco found that about 54 percent of all women experience violence. As I said, immigration from these countries and regions inevitably leads to increasing violence against women in Europe.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Qabel il-ftuť tal-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni tal-lum nixtieq nagťti l-kelma lis-Sur Markus Ferber skont l-Artikolu 59(4) dwar ir-reference lura lill-Kumitat gťal Negozjati Interistituzzjonjon rigward ir-rapport tiegťu dwar l-emenda tad-Directive 2014/65/UE fir-rigward tar-rekwiżiti ta' informazzjoni, il-governanza tal-prodotti u l-limiti ta' pożizzjoni gťall-irkupru mill-pandemicja tal-COVID-19.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her You have already anticipated everything. In accordance with the Rules of Procedure, I request that my report be referred back to committee so that we can enter into interinstitutional negotiations as quickly as possible.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Sur Ferber, it-talba tiegťek se titressaq gťall-votazzjoni wara l-votazzjoni dwar il-proposta tal-Kummissjoni. Issa se niftať l-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni tal-lum. Se nivvotaw dwar il-fajls kif indikat fuq l-aťenda. Is-sessjoni ta' votazzjoni se tkun miftuťa minn issa, is-13.00, sas-14.15. Se jintuża l-istess metodu ta' votazzjoni użat matul l-aťťar sessjonijiet parzjali. Il-votazzjonijiet kollha se jsiru b'sejťa tal-ismijiet. Niddikjara l-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni miftuťa. Gťandkom sas-14.15 biex tivvotaw u r-riżultati ta' din l-ewwel sessoni ta' votazzjoni se jitťabbru fil-16.45. (Σin li fih żiet sospiża s-session: 13.02)

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The next item is the debate on the Declarations of the Council and the Commission on Hungary's interference in the media in Slovenia and Northern Macedonia (2020/2840(RSP)). I remind you that in all the debates of this part-session, there will be no catch-the-eye procedures or blue card questions.  Interventions are made from our Liaison Offices in the Member States.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for including this topic on the plenary agenda. The Commission attaches great importance to freedom of expression, media pluralism and freedom of the media in the EU Member States as well as in the EU candidate countries and potential candidates. Free and pluralistic media is essential to democracy. It helps citizens hold to account those in power and allow them to make informed electoral choices and fend off disinformation and attempts to manipulate the democratic debate and interfere in elections. It also helps ensure that a plurality of views can be expressed and heard in the democratic debate. This is why the Commission will include measures to strengthen media freedom and pluralism in the upcoming European democracy action plan, alongside measures targeted to fighting disinformation and ensure free and fair elections.  While the measures presented in the action plan will in a large proportion address threats to democracy in the EU, the plan will also have a strong international dimension. The Commission already supports media freedom and pluralism through a variety of initiatives within the scope of its competences. The media pluralism monitor, drawn up by the independent Centre for Media Pluralism and Media Freedom and co-financed by the Commission, examines threats and risks to media pluralism in the EU and selected candidate countries and potential candidates. Media freedom and pluralism is also part of the Commission’s annual rule of law report. The 2020 report adopted in September covers all 27 Member States, including Hungary and Slovenia. The report examines a number of issues relevant for media freedom and pluralism, including transparency of media ownership, state advertising and political control of the media.  Concerning North Macedonia, the Commission and the EU delegation are following the developments in the media sector in the country very closely. The Commission reports on these issues in its regular enlargement packages, including in its latest 2020 report on North Macedonia. This report assessed that greater transparency on media ownership and possible illegal media concentration is required.  In accordance with the division of competences between the European Union and its Member States, matters regarding the application of electoral laws are the responsibility of the Member State authorities and it is for the competent national administrative and judicial authorities to ensure compliance with applicable EU law and relevant standards. As a part of the electoral package issued by the Commission in September 2018, the Commission asked the Member States, in line with their applicable rules, to encourage and facilitate the transparency of paid online political advertisements and communications. National and European political parties, foundations and campaign organisations were asked to provide such transparency. The law in many Member States, including Slovenia and Hungary, regulates transparency in campaigning.  Concerning the online platforms’ role, the major online platforms that are signatories to the self-regulatory code of practice on disinformation have committed to provide transparency and public disclosure around online political advertising.  Democracy is a common value of the European Union. The functioning itself of our Union is founded on the principle of representative democracy. Elections in Europe shall be conducted according to the highest democratic standards. You can count on the Commission’s vigilance on these important matters in line with our competence. The aim will be to counter disinformation and to adapt to evolving threats and manipulations, as well as to support free and independent media.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Dear Sirs! We are talking about an issue that is asked solely for the purpose of interfering in internal affairs and discrediting the Slovenian Government. It is absurd to do so that it is based on information from a cyber-organised Slovenian web portal with suspicious and opaque ownership, known for attacks on the centre-right government and by journalists who have already been indicted at the press honorary tribunal. In Slovenia, we have serious problems with the media space, which has been completely unbalanced for thirty years. Monopolies, which have formed in all areas, from the economy to the judiciary and the media, during this time, are in the hands of the left. This prevents democratic processes in the country from being realised. A particular problem is national radio-television, which you would expect to be independent, but unfortunately that is not the case. The dominant media in Slovenia accounts for 90% of the media space. Those in Slovenian ownership are in the hands of the left tycoon elite, which through them implements the political agenda. And their power is extraordinary. With a few bright exceptions, objective journalism in Slovenia is unfortunately a myth. They don't write stories that don't fit. There is a lot of cover-up and biased reporting, which is why those few non-left and independent media are really important to Slovenia. The European Commission also notes a great lack of transparency in ownership. Changes are therefore necessary and do not mean the destruction of independent media. On the contrary, they are an attempt to make the media space better, more independent, transparent and balanced. Unfortunately, this is precisely the case that is an obvious demonstration of how even in the European Parliament Slovenian socialists are abusing the media for political struggle. I will be treated by two former Slovenian journalists who have extensive experience with an unbalanced media space. They were part of it, and I have no doubt that they will use all their forces to defend the monopolies in which they operated.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Mr S&D, Commissioner, on whose behalf of the S&D Group. Unfortunately, that's our reality. Unfortunately, my colleague was once again blaming my country and all the other minds. That was not the purpose of this debate. We have asked you five concrete questions, contributions from investigative journalists. Why are these extremely important? If it is true that Hungarian companies are close to the closeest circle of Hungarian Prime Minister Orban, talking about €4 million, financing media purchases in North Macedonia in the run-up to the elections in support of the former Macedonian prime minister Gruevski, who later gained asylum in Hungary, this can be a rough interference with the country's democratic processes. Half a million Hungarian money is also alleged to have come from the accounts of two Slovenian media outlets close to this currently ruling SDS. The remittances were investigated by a parliamentary commission, but unfortunately the government was replaced and the investigation was halted. My concern – even with the recent sale of the Slovenian media house to the Hungarian TV house – is that it is about the implicating the Hungarian political summit in the media and the democratic processes of my country. If this is proven, it is grossly unacceptable. The freedom of the media and the sovereignty of our countries are not for sale. Nowhere and never.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – All 42 minutes to which this debate is supposed to be devoted is unfortunately too little to say what is wrong in this area. Just yesterday, we discussed here that the state of media freedom in the Union has deteriorated. And it is precisely most of the issues raised yesterday, in fact, we can see in the case of Hungarian interference in the media in North Macedonia and Slovenia. Moreover, it is no longer a secret that the Slovenian Government is trying – without the mandate of the public – to reash Slovenia into an iliberal society. Modeled on Orban, how much.  Attacks on the public media, undermining their funding and running a parallel partisan media landscape, which, on top of that, are clearly funded by Orban's circle, are just three of many attempts to usury power by methods that violate the Union's core values.  The Commission should therefore, in my view, also monitor many of our government's other moves, because the actions of the largest party are essentially growing into a union-wide problem. I think that we are all aware of this here, as we are also aware that in the past the Union has naively delayed action for too long until one such problem has got out of control. And that's where things are actually getting out of hand.  We have tools at our disposal, you know. But you also know what else we need to stand up to this kind of degradation of our democracies. Courage and political will. Therefore, this time I really do not want general answers, but rather a concrete definition of this problem. And above all, I want action.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, I am pleased to speak from our beautiful Parliament in Strasbourg. Today's debate illustrates the chasm that now separates citizens from Member States from their elites. Indeed, its purpose boils down to a collection of specious allegations relating to certain North Macedonian media financed by Hungarian personalities and the promotion that would be made up of brands of olive oil or magnets for fridges. This is what the European institution is reduced to, determined to make fire of all wood to corner the government of Viktor Orban. In reality, the latter is guilty in their view only of having opposed an end to the reception of migrants and vetoed the European budget in response to the inequitous principle of conditionality. This discussion on a subject of no interest to our fellow citizens is deftly diverting attention from the real time bomb of the senseless enlargement project in the Balkans, particularly Albania and Northern Macedonia. For the interference that we should denounce in this case is not that allegedly practised by Hungary for the benefit of a conservative North Macedonian party, no, it is that of Tirana, who, with the base of some 25% of Albanians in Northern Macedonia, seems to be patiently weaving the web of Greater Albania. It is also the one implemented by Turkey with great cooperation in the military and political fields, notably through its affinity with the pro-Albanian Movement Besa, but also educational and cultural. This is evidenced by Ankara's project of history textbooks for Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Northern Macedonia, which are strongly or predominantly Muslim countries. A significant example of the rewrites of neo-Ottoman history that flourish in the wake of Sultan Erdogan, while Europe is called upon to repent of its colonial past. But it is also and above all the interference of associations with the charitable façade that, coming from Saudi Arabia, Qatar, or Even Pakistan, crisscrossed the country from the moment of its independence, while the so-called Islamic Youth Forum, emanating from the Muslim Brotherhood, has always been on the street in its capital, Skopje. Radical Islam is also driven by the surge in migration. A report published by the European Parliament denounced, as early as 2012, the infiltration of Islamist militants via the Balkan route, as well as the radicalisation of children within the diaspora of these states, which are based in the European Union and, according to the report, in Austria. A warning that freezes the blood, since it recalls the profile of the Islamist terrorist shot in November in Vienna, an Albanian from Northern Macedonia. The Commission cannot pretend to ignore the considerable risks it exposes Europeans at a time when the Balkan countries, a region of Europe where the concentration of jihadists returning from Syria or Iraq is the highest, are the only ones to voluntarily and publicly repatriate men affiliated with the Islamic State and held by Kurdish forces, according to a reference source. And by inserting itself, in spite of common sense, in its plan to extend to States affiliated with Turkey from Erdogan, it will bear sole responsibility.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this morning in this House, many of us made clear that if Hungary can continue to violate the rules and the values of our Treaty and enjoy impunity, breaches of the rule of law will spread throughout the European Union. Hungary is even actively promoting this. There’s evidence that Hungary is buying media outlets in Slovenia and North Macedonia and in this way contributing to the limitation and violation of freedom of expression, freedom of media and even freedom of elections. I would like to know what the Commission is going to do about this. Does it address this issue with Hungary? What concrete measures does it take towards Slovenia – either more investigation or measures really to ensure that there is no backsliding in Slovenia on this issue? How can we better protect North Macedonia against this harmful interference? This example shows exactly the importance of a swift start to the negotiations and talks with North Macedonia, as has been promised now for a very long time. I call upon Bulgaria to lift its obstruction and let these start, and also on the Council Presidency to increase the pressure on Bulgaria to do so.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, a revered colleague, this cannot and will not happen because the pressure on Bulgaria comes from anti-Bulgarian circles in Skopje, pro-Russian and pro-Serbian, aided by the media concentration associated, unfortunately, with the state leadership in Hungary. What do you want an anti-Bulgarian, anti-European, pro-Russian and pro-Serbian onssula to enter the European Union?  You are working against the idea of a European Union, I am sorry, I will tell you a lot about it and I will introduce you why this is the case.  And now on the topic with the media in North Macedonia. Yes, there is a fierce anti-Bulgarian campaign in North Macedonia, furious. I say again, unfortunately, it is supported by pro-Russian and pro-Serbian circles and unfortunately, Mr Orban gives asylum to Mr Gruevski, and thus directly participates in this anti-Bulgarian campaign. But even this parliament participated when it adopted a resolution in which my two colleagues, Mr. Kanev and Mrs. ..., forgot her name, proposed a resolution demanding the recognition of a non-existent separatist organization, non-existent minorities. That can't happen. When we talk about freedom of speech, dear, it is not only what the media is saying to Mr Soros, but unfortunately Mr Orban also has his share in this bad situation at the moment. But I promise to tell you in detail the subject.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I am glad that we are debating the interference of the far right in electoral processes in Europe. It is urgent that we report it and take it seriously.  The Government of Orbán, the great protégé of the Berlusconi and Casado parties, has managed to set up a client network in the Balkans, diverting more than five million euros, and the consequences are already visible. Slovenia now acts as orbán's satellite by closing borders and allying itself with the liberticidal governments of Poland and Hungary in blocking recovery funds, a blockade that is leaving millions of European workers, especially those in the south, in the snout. And they do this because they are required to respect the rule of law.  I throw a question to the members of the Spanish People's Party: will they continue to protect Hungary's corrupt far right by preventing their group from expelling it? Orbán's is not the only interference: in Spain we are living the illegal financing of Vox, who received almost a million euros from an Iranian terrorist group.  As I was saying, it's okay for us to have this debate, but what action is to be taken? Mrs Jourová, we need more transparency and to ensure that those who endanger our democracy do not receive a euro of public money.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: – Mr President, to my colleagues on the left, let me start with some simple questions. Aren’t you concerned by Swedish or Austrian political interference in Slovenia? Or maybe German political interference in Hungary, Poland or perhaps in Croatia?  I am asking you this because, for instance, a Swedish company owns the biggest economic daily newspaper in Slovenia. Another big Slovenian paper is owned partially by Austrians, and one of its commercial TV channels is now in Czech hands. Or let me tell you that RTL Klub, a popular TV channel in Hungary, is owned entirely by the German RTL Group. Believe it or not, 80% of regional papers in Poland and 60% of the print media in Croatia are also in German hands. Doesn’t this give you a hard time sleeping at night? Well, it should not.  These companies have invested their capital into media products in other Member States for profit, in line with one of the most basic principles of this community: the freedom of movement of capital. The same is true for North Macedonia: investments are private business matters for media companies, and they have nothing to do with politics. This one-sided criticism which is always directed at countries with conservative governments is hypocritical and absurd, and it really shouldn’t feature on the agenda of the European Parliament. This institution should remain a serious place that acts in the interests of citizens, and it should not become a circus for political clowns.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, it hardly comes as a surprise that Hungarian leaders, with Slovenian assistance, put together an international interference operation pouring millions of euros into pro-Janša and pro-Gruevski media organisations, because we all know very well that Orbán’s outrageous propaganda efforts in North Macedonia and Slovenia are just the tip of the iceberg. Whether in Brussels, Ljubljana or in Skopje, Orbán has only one goal: undermining the European Union for his own personal gain. That is why he sought to topple the Zaev Government, end the Prespa Agreement, grant political asylum to Gruevski and prevent North Macedonia’s much delayed EU accession. When will the EPP Group finally end this bumpy love affair with Fidesz authoritarians? Orbán has failed for now, but for his efforts will not stop unless you finally take action. And Commissioner, combating foreign interference is rightly one of the Commission’s top priorities. I urge you to show the same resolve in tackling such brazen interference by one of our Member States.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: – Mr President, the Commission has not taken any concrete measures to stop the Hungarian Government from pressuring independent media. Yet, at the same time, this Commission officially states – and it’s a good thing – that media pluralism is a fundamental pillar of democracy. Sadly, as this debate shows, the trend we’ve seen in Hungary is now spreading to other countries. And we know the story: the Hungarian Government likes to say that there are no journalists imprisoned in Hungary, but suffocating the media is enough to kill freedom of expression. It also allows oligarchs to cherry pick media sources, which then ultimately get leaders elected who are more complacent. The European Commission has still not responded to two complaints from 2016 and 2018 on the abuse of State aid and State advertisement by the Hungarian Government, leading to the distortion of the media market. The concentration of media ownership should be taken seriously and urgently addressed by the European Commission if we want to ensure democracy and truly fight corruption.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Let me first point out that I am disappointed with the intensiance of this item on the agenda. The promoters certainly know that the free movement of capital is one of the fundamental freedoms of the alliance, but this is clearly irrelevant to them. To my knowledge, the investments made by private Hungarian companies under European Union law are transparent, purely commercial and economic in nature and cannot constitute government interference in the internal affairs of Slovenia or Northern Macedonia. Last but not least, a good part of the left-wing media, which has an explicit monopoly on the advertising of public undertakings, is foreign-owned. There are problems with the media in Slovenia, therefore. The vast majority, especially the mainstream media, are left-leaning. It cannot be argued that in Slovenia the media space is balanced and plural. Investment in new media can, however, increase media pluralism and the independence of journalists, who today often write after the dictatorship of the advertising clique and left political elites, who often do not even hide sympathies with old and surviving communication patterns. In short, the media sphere is asymmetrical. And on the left, they will do anything to keep it that way, because it allows them to control the media space. Slovenian Democrats, however, want the ratio to improve so that the 10% share of right-wing alternative media increases. Therefore, investments from abroad are extremely welcome in this respect.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I'm small, I'm standing on a chair, and I'm shouting a big shout so you can all hear me. Dear Colleagues, This is the very beginning of a Hungarian children's story, and it fits precisely with the politically dwarf prime minister of a country worthy of a better fate, who, in addition to his own personal enrichment, is interested in one thing: to try to look bigger in the international world than he is in reality. Therefore, it does not regret the money, the money of the Hungarian taxpayers, in order to try to buy influence in other European countries. For example, buy media for yourself and your circles in Slovenia or northern Macedonia. There's no misunderstanding between us, is there? A Prime Minister who, on his way from morning to night, is talking about the EU interfering in Hungary's internal affairs has no problem interfering in the internal affairs of other EU countries for Hungary moment. I ask you that the next time you hear Viktor Orban say that national sovereignty is this and national sovereignty in this way, you should never forget that there is no deterrent in it when his interests so wish to interfere with the national sovereignty of another country. And the European Union, Budapest and Brussels have exactly the same task: we must stop this madness because it threatens the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, colleagues, this oral question to the Commission is incomplete, even inaccurate, mis addressed. The conversation shifts, the main question is omitted. I know the so-called "Hungarian media" in North Macedonia, close to former Prime Minister Gruevski. I know them because they are at the heart of the fiercest anti-Bulgarian campaign in Macedonia. They work for conflict, they work for divided Balkans, they work against European integration. They are among the main reasons for the current unfortunate situation in which Bulgaria vetoes the extension of the European Union with the Republic of North Macedonia. But this is not the interest of Hungary, it is not the interest of the Hungarian people, much less the interest of the citizens of Bulgaria or of North Macedonia. This is the interest of the Kremlin, this is the interest of the services in Serbia. And here is the right direction, this is the real issue for the European Commission, but this is also the real issue for Mr Orban's government in Budapest. What is behind the so-called "Hungarian media" in North Macedonia? Is the ownership clear? Why do these media outlets, which are accused of being close to the Government of Hungary, work for the interest of Moscow and Belgrade? We have to answer that question.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for their interventions and for this interesting debate.  I will first reply on the comments addressed to the Commission. This Commission does everything to support an independent, professional and trustworthy media because, more than ever before, we need objective news which will inform citizens about the situation. We have to do it and we are doing everything with the competences we have.  Concrete steps on the concrete situation is always a matter of a thorough analysis as to whether this is against EU rules and whether we have the instruments to take concrete steps which will address an individual case. You know the system very well. We work on individual cases, which can be addressed by enquiry into infringements – which is not this case – and we can work by adopting new legislation, or proposing new legislation, to address systemic issues. This is what we are doing. We now have the Audiovisual Media Services Directive already being transposed into national laws. We are scrutinising whether it is done in full because, if not, we have to launch an infringement against the Member State and ask for an improvement in the implementation or application of the European Directive in national law. This is now ongoing because this Directive came into force this year. We are preparing very thoroughly for the application date of the Copyright Directive, which will come next year in June. It will be a very important moment in history for strengthening the position of professional journalism because, behind this heavily lobbied piece of legislation – I think you will remember the time when this was in the final stage of adoption – there was a very simple idea, namely that professional journalists have to get paid for their work.  This is going to come into force next year in June and the Commission is prepared to help with proper implementation in the Member States, which will not be possible to circumvent. We have already seen in France that an effort was made by Google to find some middle way solution, and we said no. It has to be implemented and applied in full.  We are going to adopt the European Democracy Action Plan and the Media Action Plan next week, on 2 December. I will not go into details because of the time limit here, but you will see that in everything we are doing – by the current legislation which is already in application or the rules we are going to adopt – we are trying to strengthen the position of independent media because we need the independent and professional media to be strong and do their job. The character of their job is twofold. One is that they are economic actors. What we see now, in the time of COVID, is the more we need professional and objective media, the less money they get. They are in horrible financial distress now in the time of COVID. That’s why we recommended to the Member States to use the state aid schemes also to help the media as economic players and employers. The second task of the media, and an indispensable role, is that they must remain strong watchdogs of democracy. They must hold us, who are in power, under control. We are also working in this direction. You will see in the European Democracy Action Plan that we will propose several actions to strengthen their position as the watchdogs of democracy. I will always emphasise professional independent trustworthy media. This is what we are speaking about.  And why? Why are we trying to strengthen the position of the media? Because we see clearly that when the media are weak, they are easy targets for political and economic pressure. This is what we see in Europe. The trend is worsening. In the summer this year, we published the Media Pluralism Monitor, where we saw this very clearly. A worsening trend of political pressure on the media has increased everywhere in Europe. Economic pressure, now made more dramatic by the impact of COVID, has made the situation of the media very difficult. Advertisers have moved to the online sphere and 50% of all advertising money goes to Facebook and Google in Europe. This is the reality. When the media are hungry, then they have no other choice than to take the money from those who want to impose the political agenda. This is what we are witnessing in many cases. So we need to do everything we can – this is for me a systemic measure – to make the media stronger and not to be driven into this financial trap because they of course need to make money doing their job. We have a very vivid dialogue with media organisations because we also want the EU money to help, but of course we cannot pay individual media because we have to respect the independence of the media. I will finish by asking all of us to try to look at things objectively. The EU is, of course, supporting the media, which is also financed by foreign actors when they operate as business players. But when we see that there is a political agenda behind that, then there is something wrong.  Thank you very much for this debate. I do not believe that this was the last debate about the media. This was a geographically—specific one, but it also revealed the systemic issues we are facing and that we are trying to solve at European Union level because we have a limit to systemic functioning solutions, including the increase in transparency of ownership. This is one of the things which we now want to scrutinise in more depth because this is one of the conditions which are already in the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, which is now in force.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The debate is over.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The next item is the debate on the Declarations of the Council and the Commission on the right to abortion in Poland (2020/2876(RSP)) .  I would remind you that, as in previous debates, there will be no catch-the-eye procedures or blue card questions in this debate. Interventions are made from liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, protecting women’s rights is my mission as Commissioner, and also my personal fight, and you know this. You also know – we all do – that high—quality sexual and reproductive health services are essential to women and girls. This includes access to contraception, prevention and treatment of HIV and other sexually—transmitted diseases, and fertility and sex—specific cancers, and access to abortion.  From a legal perspective, it is clear that the EU has no competence on abortion rights within a Member State. Legislation in this area is up to the Member State concerned. I will state factually that the recent decision by the Polish Constitutional Tribunal has restricted Poland’s abortion law. As you know, in the Article 7 procedure launched by the Commission in 2017, we raised concerns over the independence and legitimacy of the Polish Constitutional Tribunal. As recalled in the 2020 Rule of Law Report, these concerns have so far not been resolved.  In the weeks following the Polish Constitutional Tribunal’s decision, we have seen how many Polish citizens have taken to the streets – civil society, women and men protested in Poland – and I wholeheartedly hope that these voices are being heard and listened to.  Strong women’s rights are an asset and an achievement which the whole of Europe must be proud of. But progress is hard won and easily lost, and we see this in Europe and worldwide. As President von der Leyen said: backsliding is not an option for a continent that aims to win the future. So I look forward to working together with you to push forward on women’s rights, and I know that I can count on your support. (Applause)

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is clear that Poland is under attack. It is under attack from within, from a government, a political party and from a belief that doesn’t respect fundamental values, including the rule of law and women’s rights.
