And let us remember, all over the world, women’s rights are human rights. A party that seeks to sabotage the very institutions that built a democratic Poland, that sought to oppose guiding principles after the fall of communism, where once the Solidarity movement took to the streets amidst a tidal wave of support for fundamental values. Now a pitiful government cowers behind Mr Kaczyński as he tries to tear down the very essence of democracy, human rights and the rule of law.  And yet, as the poet from my own country, Seamus Heaney, would say: the longed-for tidal wave of justice can rise up. And where the spirit of the Solidarity movement rose up in the 1980s, so too does the spirit rise up again today, and it can be seen on the streets in cities across Poland – Warsaw, Gdańsk, Kraków, Poznań and others. The great spirit of Polish women can be seen on the streets again. From the country that gave the world women like Marie-Skłodowska Curie, Wisława Szymborska and Edith Stein, once again, Polish women are rising up and indeed inspiring the world and the autocrats and the strong-man politicians better watch out. To them I say give up your futile path. You may try, but your brand of politics will never win against a determined crowd of millions of women and men.  And to the women of Poland, know this: we in the European Parliament support you, we salute you and we stand with you. Poland: piekło kobiet – women’s hell, no more! (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, ladies and gentlemen, we should not be holding this debate today. It is totally unacceptable, it is totally intolerable that in the middle of the 21st century, women's rights are being attacked in a Member State of the European Union, as is happening in Poland today. And in the face of this situation of injustice, this Parliament must manifest itself as it is done on the streets full of men and women in Poland by claiming the freedom and rights of women. It is totally unacceptable that a Constitutional Court, controlled by the Government of Mr Kaczy-ski, wants to attack one of the fundamental principles, which is the freedom of women to decide on our own bodies, to decide on our motherhood. And, therefore, the voice of this Parliament must be heard as a reflection of a society which will not allow it to take a step back in the fight for equality. Because we can't let our daughters have fewer rights than our mothers, and that's what's happening right now in Poland. Therefore, the Social Democrats will work to guarantee the rights and freedoms of women. I would like to recall that six years ago today the Government of the People's Party in Spain tried to amend the Abortion Act, it tried to cut women's rights. And Spanish women took to the streets in Spain, just as women took to the streets in France, Italy, Berlin, many European Union countries. Spanish women stop the law. European women, together, stop the law. When we are together, we are strong and today we are all with women in Poland for defending their rights, their freedoms. We will not fail to claim for a single minute that Europe cannot allow this attack on women's fundamental freedoms across Europe. We're with you.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, a woman’s right to make decisions about her body is hers and hers only to have. This is about self-determination as a fundamental right. Today Polish women are left with no other option than going to neighbouring countries to undergo a safe and legal abortion, and the Polish women who can’t afford to go abroad face even worse prospects. I see this as a move backwards in time, and as women, we have to prove that we have the right to self-determination time and time again. We are held accountable for how we dress, and the decisions we make about our own bodies and so on, and even when we get to sit at the table, the focus is on our appearance, our capabilities often neglected. To the women in Poland, I would like to say: we are standing right next to you and we will join you in this battle till the very end. We won’t back down, and we in the European Parliament will not let you fight this battle alone. What is happening in Poland regards all of us – your backlash is our backlash; when you struggle we feel your pain. We hear you, we see you, and we will fight with you. And this is not where this ends. We need to have a clear call to action. Together with my colleagues from Renew Europe and our other allies, we demand that EU funding to the Polish government is cut if they fail to respect the rule of law. Secondly, we will continue to support civil society movements in Poland in their fight for women’s rights. Last but not least, we demand that the Commission works on guaranteeing universal access to sexual-reproductive health services, including abortion, and for these rights to be included in the next EU health strategy.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Eighteen years ago, my wife and I faced a difficult decision. We had welcomed our ninth child, and the ultrasound had diagnosed a neck fold. Should we let the amniotic fluid test be done now or not? We decided against it, because an abortion would never have been an option for us, and Paul was born healthy. For the curious among you: God also entrusted us with a tenth child. Ten years after this birth of Paul, I was for the first time at a demo, at the March for Life in Berlin – against abortion. There I met them, these lucky charms, these joyful people with trisomy 21, Down syndrome. They reported from their lives, their profession or from school and how much they loved their parents for allowing them to live. Nowhere have I seen so much contagious cheerfulness and light-heartedness as on these demos for life. But unfortunately – behind the police cordons – nowhere has so much hatred and enmity against the beautiful, the good, the selfless and the holy. And now we want to rebuke and condemn the Poles for saying 'yes' to life, because they are committed to their Christian roots? They are fighting for one of the greatest assets that our human rights declarations and constitutions want to protect: for human life. Poland is right to object to abortion being made a human right by means of the detour of protecting sexual health. Even the ECJ defined the result of merging a male sperm cell with a female egg as human life many years ago, and we now want to criticise the Poles for respecting a person's right to life more than our selfish rights to self-determination? Who is actually protecting human rights here more?

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: On behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Again, we cry out to the Polish government. The rule of law, freedom, human rights, but in Poland there is no longer the rule of law and human rights. There are no free courts, public media, LGBT rights and women's rights. Every year we move away from Paris, Brussels and Berlin. This House is perhaps the last place where women's rights can be talked about without fear of getting into the head with a police baton or gas in the face. You can temporarily take away our rights, condemn us to suffering, put our health and lives at risk, but you will not take away our voice because we are in the European Union. In Poland, you are brutally suppressing demonstrations, but here in Brussels you will not close our mouths, because here human rights are fundamental values and the right to abortion is a human right. We no longer want to suffer through one party, one religion and one ideology.  I have a dream that one day women in Poland will have the same rights as Germans, French women, Lithuanians, Czech women and all the other women of our community. But we will not change this as long as health and every other dimension of human rights is not the full competence of the European Union. If we become a community of agriculture, transport and borders, we will not be there in a moment. Let us remember freedom or death. I call on everyone to support our resolution in its entirety, without compromise.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let us discuss facts, not imagining. A request to the Constitutional Court to examine the constitutionality of the law was submitted by parliamentarians from different political parties. The Court examined the constitutionality of the law, a constitution signed by the former left-wing president and passed by the Sejm under the left. Even the former Members of the Court judged that the Court could not have ruled otherwise in this case.  So today, the so-called defenders of the Constitution are protesting against, de facto, not only the ruling of the Constitutional Court, but also the Constitution itself. Looking at the matter from an EU perspective, once again the European Parliament, which is calling for the rule of law to be respected, unfortunately, is breaking the rule of law itself. I therefore call for respect for the Treaties, because they clearly define the scope of the Union's action and the limits of its competences. In accordance with Article 168(7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, Union action shall be conducted in accordance with the member states' determination of their health policy, as well as the organisation and provision of health services and medical care. And the initiators of today's debate want to sustain street protests at all costs, which, during the pandemic, threaten the lives and health of not only the protesters, but also all those who contact them.  A Member from Spain is calling for protests. I would like to recall the March protests in Spain, which were mard by a large number of deaths in Spain. How are you not ashamed? Thus, the implementation of this left-wing agenda will be occupied by thousands of illnesses and deaths due to COVID-19. And it will also be your responsibility.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this is not a debate on the right to abortion in Poland, it is a debate as to whether we will allow a decades-long setback in women's rights in the European Union. Thirty years ago abortion was legal and accessible in Poland, in 1993 it was severely restricted and a month ago the Constitutional Court eliminated the case of fetal malformation, which accounts for 97% of legal abortions performed in the country.  This judgment is the Polish government's umpteenth attack on the rule of law. Yes, yes, it is the Government, which has appointed these judges, in case anyone doubted the need to link every euro of Community funds with the guarantee of fundamental rights. Let's be clear: banning abortion is a form of torture; forcing women to use pills and other methods clandestinely and without medical support is a form of torture; forcing women to travel to other countries in order to terminate their pregnancy is a form of torture.  In 2015 the Government attempted to ban abortion with the support of the Catholic Church and ultra-conservative organizations such as Ordo Iuris, but crashed into a tide of women in black. This year, taking advantage of the pandemic, she has stepped on the accelerator of her anti-right agenda and women have taken to the streets again.  He said at first that this debate is not a debate on the right to abortion in Poland: in Spain, for example, the People's Party tried to break down the Abortion Act in the Constitutional Court. His appeal is still in a drawer, but the rapporteur is a judge linked to Opus Dei, so we can still go back. The lightning that Polish women use as a symbol warns us of a danger: after Poland, the far right will go after each and every one of us.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the reactionary Polish Government is facing a crackdown on mobilisations that have broken out in the country calling for the unacceptable decision of the Constitutional Court banning all abortion not to be implemented. It is not the only government, dozens of countries, and the United States, have signed such a shameful anti-abortion declaration. This is another blow to the rights of young women and couples. The Polish government's aim is a total ban, pushing more women into illegal abortion, rewarding the commercialisation of health, reinforcing anachronistic views on the role of women. Moreover, it is an example of alignment with the EU's anti-grassroots health commercialisation guidelines aimed at fully flattening the rights of women, the working-class family as a whole, but also at criminalising support for socialist conquests, which laid the foundations for achieving gender parity in social life. On the occasion of today, we would like to emphasise that the socialist countries, including Poland, saved thousands of young women when abortion was banned in almost all the capitalist states of Europe. It is a duty to strengthen the fight for the modern rights of workers and women in working families. Invoking supposed respect for human rights, and in the case of Poland, triggers new unpopular mechanisms that come to stay, based on competition within the European Union.  Today it is imperative to legalise abortion within the framework of an exclusively public and free health system, with services related to sex education, family planning, prenatal screening, pregnancy and childbirth.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Every woman should have the right to choose according to her values and views. Abortion should not be a contraceptive, but if a woman chooses to do so, I, as a man and a politician, should respect it, because no politician, ladies and gentlemen, can right to be the conscience of another person. No politician has the right to force women into heroism, because this is a form of violence. No politician can force a woman to give birth to a badly damaged fetus and to look at the death of her own child in pain and suffering, because this is a form of violence.  Politicians, on the other hand, have a duty to create laws and solutions that support those women who have chosen to give birth and raise a child with a severe disability. The lack of such support, when so much is said about values, is a form of violence. The lack of reliable, age-appropriate sex education to help young people make the right decisions at the right time is a form of violence. Failure to properly protect children from paedophiles or to side with paedophiles rather than victims is a form of violence. Today we are with Poles and Poles on Polish streets, because they are protesting against human rights violations, the destruction of democracy, the rule of law, against pseudo-education. They demand efficient health care, a proper fight against the pandemic or help entrepreneurs. This is no longer just a protest about abortion, although it has started since abortion.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I recently met Mrs. Eve. She told me the story of her daughter, a raped young woman who wanted to use abortion surgery. She visited more doctors, but none of them wanted to perform this procedure. So she did it illegally in the so-called abortion underground, paying for it with serious health problems. It is today's Poland in the heart of Europe in 2020 – hell of women. At the end of our meeting, Mrs. Eve said, "Mr. Robercie, please do everything so that no one ever has to go through what my daughter did again." That's why I'm here, that's why we're all here today. You will never go alone again. As rapporteur for this resolution, I would like to thank all the groups, all those who support this resolution. But I have the impression that if the guys had an abortion, we wouldn't have to talk about it here today, because it would probably be available on every newsstand. This is a historic moment that millions of Poles are waiting for. It is the hope that Parliament gives today to those who courageously opposed the so-called ruling of the so-called Constitutional Court on the streets of Polish towns and cities and who, despite the violence of power, are being beaten by the police and shouting strongly and clearly 'We want a whole life'. Today we are sending them a clear message: we do not agree with violence against women. We do not agree with the restriction of their rights. There is no such thing as a so-called abortion compromise, but there is a hell of a woman, once – the suffering of our grandmothers and mothers, today – wives, girlfriends and daughters. This is their health, their lives and their choice.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: Mr President! Equality means that we women are not children, we are adults, empowered people who can choose for themselves, who can make decisions about our own lives. In order to have equality, we must have the right to control our own bodies. The right to abortion is simply a prerequisite for equality. Equality is a European value enshrined in the Treaty. The right to abortion should not be a political struggle, it is a right. But the Polish government has made it an ideological battleground. Over the last five years, Poland has abandoned the values that bind us together in Europe. Minorities have been under attack, the rule of law has been under attack and women – indeed women's bodies – have been under attack. The right to abortion has been slowly but surely stolen from Polish women. The Polish government's ideology removes rights from people. Creating LGBTI-free zones, it's an ideology, the removal of a woman's rights over her own body, it's an ideology. But regardless of the Polish government's ideology, remember that a ban on abortion does not make abortions disappear, it just puts them underground. Those who can travel abroad do so, those who cannot, are left to crochet needles and kitchen tables. Secret, unsafe, dangerous abortions. The struggle for freedom does not always take a straight line, it is not a given that freedom and equality are gaining ground every time, which is why we must fight against every step backwards. As a woman in Denmark, I am not free until women in Poland are free. Denmark is not part of a free Europe until the whole of Europe is free.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, nothing, exactly nothing, about what is happening in Poland right now can come to us as a surprise. Fundamentalists and authoritarians are taking political control of the judiciary, and what is the first thing they do? They take away the rights of women, of LGBTIs and others. If we don’t do anything about it, it will continue, so again, Commissioner, do not let this happen. This is a responsibility of historic proportions. Take it and do something about it. Yesterday, with 200 Members of Parliament from all across Europe and from across the political spectrum, we sent a letter again to the Commission to say to stand up against these attacks on the rule of law and fundamental rights.  And secondly, all my admiration, my love and my solidarity to the brave people who are resisting this in the streets of Poland right now. Our bodies, our rights in Poland and everywhere else. This Parliament salutes your strength and resilience. You make all of us proud to be Europeans. (Applause)

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The right to life is one of the fundamental civil rights. There is a lot of talk in this House about defending values and defending fundamental rights. The most important value is life. Today we stand up for him, we stand up for those who cannot defend themselves. Poland is a law-abiding country. The most important piece of legislation in Poland is the Constitution, article 38 of which makes it clear that the Republic of Poland provides every person with legal protection of life.  The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child also explicitly speaks of the legal protection of children both before and after birth. Above all, our humanity is evidenced by how we care about our society. We care for the elderly, the sick, we do not categorise and divide people into better and worse. Man is human, and this is not changed by the fact that he is 80, 50 or 15 years old or is preparing to be born. Every person should be respected and protected at all stages of life. It is our moral duty! Ladies and gentlemen, if abortion is a woman's right, where are the rights of unborn children?

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Madam President, the conservative right wing in Poland and across Europe and other countries is trying to attack and use women’s bodies – and LGBTI persons’ bodies – as a battleground. The attack on abortion rights is one of the most brutal ways to try to control our lives and to control and install patriarchal values in society. And I think, as has been said here, it’s also part of a bigger picture of this conservative right wing project to try to install ever more authoritarian rule. They want to control the courts, the media, civil society, and we have to say stop! Women’s lives are on the line here.  In Poland a very strong movement is opposing this. We see demonstrations, we see mobilisations, and we stand with you. This debate here, the European Parliament resolution, is there to stand with you, to hold your back. You will be winners in this. We will all be winners in this, because we will have protected women’s rights, abortion rights, abortion care and rights to control our own lives. So we stand with you. We stand with all the women and men in Poland that are fighting for equality and democracy. (Applause)

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, I would just like to remind all of us that women are human beings, and that’s why women’s rights are human rights. Part of human rights are the Beijing Declaration, the Istanbul Convention, sexual and reproductive rights, and the right to determine over our own bodies. This is a crucial and indisputable element of human rights, and of the international interpretation of not only rights but international law. I would like to remind you that human rights are part of the rule of law, as you can read from the various interpretations of the Commission. That means that it is the duty of the European Union to also defend human rights and women’s rights in all of its Member States as a part of the rule of law. Poland has breached the rule of law, and the latest decision of the Constitutional Tribunal is clearly against all these principles. What we need to do is to defend the European people, we need to stand beside the European people, we need to stand behind and beside European women, and, dear friends, we need to stand beside the Polish women and defend their rights and the rule of law in the European Union.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Dalli, I would like to thank you for your support. Fifty years ago, Sweden's abortion legislation was restrictive. Then young Swedish women went to Poland to have an abortion. Since then, much has happened around sexual and reproductive health and rights, both in Sweden and throughout Europe, and thus also access to safe and legal abortion. But we see that it is not enough, because every day women's human rights are violated, and Poland's restriction of abortion rights is serious. It is an attack on women's human rights. We in Europe must act and react every time. Every woman and girl has the right to decide over her own body, and I want to say to all of you that it feels particularly important on a day like this – on Orange Day – to underline the value of women's rights and women's rights to their own bodies.

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is 25 November, the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, and we are here debating the right to abortion in 2020 in Europe! Since the Conservatives, these defenders of the right to life, oppose legal abortion, let us explain to them then what an illegal IVG! An illegal IVG, ladies and gentlemen, means accepting to endanger a woman's life, accepting the use of medieval methods and serious complications for women's health, such as sepsis, haemorrhage, infertility and even death. An illegal IVG is treating women's bodies as a commodity, of which Europe is the market.  Colleagues, abortion is a fundamental right and Europe has a responsibility to enforce it everywhere. Polish women have had enough. European women have had enough. The European Parliament has had enough. 'Mamy do' (Translated in Polish as 'we've had enough')

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Constitutional Court in Poland has ruled in favour of the protection of life. This is in line with documents of the European Union, the Council of Europe or the UNITED NATIONS, which state that every human being has a natural right to life. This is the fundamental value of our civilization. The initiator of the resolution says that it is guided by hope and love, and in the name of this love wants to kill children in the majesty of the law only on suspicion of illness or disability. It's nothing new. In Bolshevik Russia , as the first country in the world, abortion was legalized. This law was then introduced by Nazi Germany. Hitler also used to say "I will personally shoot this idiot who would like to ban abortion in the eastern occupied territories." Is this thought realized here? Eugenics seemed to have been discredited in the end due to the actions of the Third Reich. Unfortunately, today, those who do not get out of the mouth of the slogan of equality, in this case, seek legal segregation of children and believe that because of various selfishness, they can be killed. Here we have a dispute between the civilization of life and the civilization of death. May it not mean the end of European civilization.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to make a clear declaration on behalf of the European People's Party. We are in favour of this resolution, we are signing it like most of the European Parliament. We hear this dramatic cry of Polish women and we also see the cry of Polish young society, young Poles, young Poles, students, students who do not agree to try to build an authoritarian ideological state. This is discord, not only against drastic draconian laws introduced in violation of the legal order, that is, disagreement with the restriction of freedom of expression, the media, assemblies, association, attempts to harass high school youth, the use of police against women, the brutal breaking up of demonstrations. It is not only Polish women and those who protest that Polish society does not accept this.  I wanted to say very strongly that this is also an experience of my generation when we wore resistors, because there was a power that wanted to decide for others.  Today you have lightning, this is a symbol of energy, and you will win, because the energy of youth always wins, because there is hope in you, because you are Europeans, and this is also a symbol of hope for a future European free society.  Freedom always wins.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: – Madam President, dear protesters outside in the streets of Poland and elsewhere, your actions matter – not only in Poland; all over Europe, and therefore a big thank you. The Polish Government has spent the last few months doing everything it can to de facto deprive Polish women of their right to self-determination and their decision-making power. But women must be able to decide for themselves when to perform abortions.  This misjudgment by the so-called Constitutional Court in Poland is an attack on women's rights throughout Europe. The consequences are already clear: the de facto ban leads to more dead women who have to make unsafe abortions in secret. And other countries, such as the Austrian Government, as we have known since yesterday, are now also beginning – in a quiet step – to strengthen this attack on women's health.  In the European Parliament, therefore, we stand in solidarity with the many Poles against this backward-looking and inhumane policy. Women's rights are human rights, and every day, day after day, they are defended anew.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The European Union was founded on Christian values, the central value of which is the life of every person, especially the defenceless, his inalienable dignity, the inalienable and indisputable right to his protection. Every tiny person at conception has its own unique genetic code that determines everything: eye color, intellect, talents and unique fingerprints. This tiny man often has to collide with the civilization of death in the Union today. Therefore, ethical norms concerning the protection of the phenomenon of human life cannot be called into question or distorted by any vote, by any majority. What we humanly do legally is morally indivenable. Saint John Paul II said, "A nation that kills its children is a nation without a future." How sad it must be today, where children do not want to hear laughter, where they do not want to see the joy of children, and older people who can enrich us with their experience and warmth are killed in the name of false pity. Commissioner, 'Quo vadis Europo?'  I thank the doctors who care today for every life, for the lives of premature babies, for the lives of all people. Thank you to all Polish doctors and not only.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank you all for this debate. If I were to compress what the majority in this room said in five words, it’s: women’s rights are human rights. And we are certainly on the same page. I want to close this debate by remembering the first woman president of this Parliament, Simone Veil, who envisioned a Europe where women’s rights were not questioned, let alone curtailed. This is a vision that we still need to fulfil, and I pay homage to her and her legacy and hope that we can find inspiration in her work at the European level and as French Health Minister. I thank you.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 26 March 2008. Adopted on 15 November 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Marek BELKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The issue of anti-abortion law has recently heated up the debate in Poland. The ruling of the so-called Constitutional Court, whose impartiality and legality of action raise objections, has provoked widespread agitation and spontaneous protests across the country. The Court's decision of 22 October leads to a near-total ban on abortion, which can be regarded as an attack on the fundamental rights of all Citizens of the Union. It also puts Poland on the inglorious podium of countries with the strictest anti-abortion laws in the Community and, more importantly, is contrary to the popular opinion of Polish society.  This attack on the freedoms of Polish women is doubly outrageous when we realise that it was carried out on a political order, in the midst of a pandemic with which the Polish government is completely uneasy. By provoking social dissent, the power-dependent Court has put citizens at risk by giving them a deadly choice between freedom and health.  In Polish tradition, the defence of women is considered a noble attitude. When the Polish authorities raise their hand on The Poles, it is our duty to defend their dignity. That is why I appeal, first of all, to the European Commission – we can help, for example, a mechanism of financial support for women who decide on their own body and will be forced to carry out the procedure outside Poland. Let us save the citizens of the European Union from the hell that the fundamentalist government wants them to cook!

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – An attack on Polish women is an attack on all women in Europe. Poles, who have been refused access to abortion by the government, understand what it means to have the right to decide on their own body. It's a right that should belong to every woman. I support The Poles in the fight for the possibility of abortion, and I admire the unity of a people who are fighting the authoritarianism of their government. It is unfair that, in the 21st century, in the midst of modern Europe, we should return to discussions about restricting this right. However, it is important that we show the greatest public support for the thousands of Poles and Poles who have had to take to the streets for their rights. For now, they have managed to delay the implementation of the new controversial regime of artificial termination of pregnancy, but unfortunately this is not over. However, I hope that the Polish Government will - and as soon as possible - see that such political decisions, which bring the country back to the past, have no place in the modern European Union.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Treaty of Lisbon gives legal character to the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Charter was accepted by all EU countries except the UK and Polish, which reserved the restriction of its protection to its citizens through the provisions of Protocol 7, known as the British Protocol. In Article 1 we have expressly stated that, for the avoidance of doubt, nothing contained in Title IV of the Charter creates rights that can be prosecuted applicable to Polish, except where Poland has provided for such rights in its national law. Article 2 Where a provision of the Charter relates to national practices and national laws, it shall apply to the Polish only to the extent that the rights and principles contained in that provision are recognised by law or Polish. On the basis of these two articles, Poland is sovereign on the issues raised in the debate today. We do not agree with imposing on Poles how to act or think on issues where they have their inviolable rights. The Constitution of the Republic of Poland protects every life, the life of the mother, but also the unborn. Poles are a wise Nation that can solve its own internal problems and does not need pressure from the EU institutions, because that is the only way to see this vote. Today's resolution exceeds all democratic standards, and its provisions are an incitement to violations of Polish and international law.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Statements by the Council and the Commission on the new LGBTIQ Equality Strategy (2020/2877(RSP)). Members are informed that no requestable speeches will be given during this part-session and that blue card questions will not be accepted. I would also like to point out that the speeches can be spoken remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for having included this debate in the plenary agenda. Since the founding of the European Union, its Member States have intensified their efforts to build societies based on shared values of human rights, equality and non—discrimination. In response to increasing societal pressure to ensure equal rights for all, we have made some progress over the years in fighting discrimination and in advancing equality and inclusion of LGBTIQ people in Europe. However, we still have a long way to go. Today in the EU, too many LGBTIQ people cannot be themselves without fear of discrimination, exclusion or violence. In 2019, 43% of LGBTIQ people felt discriminated against. In 2012 this figure was lower, at 37%. All of this takes place in a climate of growing opposition against the protection of LGBTIQ rights and the global pandemic, which has compounded existing inequalities for LGBTIQ people. So the European Commission is taking a strong stand for European diversity by launching the first ever LGBTIQ equality strategy as part of the union of equalities strategic approach. The LGBTIQ equality strategy will help to build a Union where people, in all their diversity, are equal, where they can be themselves without risk of discrimination, exclusion or violence. To achieve this vision, the LGBTIQ strategy presents the Commission’s key actions and objectives for the coming five years around four pillars: tackling discrimination, ensuring safety, building inclusive societies and leading the call for LGBTIQ equality around the world. Several Member States do not have laws to punish hate crime and hate speech against LGBTIQ people. The Commission’s new strategy announces the initiative to extend the list of EU crimes to cover hate crime and hate speech, including when targeted at LGBTIQ people. Due to legal differences across Member States, rainbow families continue to struggle to have their family ties recognised when they cross the EU’s internal borders. Despite the differences in national legislation, the Commission will push for mutual recognition of family relations in the EU. As the President said in her State of the Union speech, when you are a parent, you are a parent everywhere. And in order to improve legal certainty for EU citizens exercising their free movement rights, the Commission will review the 2009 guidelines on free movement. The reviewed guidelines will reflect the diversity of families and hence contribute to facilitating the exercise of free movement rights for all families, including, of course, rainbow families. To realise the strategy’s objectives, the Commission will harness all tools that are at its disposal. Targeted actions will be combined with enhanced equality mainstreaming. LGBTIQ people, like all other groups, are not a homogeneous group, which is why intersectionality will be used as a cross-cutting principle throughout the implementation of the strategy. Furthermore, EU actions to advance LGBTIQ equality need to be matched by sustained efforts at all levels, which is why we are calling for LGBTIQ equality strategy in all the 27 EU Member States. So I really look forward to your debate and your impressions on this strategy. (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Colleagues, I have to ask for your patience because I am now going to announce the results of the first votes of today. So it will be some poetry for you to listen to! Or you can do something else. But we will continue with the discussion on the LGBTIQ Equality Strategy right afterwards.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: We now continue with the discussion on the Council and Commission statements on the new LGBTIQ Equality Strategy (2020/2877(RSP)).

name: Maria WALSH
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to thank the Commission for launching our first LGBTI+ gender strategy. Given the serious deterioration of LGBTI+ rights in recent years, as the Commissioner shared, it is important now more than ever that we focus and we work together on protecting our citizens. As an MEP, I consistently advocate for the protection and promotion of good mental health and make sure that my work within Parliament reflects this.  The numerous references throughout this strategy to the importance of ensuring that our LGBTI+ community have their mental health protected is deeply important to me. Therefore, I would like to take this opportunity to appeal to colleagues in the House, and all EU institutions, to support an EU—wide ban on conversion therapy, a clearly destructive and disgusting practice which has horrifying, detrimental impacts on those who go through it. It has no place in Europe. It violates the fundamental rights of our citizens. It destroys a sense of self and it must go.  My second focus is on the importance of inclusion of LGBTI families in the strategy. For me as a gay woman, being a European, I welcome the rainbow families. They already exist in Europe, they have done so for generations, and we simply have failed to accommodate and advocate for them. This sets that right.  Picking up from what our President, the Commission, and indeed Commissioner Dalli has said herself, a parent in one country is a parent in every country. We cannot pick and choose which families we protect. I am hopeful and I expect us to work together.  (Applause)

name: Marc ANGEL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commission for this ambitious action plan concerning acceptance, recognition and protection. This long-awaited strategy is welcomed by LGBTIQ civil society organisations, but also by millions of LGBTI people living in Europe, their parents, their children, and their families and friends. As the Co-Chair of the European Parliament LGBTIQ intergroup, I would like to thank you for the close cooperation we have had with you and also for your close cooperation with civil society. This strategy comes at a very opportune moment because in several Member States of the European Union, for instance Poland and Hungary, the governments have organised a real witch-hunt against LGBTI people. This has even intensified during the pandemic because they want to divert attention from the failures in fighting the virus. We Socialists and Democrats appreciate that this strategy also tackles discrimination in employment by bringing forward legislation to enhance the role of equality bodies. We also welcome the fact that EU funds will strengthen LGBTIQ civil society and research on gender in the Member States.  Hate speech and hate crime is on the rise in the European Union and therefore extending the list of hate crimes, including when LGBTIQ people are targeted, is crucial. Enhancing legal protection for rainbow families and facilitating the exercise of free movement for all families is paramount. We welcome the strong commitment of the Commission that when one is a parent in one country, one is a parent in every country. However, it is regrettable that the commitment on mutual recognition of same-gender partnerships between Member States is softer. By urging Member States to adopt national LGBTIQ action plans, the rights of trans, non-binary and intersex persons can no longer be ignored by Member States. Yes, they exist. They live with us. They live next to us. This strategy, together with the EU Gender Equality Strategy and the intersectional approach, is the best answer to counter the anti-gender movement – a movement made up of ultra-hard-core conservative politicians and their followers by religious fundamentalists, who stand for an outdated patriarchal society where women’s rights and LGBTI rights have no place.  Let me finish by recalling that being an LGBTI person is not an ideology, it is not an identity, and it is not a choice – but being homo, bi, trans and inter-phobic is a choice. (Applause)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for putting on the table the LGBTI rights strategy that this House has been asking for repeatedly for many years. Finally we have something on the table, and I think you can count on almost all groups in this Parliament to make it even better, because we will keep pushing. In recent years, we have been talking a lot about LGBTI-free zones in Poland and recently also in Hungary. Let’s be ambitious: let’s make Europe the biggest LGBTI welcome zone in the world, and there will not be any white spots. I think the vast majority of European citizens are not homophobic. What the Polish government is doing is not representative for the majority of people. That’s why it’s very good that this is on the table, because it’s a political statement. It is representative for the set of values that we represent, the kind of society that we represent: a society where everybody has a place, every European is welcome and safe. What’s in it on hate speech and hate crimes, legislative proposals on rainbow families, is very good, but I would like to echo what has been said by Maria Walsh on conversion therapies, where we want a legal ban at European level. Please, Commissioner, also think about LGBTI sex workers, people who are very marginalised, very vulnerable; think of transgender persons, who still in five countries undergo unnecessary sterilisation, and people who, thanks to Covid measures, are back in an unsafe situation. Finally, Commissioner, I hope that this Commission is not just going to put forward new proposals but will also enforce the existing instruments, because we already have a lot of tools that we could use a lot better. Thank you: you have our support.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is truly disconcerting that, in the midst of a pandemic, the Commission is once again ideologically chooses to discuss the new strategy on LGBT equality. When I entered Brussels, I was proud to be part of a large community that trusts the values of our founding fathers - De Gasperi, Monnet, Adenauer - Christian, liberal and social values, and everything I would have expected less than having to find myself within a "Zan model" Europe, named after the first signatory of the measure that the secularist left already wants to use in Italy to censor and process freedom of opinion , leveraging the concept of homophobic discrimination, coincidentally the same words I hear here. There's no need for that. The European Union, according to all the reports of the European Institute for Gender Equality, Eurobarometer and the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, is one of the most LGBT friendly areas in the world and it is absurd that ad personam measures should be taken to protect certain categories instead of others, creating discrimination on the contrary. Instead, we want a Parliament that protects all citizens, without distinction of sex, opinion, weight, health, age, personal, political or religious convictions, even when they say that the family is only the natural one, that every child has the right to a mother and a father, that surrogacy is an inhumane practice and that in school our children should not be subjected to gender lessons. Finally, when the President of the Commission talks about the recognition of parenthood for homosexual couples, I would like to remind her of Article 81 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, according to which family law is the exclusive competence of the Member States, and even when there were transnational implications, it would be the Council that should intervene and not the Commission.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, let’s be honest, Europe’s LGBTI community has been attacked on many occasions in recent years but, importantly, this strategy is now a comprehensive plan to create a Union of equality for all of us. We have to make sure that LGBTI citizens are no longer treated as second-class citizens in the European Union. We enjoy exactly the same right to freedom of movement as everybody else, and when we move, we want to stay protected by EU law. The Commission President rightly said a parent in one Member State is a parent in all Member States. I would like to add, like my colleague said, a marriage partner in one Member State should be a marriage partner in all Member States.  But most of all, I would like to take this opportunity to remind all of us of the people we actually have to thank for the progress we have made in our community over the last few decades. It wasn’t rich people wearing fancy suits who started this movement for equality; it wasn’t in palaces or parliaments where the struggle for our rights began. It was in the streets, in dodgy bars, in forbidden places where the talk of our liberation was ignited. Black trans activists, queers, marginalised groups – who were ridiculed, attacked and oppressed – had the courage to start this. Today and every day their power made this movement. Let us never forget that.  (Applause)

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that, regardless of gender and sexual orientation, all European citizens must be guaranteed the same rights and the same legal protection. Now I wonder if this statement I have just made is racist. On the contrary, I believe that it is racist to divide people according to an endless series of sexual categories and subcategories, as this report does: L, G, B, T, Q, I, A, P, K, if we want to update the list at 5.05 p.m. today. We got to nine, not to consider the old, outdated categories of male and female. It seems ridiculous to me and also a little suspicious, if I have to read page 20 of that report, which states that local organisations will receive support through economic funding from the European Union.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to say to colleagues that this is not about any ideology or anything political. This is about human rights, equality and non-discrimination. That is why this first LGBTIQ strategy in history is so long awaited and so welcome that I would like to express my thanks to the Commission for this. Its importance in this time has become more pronounced. In a time when in many countries the rights of sexual and gender minorities are being trampled under and even presidential elections are being waged with homophobic hate speech. In that time, the importance of this strategy will be greater than its size.  It contains many good openings and I would like to point out myself that I am delighted that the particularly vulnerable situation of asylum seekers belonging to sexual and gender minorities has been taken into account. It has been recognised that this is a genuine problem and that development needs have been put forward. This section is very well written, but it is in complete contradiction to what we know about the new migration and asylum agreement. I wish these well-written words, which make it possible to safeguard the legal protection of every applicant, could if these words were to become part of the eu refugee policy as a whole.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic that should have brought us closer and made us more sensitive has, on the other hand, exacerbated the internal rift in our society even more. Hate-hate incidents are common place on the agenda and discrimination against those still considered different is more entrenched than ever before. Equality and the universal recognition of fundamental rights even here in the European Union are still a long way from being achieved. The LGBT community in particular, women and adolescents, see their rights trampled underfoot every day, victims of blackmail and exploitation. We live in a world where people are still sold as slaves, where prostitution is not exploitation if it brings profit to the country, where hatred runs fast on the Internet and is often called freedom of expression. We have become so used to turning the other way that we can no longer see the right way forward, and this fault is paid for by millions of European citizens. We need a major change of course, and the strategy for lgbt equality could be the beginning of a broader transformation, based on the pillars of the fight against discrimination, security and equality, with the aim of creating an inclusive society. I call on the Commission and this House to be courageous at this juncture, because combating violence and discrimination is a moral and civil duty.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, six out of ten LGBTIQ people avoid going hand in hand on the street, two out of five have been harassed over the past year, one in five have been harassed at work and one in three have felt discrimination when socialized. Many LGBTIQ people have to live in the dark because they are suffering, in today's Europe, discrimination. With COVID, the COVID pandemic has become even more vulnerable. That is why this strategy, the Commission's first strategy, for equality of LGBTIQ groups, is very welcome. It is very welcome because it is a shared responsibility to protect human rights. We are talking about human rights, the right to freedom, the right to physical integrity, fundamental rights. It is important to ensure the safety of this collective. It is important that there is no discrimination, that we are an example of inclusivity, that diversity is respected and that we are pioneers in leading equality around the world. But for that we have to preach by example. The Commission, Parliament, civil society, each of us with our actions. Because if we accept discrimination, we will be accepting the strengthening of diversity intolerance. We'll be accepting an attack on human dignity. We will be accepting that inequality is normalized and we will be accepting the cancer of democracy. That is why, welcome this strategy, and all together we fight for a Europe on equality where everyone can love whoever they want and not be discriminated against.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. All people must be allowed to love and live as they please, and it is up to politicians to create the framework conditions for a happy life. The European Union's LGBTIQ equality strategy is therefore an important step in the right direction and, above all, at a time when we need it most urgently. Governments across Europe are trying to destroy our diverse society. It is quite clear that where democracy and fundamental rights are threatened, LGBTIQ people are among the first people affected. In Poland: the inhumane LGBTIQ-free zones. In Hungary: Discrimination against homosexuality and transidentity is to be elevated to constitutional status. And you could continue there. In the European Union, 53% of LGBTIQ people are affected by hostility. What are these horrendous figures? Violence against the LGBTIQ community is rising particularly rapidly where politics fuels hatred and discrimination. This must not happen in our Europe! No one should have to live in secret and fear violence on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity. Europe must guarantee the protection of human rights and citizens a self-determined life. A life away from discrimination, a life away from violence, that is what we all deserve in our European Union.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: Madam President, tomorrow France will pay tribute to Daniel Cordier, who has died at the age of 100. He was the penultimate Surviving Liberation Companion. 1038 of them were so distinguished for their action in the liberation of France in the face of Nazi oppression more than 75 years ago. I'm talking about him because Daniel Cordier was gay. He wrote it in his memoirs at the honourable age of 89. However, you will find few articles recalling this aspect of its identity. But why is this part of the identity of this French hero so erased? What for? Elsewhere, it is the so-called LGBT ideology that municipalities in Poland and more recently Hungary would like to erase. But President von der Leyen pointed out that we cannot tolerate this desire to erase, because being gay, lesbian, bi, transgender or intersex is not an ideology, it is an identity that some would like to erase. Colleagues, Commissioner, you were with us for the Renew Europe seminar. We listened to this poignant testimony of Benedict, whose loving parents, with the best will in the world, wanted to erase this part of identity. Of course, I'm talking about conversion therapies. You are talking about this, I want to support you, I want to tell you that we will support you, especially if you go further. We are with you, Commissioner, for Europe to become, as our colleague Sophia in't Veld has suggested, a welcome zone, that is, a continent where we can no longer, where we must no longer erase the identity of people on the pretext that this identity is homosexual.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In the current FOCUS, a German news magazine, columnist Jan Fleischhauer asked the provocative question of how to explain how it could be explained that President Trump – the still-president – not only gained among women, Latinos and black voters, but that the number of lesbians and gays who voted for Trump this time had actually doubled. Why do so many people with an LGBTIQ orientation feel represented by Trump and obviously not discriminated against? Many people with the aforementioned orientation do not want to be dragged into the public eye. They know who they are and what they want. They simply want to be perceived for what they are: people like you and me and with all the rights and duties that we enjoy in our wonderful Europe. Let us therefore leave them alone with our strategies! Voter behaviour in America could otherwise be repeated in our case.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The EU's LGBTQI strategy is a clear sign against the right-wing populist winds blowing in Europe, against Hungary's constant attempts to curtail the rights of transgender people, against the Polish LGBTQI-free zones that make life a hell for thousands of people. It is a mark against an extreme and vile intolerance and a distorted view of humanity. But fine words on paper don't make a difference. The civil society organizations that I am in regular contact with, they want to see change now. We must ensure that the EUROPEAN Union lives up to the fundamental values that we have about equality, about respect for human rights and on non-discrimination. And it should cover everyone, not only in theory but in practice.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Madam President, my family, with two mothers, we are a family every day, from the morning when I wake my kids up – my daughter prefers music, so that’s what I try to use – until we put them to bed at night and kiss them goodnight. But, legally speaking, our family ceases to be a family if we move to certain countries in this Union. So how do you explain that to a child? Well, I’ll tell you, you don’t, because it is unacceptable. So what do you do? You wake up and you fight for your family and for all other rainbow families, as well as for same-gender partners. And that’s why I welcome the fact that the Commission is finally taking action to ensure that I will not have to explain this to my kids.  I also welcome other parts of the strategy: the fight against hate crimes, hate speech, the way we’re going to support education that’s inclusive. Finally, this strategy, as has been said here, comes at a very important moment where we see LGBTI people in Poland, Hungary and elsewhere being harassed and persecuted. We cannot have it anymore. It has to stop!  (Applause)

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Madam President, Mrs Dalli, ladies and gentlemen, today is the international day to eradicate violence against women, and I really want to remind everyone from this step that the fight against violence and inequality never stops. Ensuring equality, freedom and rights is a moral and worthy pillar of the European Union. These values are also served by the new strategy for the equality of LGBTIQ and non-binary individuals. For many years, as Europe and as states, we have volunteered for this social group and allowed extreme elements to violate the rule of law and take aggressive actions.  Whether we disagree or agree with the existence of these individuals, we must not allow our society to slip into violence and violation of people's rights to self-determination. That is why, as the Vice-President for Values and Transparency, Mrs Vera Yurova, said, everyone should feel free to be themselves without fear of persecution. That is the essence of Europe. Everyone in the European Union should feel safe and free without fear of discrimination, in particular because of sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression or gender characteristics. I cannot deny that progress has been made in the European Union in recent years on the equality of LGBTQI people, but they are still discriminated against. This can also be seen from the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights survey carried out in 2019. I hope that with this new strategy the Member States will create national strategies and enable these people to live without fear.

name: Cyrus ENGERER
text: – "The Pursuit of Happiness" (It-tfittxija għall-milja tal-kuntentezza). Ippermettuli nislet dawn il-kliem minn Jefferson għaliex nemmen li l-inqas ħaġa li jistgħu jagħmlu l-gvernijiet, f'kwalunk Statwe madwar l-Unjoni Ewropea u f'postijiet oħra, hu li jippermettu li大-大ittadini tagħhom - nisa, irġiel, u anke dawk li ma jpoġġux il-ġeneru tagħhom f'xi kaxxa partikolari – biex jgħixu l-ħixja fil-milja kompleta tagħhom għall-kuntentezza koll taghaħhom. Ngħix fejn ngħix madwar l-Unjoni Ewropea, jiena bħala raġel gay u l-familja tiegħi għandu jkollna l-istess drittijiet, l-istess libertajiet u l-istess protezzjoni daqs kull ħittadin ieħor u daqs kull familja oħra fl-Un Ewropea kollha. F'dan l-ewwel diskors tiegħi f'dan il-Parlament, ippermettili nindirizza lil ħuti LGBTIQ fil-Polonja u fl-Ungerija u f'kull pajjiż ieħor madwar id-dinja li jħħħad id-drittijiet fundamentali li-大大dinidi tieħu. Aħna hawnhekk, fil-Parlament Ewropew, nafu minn xiex għaddejjin, qegħdin magħkom u mhux se nħallukom waħidkom. Aħna mhux se nieqfu naħdmu sakemm naraw illi intom ukoll ikollkom id-drittijiet fundamentali tagħkom protetti u tkunu ttigħu tgħixu l-ħajja fil-milja kollha tagħha. Irrid nifraħ flower-Gumssarju Dalli u lit-tim tagħha għall-istrateġija li ressqu quddiemna llum hawnhekk. Strateġija illi, aħna li għandna l-għaqda Maltija, tant kb kb biha illi f'pajjiżna rnexxielna nkunu wkoll ta' eżempju għall-kumplament tal-pajjiżi l-oħrajn fl-Unjoni Ewropea, ta' fejn nistgħu naslu, "from zero hero". Kif għamilna f'pajjiżna, jista' jkollna wkoll Unjoni Ewropea li timxi "from zero to hero" u fejn hawk tifel u tifla, it-tfal kollha, li jitwieldu fl-Unjoni Ewropea, tkun xi tkun l-identità tagħhom, ikunu jafu li fl-Unjoni Ewropea tagħna jistgħu jilħqu l-kuntentezza kollha tagħhom.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I congratulate you on your first speech!

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: – Madam President, first I would like to compliment the European Commission for publishing their first ever LGBTIQ equality strategy. I am happy to see that this Commission finally puts LGBTIQ rights high on the agenda and is now presenting concrete plans to improve LGBTIQ rights throughout Europe. And, may I say, not a moment too soon, as we are still witnessing many LGBTIQ persons dealing with discrimination simply because of who they are and whom they love. We have heard about the awful attacks on pride marches and have seen the growing number of LGBTI-free zones, and within Europe we still have these unimaginable treatments such as conversion therapy and barbaric forced sterilisation. And can anyone tell me how we can allow people losing their parental rights over their own child by crossing a border within the European Union? How do we rhyme the denial of parental rights of rainbow families with our European values? We simply cannot allow for these practices to go on any longer. Everybody should have the right to be who they are and love whom they want and to decide what happens to their own bodies. This LGBTIQ strategy is a good first step, but as a Member of the European Parliament, I like plans – but what I like even better is action. So let’s get to work, Commission. Let’s get this done.

name: Monika VANA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which As a member of the LGBTIQ intergroup, I very much welcome the strategy. Equality for all people, regardless of their gender identity, appearance or sexual orientation, should actually be a matter of course in a united Europe. It is shocking that almost half of all LGBTIQ people report direct experiences of discrimination and even there are so-called LGBTIQ-free zones. This is unacceptable in Europe. So the Commission's strategy is actually at its best, but it is not enough. One is a strategy, the other is decisive action and implementation. I think that all Member States, supported by the Commission, are now also called upon to build a society that is pro-LGBTIQ. We need to act urgently and legislate, because LGBTIQ rights are human rights.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, again if I were to sum up your comments here in a few words, what we are saying here is that LGBTI persons’ rights are human rights and there is no place for second-class citizens in the European Union. And yes, I look forward to living in a Europe which is humanity-welcoming, without humanity-free zones.  I want to refer to a particular question which was put with regard to migrants and refugees, and yes, the LGBTIQ equality strategy contains a whole section on the upholding of rights of LGBTIQ applicants for international protection, and here we have specific actions in that regard, namely that we will ensure appropriate protection of vulnerable applicants in the context of the common European asylum system and its reforms, and also that we will ensure support for LGBTIQ equality in action under the asylum and migration pact.  Honourable Members, dear friends, I really thank you for your contributions and for your support, for your commitment to LGBTIQ equality. Combating discrimination in the EU is a shared responsibility and deserves a collective European effort. We will continue with our cooperation towards this goal. I thank you heartily for your support now and your support before the strategy, during the writing of the strategy and, of course, most importantly, now in the implementation phases of the strategy. Thank you for making this possible.  (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – I welcome the FIRST EU strategy for equality for LESBIAN, GAY and bisexual, trans, non-binal, intersex and lgbtiq people. Although some progress has been made in this area, discrimination and stigmatisation of LGBTIQ persons in the EU is still very much present. We therefore need a coordinated and, above all, codified effort to preserve and improve the status quo, as well as to improve and unify the parameters for determining the level of discrimination as a condition for equality. The strategy brings a range of long-term measures in the area of legislation, the extension of the definition of hateful acts, the regulation of the issue of parenting in cross-border relationships, the protection of the rights of rainbow families and the fight against discrimination. Above all, the new strategy guarantees a more consistent consideration of the rights and diversity of LGBTIQ persons in the design and implementation of all EU policies. While promoting equality between LGBTIQ people is the responsibility of the Member States, the EU still has an important role to play in coordinating actions, monitoring progress, providing support and, above all, in promoting and promoting progressive social policies. In order to achieve true equality and non-discrimination in line with the EU's fundamental principles and values, we need structural change with the EU as a leader. The new strategy is a step in that direction.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – It was high time the European Commission issued it’s first-ever EU strategy for LBTIGQ equality. In an era of governments establishing “LGBTI free zones”, here, within our Union, a strategy for mainstreaming the rights of this community is of utmost importance. The European Union is a place of openness and respect, respect for all people, no matter their origin, religion or sexual orientation. I am proud to see that the Commission has committed to put forward initiatives to combat discrimination, ensure individual safety, and open a dialogue to ban entirely the abhorrent practice of “conversion therapy”. The EU must promote the rights of all families, including LGBTIQ families. A system of mutual recognition of parenthood and same-gender partnerships between Member States would ensure that everyone’s rights are respected across the EU. This would also truly mean upholding the right to freedom of movement. No matter our shortcomings, the EU remains one of the most progressive regions in the world. We must continue our fight by promoting LGBTIQ rights and non-discrimination, both within our Union and beyond.

name: Estrella DURÁ FERRANDIS
text: in writing. – EU leaders met to discuss the Commission's first strategy for equality for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, non-binary, intersex and queer (LGBTIQ), presented by the Commission on 12 November. The Strategy sets out a number of specific actions around the following four priorities: (1) combating discrimination; 2) Ensure safety by expanding the list of "EU crimes" to include hate crimes, and incitement to hatred against LGBTIQ people; (3) protection of the rights of rainbow families through a legislative initiative to support mutual recognition of same-sex union within Member States; 4) promote LGBTIQ equality within the framework of the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), the Pre-Accession Assistance Instrument (IPA) and the Asylum and Migration Fund. I support this strategy with the aim of Member States introduced and developing their own action plans for LGBTIQ equality, and to ensure better protection of LGBTIQ people against discrimination.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: in writing. – EU leaders met to discuss the Commission's first strategy for equality for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, non-binary, intersex and queer (LGBTIQ), presented by the Commission on 12 November. The Strategy sets out a number of specific actions around the following four priorities: (1) combating discrimination; 2) Ensure security by expanding the list of "EU crimes" to include hate crimes and hate speech against LGBTIQ people; (3) protection of the rights of rainbow families through a legislative initiative to support mutual recognition of same-sex union between Member States; 4) promote LGBTIQ equality within the framework of the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), the Pre-Accession Assistance Instrument (IPA) and the Asylum and Migration Fund. I support this strategy with the aim of Member States introduced and developing their own action plans for LGBTIQ equality and ensuring better protection of LGBTIQ people against discrimination.

name: Alicia HOMS GINEL
text: in writing. – EU leaders met to discuss the Commission's first strategy for equality for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, non-binary, intersex and queer (LGBTIQ), presented by the Commission on 12 November. The Strategy sets out a number of specific actions around the following four priorities: (1) combating discrimination; 2) Ensure security by expanding the list of "EU crimes" to include hate crimes and hate speech against LGBTIQ people; (3) protection of the rights of rainbow families through a legislative initiative to support mutual recognition of same-sex union between Member States; 4) promote LGBTIQ equality within the framework of the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), the Pre-Accession Assistance Instrument (IPA) and the Asylum and Migration Fund. I support this strategy with the aim of Member States introduced and developing their own action plans for LGBTIQ equality and ensuring better protection of LGBTIQ people against discrimination.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. – EU leaders met to discuss the Commission's first strategy for equality for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, non-binary, intersex and queer (LGBTIQ), presented by the Commission on 12 November. The Strategy sets out a number of specific actions around the following four priorities: (1) combating discrimination; 2) Ensure security by expanding the list of "EU crimes" to include hate crimes and hate speech against LGBTIQ people; (3) protection of the rights of rainbow families through a legislative initiative to support mutual recognition of same-sex union between Member States; 4) promote LGBTIQ equality within the framework of the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), the Pre-Accession Assistance Instrument (IPA) and the Asylum and Migration Fund. I, Juan Fernando López Aguilar, support this strategy with the aim of member states introduce and develop their own action plans for LGBTIQ equality and ensure better protection of LGBTIQ people against discrimination.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The last week of November marks a breakthrough in human rights work in the European Parliament. For the first time, the Commission has put a comprehensive equality strategy for LGBT+ people on the table. There is no doubt that these aspirations stem directly from EU values - everyone must be equal, enjoy the right to live in harmony with themselves and must not be discriminated against on grounds of sex, sexual orientation, religion, origin or disability. It should therefore come as no surprise that Parliament is reacting at a time when LGBT+-free zones are being created in some Member States and non-heterosexual teenagers are taking their own lives because of an atmosphere of intolerance in the statements of politicians or state media, which directly translates into public sentiment. The objectives of the strategy are to fight discrimination, ensure the safety and building of a society that includes LGBT+ people, and promote lgbt+ equality efforts around the world. We have a lot of work to do in this regard, in Poland, for example, there is no category of hate crime based on sexual orientation, and education does not provide for the promotion of non-discrimination. ILGA research shows that 70% of LGBT+ teens suffer from depression and suicidal thoughts. I believe that the strategy will be the beginning of a common policy guaranteeing fundamental rights for all throughout the European Union, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. –It is shocking that discrimination experienced by LGBTIQ+ individuals has increased in recent years in Europe. We must do everything we can to ensure that no European is afraid and discriminated against in his daily life, not in the workplace, on the streets, let alone online. I would like to thank the Commission's new LGBTIQ strategy, in fact it is high time that we ensure that all people are not discriminated against. The addition of all forms of hate speech and all hate crimes, including rainbows, to the eu-confirmed list of crimes is a good thing, hate crimes and hate speech are constantly on the increase and we must put a stop to this. We need to ensure that LBGTIQ+ people receive good, reliable, knowledgeable and confidential healthcare in every Member State. We must also ensure that each Member State recognises the rights verified in another country, for example, to custody and marriage in cross-border situations, otherwise it will be an obstacle to freedom of movement.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The strategy raises a number of questions. Social policy issues, including measures to combat inequalities, social exclusion and discrimination, fall within the competences shared between the European Union and the Member States (Article 4 and 7 TFEU) and therefore, in the actions taken in this area, the Union is committed to the principle of subsidiarity. The issues of morality, sexual morality, family shape, the relationship between parents and children, the extent of public interference in citizens' intimate lives are deeply rooted in the culture of the EU Member States and are fundamentally diverse. This strategy explicitly seeks to uniformise member states' cultures in terms of understanding basic terms such as gender or social institutions, such as family. In that regard, it infringes Article 167 TFEU. There is no possibility, in accordance with the Treaties, of arbitrary interference by the Commission or Parliament in the content of teaching, including the use of the term 'family' in the context of same-sex relationships. In accordance with Article 167(1) TFEU, the Union has a duty to respect the diversity of member states' cultures, while emphasising their common cultural heritage with Judeo-Christian roots. In accordance with Article 167(4) TFEU, in all its activities under other provisions of the Treaties, the European Union has a duty to promote the diversity of cultures represented there.

name: Nicola BEER
text: We now come to the second round of voting today. The dossiers on which we are now voting can be found on the agenda. The voting round is open from 8 p.m. to 9.15 p.m. The same voting procedure will apply as in the previous voting rounds. All votes are taken by roll call. I hereby declare the second round of voting open. You can now vote until 9.15 p.m.
